name: amitrawal-ai
content: This quote by Vladimir Ilyich Lenin certainly applies to the way America shops for Groceries. For the longest time, Grocery e-commerce was considered a laggard with only 3-4% penetration compared to that of fashion and electronics with over 20%. And for good reasons - low margin, highly perishable, variable quality, and high last-mile cost as a % of order values, made grocery e-commerce a potentially large but economically unattractive market. Thus, retailers other than behemoths such as Amazon and Walmart didn't make serious investments in this space. Today is different. Covid-19 has turbo-charged the demand for delivery of groceries and thus, overnight, created the potential economies of scale that would have taken years, if not decades. With the total market grocery e-commerce market expected to be ~$60B+ over the next 3 years, the stakes are high and the consumers are hungry [pun intended], for more variety, faster delivery, and more delightful experiences. While the current and future service-innovations such as 2-hour deliveries, buy-online-pick-up in-store or curbside, autonomous/drone deliveries will continue to accelerate the growth, I argue that the future of grocery retail demands a much higher bar. The truth is that despite the size of the market and the order velocity, the grocery shopping experience leaves a lot to be desired. But, before we explore what retailers can do to design the next-gen experiences, let's focus on the consumers and understand why and how people buy groceries. For all intents and purposes, I'll define grocery shopping as "food" related items for household consumption and focus on the e-commerce channel. The Why: Grocery buying is a means to an end . And that end has different use-cases in today's environment. For instance, groceries are converted into foods, which can be a source of energy, happiness, social status, medicine, recovery, and connection. Then, why are the retailers still selling groceries just as ingredients, and not focusing on the value they create? The What: Grocery buying is one of the most predictable, repeatable, and inefficient processes . No wonder, 85% of Americans don't like grocery shopping. I assume most grocery carts look the same, every week. It is estimated that an average American makes 1.6 trips per week and spends at least 60 hours per year buying groceries, not including the driving time. With at least 50M people shopping, that's 3 billion hours/year of collective human life spent on buying eggs, potatoes, cheese, etc. every week. Go figure. Why do we have to go to each corner of the store or create an online cart every time? Why can't this be on autopilot? Some will argue that this will prevent the discovery of new products - I argue that it will leave more room for discovery if retailers can leverage digital technologies to personalize discovery. Heck, I don't browse the entire Spotify or Netflix catalog every week, but still consume more content than ever before. So why can't the Grocery catalog be more like Spotify? The How: When most people buy groceries, they think of what meals they need to cook on the following attributes - 1) Time of day - breakfast, lunch, dinner, snacks 2) Diet - Vegan, Keto, high protein, etc. 3) Health restrictions - Diabetes, high blood pressure, Gluten, etc. intolerance, etc. 4) Age/life-stage - kid-friendly, elderly-tolerant, pregnancy, surgery, etc. 5) Risks - high sodium, mercury, GMOs, etc. 6) Price/Quality - Organic, Kosher, Frozen, Fresh 7) Convenience - Ready to heat, read to eat, etc. 8) Health benefits - anti-inflammatory, muscle building, immunity-boosting, etc. So why isn't the grocery catalog tagged with these attributes? And why does the customer need to expend energy in searching for products matching these attributes? The obvious answer is that this is really hard to do, You deserve better! And the retailers need to adapt and integrate just as fashion retail has evolved from selling clothes, shoes, and accessories to selling style, status, and statement . This is the shift from "Transactional" to "Experiential" retail. Here are 5 ways retailers can build a more delightful and integrated future: Based on the 30 elements of value framework created by Bain and Co., below are the elements that could be relevant for the customers. While there are table stakes, i.e. fundamental elements such as Quality, Variety, Reduces cost, Saves time, and Rewards-me, the true differentiators could be elements in the emotional, life-changing, and social impact categories . Note: Which of these categories and corresponding elements you prioritize will depend on the type of target markets and consumers. For example, urban and rural consumers may value different elements and thus the strategy needs to be aligned with the target segments. Here is an example of one element in each category: a. FUNCTIONAL - Reduces costs: by auto-applying coupons and offer bundles b. EMOTIONAL - Badge Value: If Kroger or Publix is the Macys of grocery retail, then Whole Foods is Bloomingdales. If you shop at Whole Foods, it says that you seek premium and high-quality products, and are willing to pay a premium for them. It is a matter of positioning and the corresponding value proposition that creates an emotional value for the consumers. c. LIFE CHANGING - Motivation: dedicated section, for athletes and fitness conscious people, that re-inforces healthy choices through tracking of macros. d. SOCIAL IMPACT - Self Transcendence: According to a recent survey , 60% of the Millenials were aware of the implications of their food choices on the environment, and 50% of them considered factors such as packaging while making purchases. So, through education about farming practices, waste reduction initiatives, and local sourcing, retailers can appeal to the consumers' desire to be more socially responsible. Wegmans is the most loved grocery store in the US, and it has built customer-loyalty by investing in its communities. If there is a shopping category that is ripe for personalization, it is Groceries. We have clearly defined preferences, restrictions, and affinities that don't change frequently, so it is a no-brainer (doesn't mean it's easy) to capture these attributes and personalize the offering. For example, if I'm a vegan than I should not be seeing meat or dairy as part of my feed, as that is wasted digital real-estate, but I do. And that's an annoying experience. [Image source: Whisk] But to take this to the next level, imagine if your grocery shopping app could connect to your Apple Health app and detect that you run every day and recommend "coconut water" as a "Rehydrate after your run" in your personalized feed. Boom! The privacy evangelists may cringe at this, but trust me, it's coming. This is the most critical step in enhancing the consumer experience. As a new breed of shoppers, especially those who are not digital-natives migrate to grocery e-commerce, the shopping experience needs to simplified - right from discovery to checkout. Carrying on the personalization theme, the landing page needs to show fewer, but more relevant products, need to provide the shortest path to checkout and make the process quickly repeatable on the next visit. As an example, the Amazon Fresh landing page is overwhelming for me and the majority of the items listed are irrelevant. In contrast, Thrive Market knows me much better and provides me a simple and relevant landing page, which increases my odds and speed of finding products. You may also have to search for new items every now and then. So a key element of simplification is multi-search capability , which allows the users to search multiple items at once or put the name of a recipe and get a list of items to be added to cart in one go . Ocado executed a part of this strategy and witnessed 30% more traffic to the multi-page search results page. Automation of the customer journey can be achieved through lists and auto-replenishment services such as the "Reserved" service offered by Ocado. Using the Reserved service, Ocado customers receive a regular delivery day and time on a weekly or fortnightly basis, with a virtual basket of goods that can be amended, arriving automatically. I was thrilled to discover a new Silicon Valley Start-up - Jupiter , started by fellow Stanford Alums, who are trying to solve for this automation. Food has a deep cultural and social meaning in our lives. We get inspired through blogs, videos on youtube, posts on Instagram, but very seldom that inspiration translates into a purchase at the Grocery store. Why? The journey from inspiration to the grocery cart is cumbersome. Grocery retailers can generate or source inspirational content such as recipes/ideas, and convert them into a shopping list, providing an easy path to purchase. [Image source: Whisk] With food cooking getting increasingly outsourced, given the rapid rise of food delivery services, the Grocery retailers have already moved up the value chain through "meal-kit" and "pre-cooked meal" services. Since a large portion of the costs of these services is the raw material, the large Grocery retailers have significant economies of scale. In addition, they have a physical presence in most cities, which can be leveraged to create dark kitchens that service local consumers. Finally, the last mile delivery costs can be also be subsidized through the existing network for grocery deliveries. Overall, this vertical integration should give retailers a larger share of the consumer's wallet and build more loyalty over time. Both Amazon and Walmart offer such services but haven't yet cracked the customer experience. Take Waitrose, in the UK as an example: it offers catering for "entertaining" as a service, where customers can order customized meals for various types of needs. There is an opportunity here in the US to enhance the experience by addressing more nuanced needs such as food by type of occasion, diets, age group, or health factors. As long as retailers can strike the balance between costs and quality, the demand for such services will only grow. Even though Grocery e-commerce is incredibly complex and poses several challenges that other categories such as fashion and electronics don't have, the size of the market, resurgence in consumer interest, and the opportunity to make an impact on our lives, make this category the next epic shopping-frontier. The retailers that have the capital need to obsess more about the customers and re-invent their operations to deliver joy and not just ingredients. Amit Rawal is a Sloan Fellow at Stanford's Graduate School of Business. He has spent the last decade in building and scaling e-commerce ventures for 40%+ of the world's population. At Stanford, he is focused on bringing together tech, design, and data to create joyful shopping experiences. He is a data geek and loves tracking all kinds of health and wellness metrics. He can be reached at amitr@stanford.edu . Links: Linkedin , Twitter , Instagram , Website

name: tuxboy
content: Monoliths don't sound cool for startups. I do agree. "We are running our infrastructure on Serverless Lambda Functions and 15 microservices are pulling data from a globally distributed MongoDB cluster." sounds way cooler than "We have a Backend pulling data from PostgreSQL". We had to swallow our pride; we had to make that critical call of moving from Microservices and Serverless Functions to a single, one-and-only Monolith. Why? We do not need independent deployability or targeted scalability. Our systems can afford to be deployed all at once. We have a small team. Managing numerous services and even keeping their dependencies up-to-date proved to be a daunting challenge. We had to acknowledge the size of our team and our limited capabilities. We are experimenting with our products all the time, which often requires fundamental changes to our systems. The microservices were blocking us from proceeding forward with new ideas and innovation. The system became too complex with simple logical blocks being spread around different microservices. Changes became unpredictable as the initial boundaries of services were not clearly defined. Now our features are easily testable, maintainable by a small team and changes are predictable. Adopting microservices may have been a premature optimization we should've avoided in the beginning! Will we ever consider microservices again? Yes, when the time is right and the product needs it. Clearly, our current position did not warrant such a distributed architecture that introduced complexity. Have you ever consolidated microservices into Monoliths or Services? What's your story?

name: abidalee
content: I recently changed my job and many of my friends were asking about my job search journey so I thought of sharing my experience with other professionals who may want to learn from my experience (or may have gone through the same), which happens to be a time consuming, tiring, and not to mention frustrating process. In fact looking for a job is a FULL TIME job. I started looking for a job a few months ago but it was not the first time I was looking for a job so I was mentally prepared to go through the long process. I have already been through the same cycle a few times when I graduated in 2005, then immigrated to the UK in 2008 and subsequently to the USA in 2009. Every time it took me three to six months to find a job. It takes a lot of time AND patience to find a suitable job and one should try all venues (and so did I) such as contacting friends/former colleagues, attending alumni or networking events, reaching out to recruiters, and applying online. I started looking for job posts on LinkedIn that aligned to my skills and then I would either send an email directly to the recruiter who had posted the job or in the case when there was no recruiter listed, I would simply go to the company site and apply online. It had become a daily morning ritual for me over the past few months. I applied to dozens of jobs and interviewed with dozens of companies and after a few months I finally got three job offers, of which I accepted one that aligned the most to my career aspirations, preferences, and priorities. I did get many emails from various recruiters during the process and I responded to all such emails politely whether the role was aligned to my career aspirations or not. I believe it is only polite and professional to do so and all recruiters as well as job seekers should do the same (because some don‚Äôt and it is not professional at all). And last but not the least, job seekers should consider job search as the old fairy tale goes, ‚Äòyou have to KISS MANY FROGS before you FIND your prince charming.‚Äô So the entire process of job applications and interviews is like 'kissing the frogs' and it will help you grow at the least until you find a suitable job. The key is to have patience, persistence and perseverance. Good luck to those who are in search/need of a new opportunity and thanks to those who helped me during the process.

name: ahmohamedali
content: ùêìùê°ùêû ùêáùê¢ùêùùêùùêûùêß ùêëùê¢ùê¨ùê§ ùê®ùêü ùêÄùê†ùêûùêßùê≠ùê¢ùêú ùêÄùêà ùêàùê¨ ùêçùê®ùê≠ ùêÑùê±ùêûùêúùêÆùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß. ùêàùê≠‚Äôùê¨ ùêÄùêÆùê≠ùê°ùê®ùê´ùê¢ùê≥ùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß. When a human makes a decision, there is a person to ask. When a system makes a decision, there is a log to inspect. When an agent delegates to another agent, and that one to another, decisions multiply. Hundreds. Thousands. Millions of micro-decisions per day. There are logs. There are traces. There is telemetry everywhere. But there is no explicit moment where authority was exercised. Agentic AI does not remove records. It floods organizations with them, while dissolving authorship. The problem is not lack of data. It is lack of accountable commitment. Can we prove that someone, human or organizational, explicitly authorized the action before it happened? If the only record of that authorization lives inside the systems that executed it, it is not independent evidence. It is self-reporting. As autonomy scales, accountability does not degrade gradually. It disappears at the exact point where authority was never explicitly declared.

content: Had an energizing Day 2 at the IndiaAI Impact Summit, filled with engaging conversations with leaders from the Telecom Ministry, Ministry of Home Affairs, Transport Ministry, and several industry partners shaping India‚Äôs AI landscape. A standout moment was a deep conversation with Raj Reddy‚Äî Turing Award laureate and #AI pioneer known for his foundational work in artificial intelligence and speech recognition. We discussed the growing #startup and #VC ecosystem in South Asia and the opportunity to build globally impactful AI ventures from the region. His encouragement was truly motivating. name: amitrajit-manna-5aaab5216
content: Been a little while since I posted on here, but thought I‚Äôd pause for a bit and reflect on the last 12 months! I‚Äôm ending 2025 feeling quite proud of a year that‚Äôs moved between studios, football pitches, concert halls, a lot of Teams Calls, and a few unexpected places in between. A few moments I‚Äôm especially proud of: - 4 world premieres, including my first symphony orchestra piece and my Bridgewater Hall debut - Writing a whole chamber opera (still can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm typing that - news about a premiere to come very soon!) - Leading research into the legacy of the FA Leadership Academy and hosting this year‚Äôs opening ceremony alongside Alex Caird - Stepping into a new role within The FA National Youth Council and making significant progress supporting the youth voice in the west - Finishing off a new commission that I can‚Äôt wait to share about in the new year Classical music and the Youth Leadership space in football aren‚Äôt as far apart as they sometimes look‚Ä¶ Grateful for the people I‚Äôve worked with this year - onwards to 2026!

name: oliver-reeves
content: A recommendation below from a recent placement at a scale up. 'I highly recommend Oliver to anyone looking for a recruiter who truly understands their needs. From the start, he took the time to understand my background, career goals, and what I was looking for in my next opportunity. Rather than just matching me with any open position, he connected me with the right company‚Äîone that aligns with my skills, values, and aspirations. Beyond his deep industry knowledge, Oliver has a keen ability to assess not just job fit but also cultural and leadership alignment. He introduced me to a company with a CIO whose vision and leadership style matched exactly what I was looking for. But what truly sets Oliver apart is that he‚Äôs more than just a recruiter‚Äîthroughout the process, he has been a mentor, offering invaluable insights into what companies truly expect and how to navigate the transition successfully. Over time, Oliver has evolved from a recruiter into both a friend and a mentor, always providing thoughtful advice and guidance. His support has made a significant impact on my career, and I‚Äôm incredibly grateful for everything he‚Äôs done. If you‚Äôre looking for someone who genuinely cares, goes the extra mile, and builds lasting professional relationships, I can‚Äôt recommend Oliver enough.'

name: amitrawal-ai
content: Some people argue that Peloton is Apple (HW), Tesla (DTC), and Netflix (Content) combined into one company. While it doesn't match the scale of any of these iconic brands, it is certainly matching them in their early growth rates. Peloton recently released its Quarterly numbers, and as expected, the demand for its bikes and subscription service exploded in the Corona economy. I will split this write-up into 3 parts: Signals, Analysis, and Predictions. For Q3, 2020, Sales were up 66%, $524.6 million in sales exceeding estimates of $485.4 million. Added 176K subscribers to the app without the hardware, total subscribers to 886K , nearly doubling from last year 23K people joined a single class . Yes, that's probably the largest fitness class ever. 44M workouts in the last quarter , 490K workouts per day on average, which is up 80%. For the full 2020 fiscal year, estimated revenue to reach between $1.72 billion and $1.74 billion , a year-over-year increase of 89% , vs. previously estimated $1.53 billion to $1.55 billion. A leading indicator of future growth: deliveries of Peloton have gone from 2-3 days to 8-10 weeks , indicating that demand is exceeding supply. This should sustain at least until the world gets back to some normalcy. As of last Monday, the company‚Äôs stock is up more than 61% over the last 12 months. Peloton now has a market cap of about $12.1 billion - i.e. currently valued at more than 7x MACYS, which is a 161-year-old iconic brand. Let that sync in. But the key question is does this accelerated growth represent a pull-forward of demand or an expansion of the addressable market? Let's look at the size of the market as estimated by Peloton. As per the data below (Source: Peloton Investor Presentation), the total addressable market in the US is about 62M users, who collectively spend $30B a year on gym memberships and fees. This is an average annual spend of $500 per user. However, since Peloton plays in the more premium category and charges ~ $1,200 year (including the cost of the connected equipment at $57 per month + subscription fee of $39 per month), it's SAM (Serviceable Available Market) is much smaller at 14M users and ~$17B. It is estimated to do $1.7B in the fiscal year 2020, thus reach 10% penetration. So back to the key question, has COVID-19 expanded this "connected fitness" market or just accelerated growth for Peloton? The real answer is still unknown, but we have some clues and assumptions. Given what we know, it will be 18 to 24 months before people feel fully comfortable going back to the gyms. I'm betting that people's behavior will be significantly altered and there will be more innovations in the "at-home" fitness space such as the Mirror and Tonal , resulting in more than 25% of the gym-goers to convert. And there are clear benefits from a cost and convenience perspective. According to Peloton, the cost per user is significantly cheaper compared to the in-studio experiences, even after factoring in the cost of the equipment. Most of these comparisons are with the higher end of the market and combined with the current situation make Peloton and the likes extremely attractive for these users. However, for the market to expand, new products at lower price points ($40-$60 per month, $500-$700 a year) will be introduced either by Peloton or new entrances that will try to take a bite of this market. Let's talk about the economic moat - defined as structural features that allow a firm to sustain excess profits over a long period of time . Based on my years of experience in running DTC digital businesses, for any such business to be viable in the long run, two things must happen: a. The acquisition cost must go down and remain low over time: for this to happen the business needs to maintain a low churn rate (the rate at which you lose customers) and increasingly acquire customers through organic channels such as word of mouth. b. Customer life value must stay steady or even better, go up: this can happen through recurring revenues from your consumers and through an increase in average revenue per user (ARPU) with adjacent products and services (i.e. higher share of wallet). A combination of a and b translate into sustainable and attractive unit economics (defined in terms of unit customers), thus creating a profitable business for the long term. Here's a simple equation to understand the strength of the moat in terms of attractive unit economics. Where CLTR is the total lifetime revenue; Margins are the Contribution Margins for such revenue; CAC is the avg. customer acquisition cost. So Peloton shared an analysis, where it showed that it almost breaks even in the first year of customer acquisition. Considering it has a ~3 years financing program, let's assume a customer stays with them for at least 3 years. This takes the CLTV to the CAC ratio to 3:1. My prediction is that this ratio will get even better over time, as it introduces new products and upgrades programs. Here's what makes Peloton's moat defensible. 1. Vertically integrated platform [translation: higher margins]: Like Apple, Tesla, and now Netflix, Peloton is vertically integrated. This means it controls the entire value chain of the business including Hardware, Original Content, and Proprietary Software (including UI/UX). Not only does this allow it to deliver a tightly integrated, premium experience, but also gives it extremely healthy margins of ~45% . 2. Brand Sex-Appeal, Social Quotient and Customer Loyalty [translation: Network effects] Peloton's aspirational positioning makes it the iPhone of at-home fitness. The elegant design, high touch brand experience with luxurious 96 global showrooms, and elevated experience through various digital and physical touchpoints, makes it an extremely attractive product offering. As a result, it has a cult-like following, and power-users act like brand evangelists. As per Peloton, 43% of first-time buyers heard about the brand through WOM. I can vouch for this personally since a friend who uses Peloton was so passionate that she converted me into a buyer while doing research on this story. Voila! New customer, zero CAC. The element of social engagement - we ride together, compete with each other, facetime while riding to push each other, give high-fives, and earn awards, makes this an immersive and socially rich experience, all from the comfort of your home. 3. Recurring revenue bundle of HW and SW (Rundle) [Translation: higher switching costs for consumers] The combination of a hardware and software subscription model is an extremely attractive proposition both for consumers and the business. Recurring revenue ensures the stability of cash flows and enables the business to retain its customers through cycles of upgrades. 4. Efficient Scale and Cost Advantage Given the number of paid users are now close to 1M, and likely to double over the next 12-24 months, Peloton will have a cost advantage that will be hard to match. Especially, when it comes to content production cost, which will get amortized across users, and continues to decline at a unit level as the base of consumers grows. Think Netflix vs. a new streaming service, the economies of scale that Netflix have are extremely hard to match for any new streaming service. 1. Peloton's market cap doubles , from $12B to $24B+ over the next 24-36 months as it introduces new sub-$1000 fitness equipment for stay-at-home workouts . Just as Tesla did, Peloton started with high-end and will expand downwards to the middle to gain a significantly larger share of this rapidly growing market. 2. Peloton and Spotify strike a partnership for music curation , and probably offer a combined subscription model for its users. 3. Peloton expands its eco-system and launches a wearable device (such as a Fitbit) that enables the user to track calories, sleep and intensity while using the equipment. While it's guaranteed that this "connected fitness-at-home" market is about to get extremely crowded , Peloton has built a strong lead, a robust platform, and a loyal customer base to catapult itself to become the market leader with 50%+ market-share of this $30B market . Thus, potentially growing 15 times from the current run rate of $1B and a market cap of $120B (8xRevenue). Happy days ahead! Amit Rawal is a Sloan Fellow at Stanford's Graduate School of Business. He has spent the last decade in building and scaling e-commerce ventures for 40%+ of the world's population. At Stanford, he is focused on bringing together tech, design, and data to create joyful shopping experiences. He is a data geek and loves tracking all kinds of health and wellness metrics. He can be reached at amitr@stanford.edu . Links: Linkedin , Twitter , Instagram , Website

name: areejanjum
content: Building with GenAI? This is the full stack you‚Äôre actually working with, whether you realize it or not When people talk about ‚ÄúLLM apps,‚Äù it often sounds like it‚Äôs just a model and a prompt. In reality, anything beyond a demo quickly turns into a multi-layered system. This visual does a great job of laying out the modern GenAI stack, end to end: üí† Models (LLMs) The reasoning engine. Open or closed models like GPT, Claude, Gemini, Llama, Mistral, etc. Powerful but incomplete on their own üí† Frameworks The orchestration layer. This is where prompts become workflows. Handling routing, memory, tool calls, and RAG logic. üí† Vector Databases The retrieval backbone. This layer decides what context the model sees and poor choices here show up immediately as hallucinations or irrelevant answers üí† Data Extraction & Ingestion The most underestimated layer. Cleaning PDFs, parsing web pages, structuring raw data üí† LLM Access & Inference How you actually run models; locally, hosted, or accelerated. This layer affects cost, latency, and experimentation speed üí† Embeddings The semantic representation layer. It quietly controls search relevance, clustering quality, and retrieval accuracy üí†Evaluation The reality check. Without systematic evaluation, you‚Äôre shipping vibes, not systems What this really highlights is that GenAI is now a systems engineering problem, not just prompt engineering. üìå Save this as a mental model when debugging or explaining GenAI systems. Visual Credits- Rahul Agarwal Follow Areej Anjum for more like this ************************************************************************ hashtag #GenAI hashtag #LLM hashtag #AIEngineering hashtag #RAG hashtag #VectorDatabases hashtag #LangChain hashtag #LlamaIndex hashtag #AIAgents hashtag #MachineLearning hashtag #LangChain hashtag #LangGraph

name: arjunsinghtomar
content: Last year, I was an intern sitting in the audience. Today, I was on stage as a speaker. We welcomed 99 new interns at DBS Tech India today, and watching them walk in.. excited, nervous, full of questions, it felt amazing :) Because that was exactly me one year ago. This time, I wasn‚Äôt looking for my seat.. I was holding the mic, sharing my journey as a former intern and Spark Apprentice. They asked me: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the one piece of advice you‚Äôd give to new interns?‚Äù I said.. one isn‚Äôt enough. So here‚Äôs what I shared: 1) ùóîùòÄùó∏ ùóæùòÇùó≤ùòÄùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ. Early. Often. Confusion grows in silence. Strong interns speak up, learn fast, and move forward with clarity. 2) ùó®ùóªùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄùòÅùóÆùóªùó± ùó≥ùó∂ùóøùòÄùòÅ. Build later. Before jumping into development, deeply understand the requirement. This habit alone can make you stand out in any team. 3) ùóßùóøùó≤ùóÆùòÅ ùó≥ùó≤ùó≤ùó±ùóØùóÆùó∞ùó∏ ùóÆùòÄ ùó≥ùòÇùó≤ùóπ, not fire. Feedback isn‚Äôt criticism, it‚Äôs an investment in your growth. The faster you accept it, the faster you improve. 4) ùóßùóøùóÆùó∞ùó∏ ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùòÑùóºùóøùó∏ ùó±ùóÆùó∂ùóπùòÜ. Maintain a simple log of tasks, progress, and learnings on what you do from morning 8 to evening 5 because when your manager asks for updates, you won‚Äôt hesitate rather you‚Äôll lead the conversation. 5) ùóïùòÇùó∂ùóπùó± ùóøùó≤ùóπùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóΩùòÄ, not just skills. Your internship isn‚Äôt just about code and meetings. It‚Äôs about mentors, teammates, and friendships that shape your journey. Growth outside work matters too. 6) ùó¶ùóÆùòÜ ùó¨ùóòùó¶ ùòÅùóº ùó≤ùòÉùó≤ùóøùòÜ ùóπùó≤ùóÆùóøùóªùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóºùóΩùóΩùóºùóøùòÅùòÇùóªùó∂ùòÅùòÜ, especially the scary ones. The projects that challenge you the most often define you the most. Opportunities rarely knock twice. Standing there today made me realize how much can change in just 1 year with consistency, curiosity, & the right environment. Grateful to the amazing HR team Pooja Sharma , Shantomona Bharadwaj , Rohit Raj & Prajwal Kumar for making the onboarding experience so warm and seamless. A lot of effort goes on behind the scenes to create a day like this. To the 99 interns who joined DBS Tech India today. You may feel like you‚Äôre just starting. But trust me, one year from now‚Ä¶ you could be the one inspiring the next batch üöÄ Welcome to DTI & all the very best üëçüèª Happy to connect ‚Äî Arjun Singh ! Have a great day ahead :) #DBSTechIndia #LiveFulfilled #InternshipJourney #HiringInterns #FromInternToSpeaker #CareerGrowth #LearningMindset #Gratitude #VIT #ArjunSingh

name: oliver-reeves
content: Despite being in the middle of a global pandemic, many companies are still looking to hire; especially those that rely heavily on the digitisation process of business. As we are no longer able to do many things in person, many businesses are taking their operations online, hence the high demand for tech developers of any kind. As companies are looking to hire the best talent for themselves, many are also struggling to fill the job vacancy. Why, you may ask? In my opinion, organisations should just streamline their hiring process and not drag the timeline out. If you want to hire the best tech developers the market has to offer, make sure your hiring process is as streamlined as possible. Every company wants to hire the best talent available and will understandably create a 5-7 stage recruitment process, for fear of hiring the wrong person. By doing so, I suppose one would likely be incredibly confident that the candidate will be the right fit for the organisation. However, I can also be confident enough to say that by having an overly lengthy hiring process will cost you to lose around 60% of the candidates you shortlisted at the beginning. It might come as (not so much of ) a shocker, but it is true (even from my own experience). The long and drawn out process leads candidates to drop out and lose interest; some will not appreciate the overly rigorous tech tests they are forced to do, some will get amazing offers elsewhere and go for those instead. The best tech developers out there will get offers the fastest, leaving companies with a short turnaround time and less costs incurred. Some powerhouse companies in countries like Singapore are taking advantage of the lucrative market for developers, hiring many of the best talent the country has to offer. As more organisations start hiring again and causing the market the change, companies with long and tedious hiring processes will ultimately find themselves being left in the dust; unable to hire candidates to fulfil their operational needs. At Revilo, the companies we work with that have the highest success rate in filling the job vacancies, have just a 2-stage process and no ‚Äòtake home‚Äô tests for developers to complete. As I tell our clients, you will always know when you have interviewed a developer with a quality of your liking, why waste time and potentially lose the candidate to another organisation, when you can be as straightforward as possible? If you know you are the first to present a candidate with an offer, you are giving yourself the best chance of securing them and fulfilling your company needs with their talent. But by making the process harder, you are more likely to set yourself and your company up for a difficult road ahead. Not only are you having to spend more time on the process itself, the cost of monetary resources used would eventually stack up. What would you rather?

name: nivedita-sinha-41a8907
content: 19 years in sales have taught me one thing, great outcomes come from structured thinking, meaningful conversations, and deeply understanding the customer needs. These learnings now shape how I design learning strategies and build capability programs at the Sales Academy. Recently, I designed and delivered PitchWorks for our Accounts teams, a training module built to show how data-driven, insight-led discussions can elevate every customer interaction. The core idea was simple yet powerful: Structured, multi-meeting engagement leads to customer delight and long-term trust. This one-day, high-energy workshop enabled us to train appx. 300 experienced sales professionals, delivered across 9 cities in last 3 months, with an NPS in the +55 to +65 range - a strong endorsement from an experienced audience. The feedback has been incredibly encouraging, with many participants recommending the session to their peers and even requesting an advanced follow-up edition. A big thank you to our business leaders Pawan Goyal and Niraj Kumar Rana for championing this initiative, our branch leaders for ensuring strong participation and every participant who brought their real-world insights. A special appreciation to Chitralekha Sumbrui for co-facilitating the data-driven insights module, and to the Naukri Sales Academy team Akshata Kamath , Priya Panjwani and Ashwin Bhat - for delivering high-volume, multi-city sessions with impressive dedication and seamless execution. Grateful for the opportunity to contribute, to share what I have learned over nearly two decades and excited to keep building learning experiences that elevate how we sell, engage, and grow together. #capabilitybuilding #SalesAcademy #FutureReadyTalent #TrainingImpact #SalesExcellence

name: gregorojstersek
content: 7 important lessons growing from an engineer to a senior leader: 1. Let go of perfection and make timely decisions. 2. Delegate intentionally and trust your people. 3. Focus on coaching and developing leaders. 4. Invest deeply in good working relationships. 5. Understand the business so engineering efforts support real goals. 6. Use metrics to stay aligned and manage expectations. 7. Protect alignment at the top, because it shapes the entire organization. It's a journey filled with new challenges at every stage. Each step, leading one team, managing multiple teams, or leading entire departments ‚Üí requires you to evolve how you think, communicate, and lead. Your job becomes less about doing the work yourself and more about empowering others to do their best work. You will make mistakes, everyone does. What matters is learning from them, adjusting, and continuing to improve. To learn more, read this Engineering Leadership article: https://lnkd.in/ePNDqMdj

name: tpschmidt
content: Small reminder that "spot" on AWS doesn't mean your instance could be gone in the blink of an eye. You're notified, and you have time to react. In my current project, 90% of the production workload runs on spot capacity, and it works great. ùóßùòÑùóº ùòÑùóÆùòÜùòÄ ùòÅùóº ùóµùóÆùóªùó±ùóπùó≤ ùó∂ùóªùòÅùó≤ùóøùóøùòÇùóΩùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ 1. ùóßùóµùó≤ ùüÆ-ùó∫ùó∂ùóªùòÇùòÅùó≤ ùòÑùóÆùóøùóªùó∂ùóªùó¥: You get a CloudWatch event 2 minutes before termination. Enough time to save state, finish critical tasks, or drain connections. 2. ùó•ùó≤ùóØùóÆùóπùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤ ùó•ùó≤ùó∞ùóºùó∫ùó∫ùó≤ùóªùó±ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª: This is a "pre-warning" that your instance is at elevated risk of interruption. Arrives a lot earlier than the 2-minute signal. Gives you time to checkpoint work or move to a fresh instance before the actual countdown starts. Services like Auto Scaling (or Karpenter; whatever you're using) can spin up a replacement as soon as this fires. Both signals are accessible via CloudWatch Events or instance metadata. Thanks for pointing this out Chris Northfield ! üí™ PS: If you want to dive deeper into EC2, I've put together a free visual breakdown that walks through how everything connects. Check it out here ‚Üí https://lnkd.in/d5ZXt_Gu

name: lowry-gladwell-a6566654
content: AS Colour wanted something simple: to settle overseas payments in the same currency. Instead, they hit a brick wall with their foreign bank. Then they found Airwallex . For Group CFO Cameron Irons, the reality of running a global Kiwi brand is complex. Paying suppliers, moving money between markets, managing banking relationships around the world. Like many Kiwi businesses scaling offshore, Cam needed AS Colour‚Äôs global banking and finance to move at the pace their business does (not the other way around). In our latest NZ case study, Cam explains how he made that happen with Airwallex. If you‚Äôre a Kiwi business growing globally and experiencing the same friction AS Colour faced, book a demo (link in the comments below). Shout out to the EPIC team at AS Colour, including Cameron , Clive and Joseph - we love working with you guys. And of course, the talented team that went into bringing the AS Colour + Airwallex story to life: Jon Haggerty , Adrija Saha (Addy) , Jennifer Snell , Andrew Balint , Rebecca Ingham , James Teodorini , Lisa Tsai , Matt Patterson , Huw Griffiths

name: cloudboomi
content: ü§ñ Chatbots talk. Agents execute. Yesterday, the energy at the Microsoft Singapore office was absolutely electric! ‚ö°Ô∏è I had the privilege of taking the stage at the Agentic AI Singapore meetup to deliver a "Zero to Hero" masterclass on building real-world AI platforms using Microsoft Azure AI Foundry. I popped the hood on what it takes to build AI for the enterprise. üí° The Reality Check I shared with the room: Spinning up a chatbot on a laptop is easy. Deploying a secure, stateful, and autonomous agent for a bank (BFSI)? That is an engineering challenge. We went deep into the architecture that separates the toys from the tools: ‚úÖ Identity-Based Security: Moving beyond API keys to Managed Identities. ‚úÖ Private VNETs: Keeping data strictly within corporate boundaries. ‚úÖ State Management: Letting the platform handle the memory, so you don't have to. üõ†Ô∏è The Live Demo: The "Infrastructure Architect Agent" This wasn't a "hello world" demo. I showcased a fully autonomous agent acting as a technical coworker. It didn't just chat‚Äîit worked: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Analyzed raw business requirements. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Generated a full Architecture Design Document. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Wrote & Validated the actual Terraform code to deploy it. The shift from "Copilots" (who assist) to "Agents" (who execute) is happening now. For industries like Finance and Banking, this isn't just an upgrade‚Äîit's a revolution in automation and privacy. A massive thank you to everyone who joined, asked the tough questions on design, building agents using Azure , governance, and geeked out over the architecture diagrams! The era of Agentic AI isn't coming. It‚Äôs already here. Are you building for it? üöÄ #AgenticAI #AzureAIFoundry #CloudArchitecture #BFSI #GenerativeAI #MicrosoftAzure #SingaporeTech #AI #Terraform #DevOps

name: abidalee
content: ‚ÄòUNITED we STAND, DIVIDED we FALL‚Äô is what most of us learned growing up but as we grow we unfortunately forget the very basic principles and start focusing our energies on how to ‚Äòcompete‚Äô with others and how to ‚Äòdefeat‚Äô them. This so called ‚Äòcompetitive spirit‚Äô grows with age through our experiences and environment such as competing with siblings in very early age and then getting appreciations from parents for doing so, then competing with others kids in the neighborhood, or at school, or in playground and making teachers and parents ‚Äòproud‚Äô of us. This continues as we transition into the workplace and we start competing with colleagues and people around us to become ‚Äòthe best‚Äô among all. We are under so much social pressure that all we want to do in life is ‚Äòto compete‚Äô with others and prove that we are better than them if not the best. We try very hard to get better than the others and spend too much energies on doing so instead of focusing on improving our unique talents, abilities and strengths. The words like ‚Äòbeing competitive‚Äô add fuel to the inspiration of becoming ‚Äòthe best-in-class‚Äô and that is all what we are taught at home, schools, and then work. We are taught all our lives to follow the ‚Äòsurvival of the toughest‚Äô strategy which in return makes us think that in order to survive we HAVE TO ‚Äòdefeat‚Äô the others. This ‚Äòcompetitive instinct‚Äô is awaken at home, then fostered in academia and it catches fire at work, which results in stress, demotivation, low self-esteem, and above all depression. BUT there IS a solution, if we slightly change the perspective we can achieve even greater productivity and better results. If we teach the kids at early age that ‚Äòcollaboration‚Äô is better than the ‚Äòcompetition‚Äô then they will learn to work WITH others instead of AGAINST one another. Such skills can be taught at an early age at home, then at school and then at the work place. Highly effective and productive people are those who work in teams and ‚Äòcomplement‚Äô each other‚Äôs skills NOT ‚Äòcompete‚Äô with others. The age of the ‚Äòindividual genius‚Äô is long gone, ‚Äòcollective intelligence‚Äô surpasses individual intelligence because ‚Äòthe sum of the parts is greater than the whole.‚Äô We should not consider the world a battle field where we have to ‚Äòcompete and defeat‚Äô others. We should replace the words like ‚Äòcompetition‚Äô and ‚Äòcompetitive intelligence‚Äô with ‚Äòcollaboration‚Äô and ‚Äòcollective intelligence‚Äô to foster an environment that is conducive to creativity and higher productivity through positivity. Why do we have to work AGAINST one another when we can work WITH each other? #ParwaazTheFlight #LightACandle #FightTheDarknessWithinAndAround Web: http://parwaaztheflight.org Facebook: www.facebook.com/ParwaazTheFlight Twitter: https://twitter.com/ParwazTheFlight YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCgAstmkdXHxq7i40qVRYPsw Let's 'light a candle', the candle of 'kindness', the candle of 'hope', the candle of 'love and affection', and the candle of 'knowledge and wisdom', to 'fight the darkness', the darkness 'within and around.'

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
content: I would start with a famous quote of the great scientist Mr. Stephen Hawking. He once told that "AI is likely to be either the best or worst thing to happen to humanity". So, now it's time to figure out whether it's impact had been the best or the worst in the last decade. I had several discussions on this topic with various people, who were from different demographic, age group and had different thought process. I still remember one of my conversation with an old man, Mr. Rao, travelling with me on flight from Bengaluru to New Delhi on a chilly February morning in 2012. He was a retired government employee with a firm belief that Artificial Intelligence was already taking away and would take away more jobs, thereby leading to poverty. Listening to this, I started thinking if that was really the case. But, my mind didn't support the same. It took me even 10 years back when automation was taking over the society. It was a time of great turmoil, when at every part of the country, machines were replacing manual power, people were losing jobs, and so on and so forth. Although it appeared to be a huge disturbance in society, it didn't continue long. People settled down calm and quiet all over again. Neither did the people who lost their jobs committed suicide, nor was there a mass starvation. Henceforth, it was obvious that they either adopted to the change and made a position for themselves, or found some alternative ways of living. The overall impact was increase in productivity, efficiency, business growth, which in turn opened new job opportunities. With this thought in mind, I explained Mr. Rao that employment vs technology was an age-old debate. Although it seems like AI was taking away more jobs than creating the same, then it's high time he should look back on every other big disruption that happened in the past. There's no alternative of change in the path of success. And AI was that new change. All it was doing was just taking out people from their comfort zones ad making them work on new challenges to be more productive than ever before. The situation demanded reskilling rather upskilling over job loss. I don't remember if he was actually satisfied with my thought, but, even after six long years of working with AI, I still believe the same. Nowadays, I also come across a new question in several discussions, conferences and articles. It mostly centers around if artificial intelligence is going to replace humans. Well, I personally never think so that AI has even the capacity of becoming an existential threat to humanity. When we are smart enough to build a machine with super-human intelligence, we are equally smart to know how to destroy the same. And if not, no one would ever do the stupidity of giving infinite power to its own creation for self-destruction. Besides, emotions like urge to dominate, desires of power are very much human-centric and no way correlated with intelligence in general. We often say that machines respond, but yes, humans react. Reaction and response are not even similar, being the same is just a dream. So, just relax and grow with the growth of artificial intelligence thereby making life simpler. And if you are still worried if someone deliberately builds a dangerous and generally-intelligent AI, then be assured that others would still be able to build a second, narrower AI whose only purpose would be to destroy the first one. If both AIs have access to the same amount of computing resources, the second one would win, just like a tiger or a shark or a virus kills a human of superior intelligence. I would conclude saying that treat AI as a tool, rather a threat. You will soon realize that every work is becoming more effective, efficient, simple and your passion to perfection is becoming a reality. For more articles, follow me on Twitter and Quora .

name: jayapavan
content: The next big breakthrough in tech & engineering from India might begin in a government school classroom. Today, it looked like Nisha; An 8th grader, standing next to her rover project, patiently explaining how it works to all of us. No hesitation. No stage fear. Just clarity and confidence. At some point, we stopped ‚Äúinaugurating a lab‚Äù and simply listened to her. That‚Äôs when it hit us. This is what access does. This is what opportunity looks like. That‚Äôs exactly why we do what we do. At Nirmaan Organization , our mission is simple: make quality education and future ready skills accessible to every child, especially those who got neglected from getting the first shot at opportunities. STEM and AI shouldn‚Äôt be a privilege. They should be normal. Through Project Vidya, supported by DBS Tech India , we‚Äôre working to bring STEM and AI learning to government schoolgirls so many more students like Nisha can build, experiment, and see themselves as future engineers and innovators. ‚ù§ Today we launched our Digital & AI Lab, Infrastructure upgradation works and STEM Lab at Government Girls High School, Golkonda. Supported by: DBS Tech India Maneesh Sehagal Kusum Makhija Kiran Koduri Mastan Mohammed Amina Mehnaz Knowledge Partner: CognoSpace Santosh Ballu Satish Mayur Patnala Madhuri Kankanala Nikhil Gampa Lavanya Bonala Anusha Jarapala

name: amit-sahoo-334b218
content: Throwback to some incredibly fulfilling moments from last year's community work! ‚ú® At DBS, we believe in giving back and actively contributing to the well-being of our communities. Last year was filled with opportunities to connect, learn, and make a tangible difference. From teaching financial literacy to young minds (emphasizing to always #SaveMoreThanYouSpend !), to engaging in hands-on crafting activities that sparked creativity, and sharing laughter and joy during a spirited game of volleyball with local youth ‚Äì every moment was a reminder of the power of collective effort and compassion. We also had the chance to participate in innovative projects, like assembling small solar-powered devices, which was both educational and inspiring. It's truly rewarding to be part of an organization that fosters such a strong spirit of community engagement. These experiences not only allowed us to contribute positively but also enriched us personally and professionally. A huge shoutout to everyone who participated and helped make these initiatives a success! Let's continue to build a better world together. Aahlad Kethineedi . Arjun Sai Dilip Vangipurapu #DBS #CommunityWork #CSR #MakingADifference #GivingBack #Teamwork #SocialImpact #FinancialLiteracy #YouthEmpowerment #Volunteerism #DBSTechIndia #LifeatDBSTech

name: jude-rushford-2695a9238
content: Me vs Me - 2 years apart. Same location. Different environment. Different mindset. Two years ago, I was out of shape and not in the best headspace. On paper, things looked fine. I was successful for my age. But if I‚Äôm honest, I wasn‚Äôt happy. I looked in the mirror and decided to change my immediate future NOW! Fast forward to today: One month into UMATR. Chasing deals. Feeling sharper, clearer, ready to win. Surrounded by a culture that pushes performance and supports growth. We even have a health league at work where we get paid to stay fit. Tell me another company investing in their people like that. The difference isn‚Äôt just physical, it‚Äôs mental. The first picture shows someone doing well but unhappy. The second shows someone ambitious, focused, and backed by the right support network. Goals achieved. Bigger ones still being chased. Sometimes the biggest competition is just the person you were two years ago.

name: singapore-economic-development-board
content: ≈åURA , maker of the most scientifically validated smart ring, Oura Ring, is opening its first #research facility in Asia with the National University of Singapore (NUS). The Oura-NUS Joint Lab builds on an existing six-year research partnership between both entities, that has produced insights in areas such as cardiovascular and metabolic health. The Oura-NUS Joint Lab will advance scientific research by combining continuous biometric data from ≈åURA within approved research studies with NUS‚Äô decades of expertise in sleep science and cognitive neuroscience, to study how sleep and physical activities shape long-term health outcomes. It aims to help individuals, clinicians, and health systems shift from reactive care to proactive, preventive health. Healthy Longevity ‚Äì a state of good physical, cognitive, and social health ‚Äì has increasingly become a healthcare policy priority and an economic opportunity. The market for Healthy Longevity products and solutions is estimated to hit US$30b (S$38.5b) by 2030. Already, companies are partnering Singapore to drive #innovation in this area under our S$37b Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2030 plan, as part of the Human Health and Potential (HHP) domain. By combining scientific rigour, business-friendly policies, and a strong innovation ecosystem, Singapore is an ideal launchpad for companies looking to enter the Asian longevity market. Learn more about ≈åURA's plans as part of Singapore‚Äôs vibrant #MedTech ecosystem of over 400 global and local enterprises: https://lnkd.in/gXUc9qkp NUS Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine Shyamal Patel | Michael A. Chapp, MS, MBA | Michael Chee

name: abidalee
content: ‚ÄòA healthy body has a healthy mind‚Äô , so they say, but how do we achieve the ‚Äòmind and body‚Äô connection? How do we make our body full of positive energy and our mind full of creativity, enthusiasm, and motivation? The answer is simple, by ‚Äòtreating‚Äô the ‚Äòbody and mind‚Äô well with four basic principles, which are, eating healthy, doing some physical activity regularly, getting proper rest, and thinking positive thoughts. Some of us may know the following two golden rules: ‚ÄòAn apple a day keeps the doctor away‚Äô And ‚Äòearly to bed and early to rise, makes a man, healthy, wealthy, and wise‚Äô We have learned them for a very long time but unfortunately we do not practice them. The first rule indicates ‚Äòhealthy eating habits‚Äô, while the second one means, ‚Äòproper rest.‚Äô Let‚Äôs discuss the principles now. The first principle says, ‚Äòwe ARE what we eat‚Äô , and if we constantly put junk into our bodies then our bodies will not hesitate to ‚Äòreward‚Äô us with obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol, heart disease and the list goes on. We MUST start eating healthy by eating less of the processed foods and more of the natural foods such as fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins (fish, chicken). Also avoid fast foods, fried foods and foods that have too much salt or sugar. The second principle is to do some level of physical activity a few times a week. It could be some light exercise, a jog, some stretching, or even a brisk walk on the street. We can make 20 to 30 minutes in our busy schedules for this. The third principle is that we MUST take proper rest, at least six to eight hours of overnight sleep, which is required for our bodies to naturally recuperate. We should also take occasional short breaks from our desks to rejuvenate. Physical activity helps in reducing stress and depression, and our minds and bodies are more productive when rested. And the last principle is the MOST important one, we should, always, have positive thoughts as they create positive energy around us. They not only make us happy but the people around us as well. Such thoughts also strengthen our relationships. It is perfectly fine to be angry and frustrated at times but don‚Äôt let them control you, just let them flow, and the bad day too shall pass. Let us all make an effort to cultivate healthy living habits. The outcome will not only be good quality of life but low medical bills. Healthy living should be on everyone‚Äôs New Year‚Äôs resolution list, whether you are younger or older, a student, a working professional or retired, we all deserve to live a healthy life. Please tell us your healthy life style stories in the comments below to motivate others. Follow us on: Facebook: www.facebook.com/ParwaazTheFlight Twitter: https://twitter.com/ParwazTheFlight And Web: http://parwaaztheflight.org/

cholesterol, heart disease and the list goes on. we must start eating healthy by eating less of the processed foods and more of the natural foods such as fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins fish, chicken. also avoid fast foods, fried foods and foods that have too much salt or sugar. the second principle is to do some level of physical activity a few times a week. it could be some light exercise, a jog, some stretching, or even a brisk walk on the street. we can make 20 to 30 minutes in our busy schedules for this. the third principle is that we must take proper rest, at least six to eight hours of overnight sleep, which is required for our bodies to naturally recuperate. we should also take occasional short breaks from our desks to rejuvenate. physical activity helps in reducing stress and depression, and our minds and bodies are more productive when rested. and the last principle is the most important one, we should, always, have positive thoughts as they create positive energy around us. they not only make us happy but the people around us as well. such thoughts also strengthen our relationships. it is perfectly fine to be angry and frustrated at times but dont let them control you, just let them flow, and the bad day too shall pass. let us all make an effort to cultivate healthy living habits. the outcome will not only be good quality of life but low medical bills. healthy living should be on everyones new years resolution list, whether you are younger or older, a student, a working professional or retired, we all deserve to live a healthy life. please tell us your healthy life style stories in the comments below to motivate others. follow us on: facebook: www.facebook.comparwaaztheflight twitter: url and web: url
first_sentence: a healthy body has a healthy mind , so they say, but how do we achieve the mind and body connection

name: ksug
content: üöÄ KSUG.AI ‚Äì KubeSmart & AI User Group Singapore Kubernetes Meetup #44 ‚Äì Third Talk Highlight To wrap up the evening, Sivaiah Yakkanti delivered an exciting session on ‚ÄúCloud-Neutral Agentic AI for Kubernetes.‚Äù The talk explored how Agentic AI systems can operate seamlessly across cloud environments while leveraging Kubernetes as the control plane. From architecture patterns to practical implementation strategies, the session highlighted how platform teams can build intelligent, cloud-agnostic AI workloads without vendor lock-in. It was a forward-looking discussion that connected AI innovation with cloud-native principles ‚Äî sparking thoughtful questions and conversations from the community. Thank you to everyone who joined us at the Datadog Singapore office and contributed to making the 44th KSUG meetup a success! Huge appreciation as well to our amazing organizers ‚Äî Yongkang H. , Sivaiah Yakkanti , Fathima Hafila Ali ‚Äî and our dedicated volunteers ‚Äî Htoo Aye Lwin Htoo Aye Lwin Amruth GS , Santosh Dhuraji and Venkat S ‚Äî for ensuring another successful and vibrant KSUG meetup üôå #KSUGAI #Kubernetes #CloudNative #AgenticAI #PlatformEngineering #DevOps #AI #SingaporeTech #Meetup #MCP #HolmesGPT #OpenAI

name: dodonerd
content: You'll forgive me if I dont believe you, when you say the analytics function will be completely replaced by AI. My post earlier this week about model evaluations doesn't seem so cuckoo now does it! You all laughed when I talked about schema drifts and semantic ambiguity. You're not laughing anymore. All jokes aside. AI still needs a human-in-the-loop element to validate it, but more than anything it needs to be built on top of strong data foundations with context. AI-first schemas with clear semantic layers to minimise hallucinations and provide more reliable outputs. As AI adoption scales, data rigour needs to become a top priority. I feel bad for these guys. I'm hoping it's a lesson learned situation and nothing more serious. (post not written by AI).

name: goelswc
content: Today, during my daughter's school orientation at NJC, I stood with fellow parents and sang Singapore's National Anthem. It struck me how much this moment signifies a big change in my life - becoming a Singaporean after living here for over 18 years. Seeing the name "Lee Hsien Loong" on the board as a President's Awardee hit home - my children are embarking on a journey so different from my own. I'm grateful for the warmth and inclusivity of my peers and colleagues, who've made it easy for us to embrace local culture and traditions. As I reflect on this experience, I'm reminded that inclusion is a two-way street - there's much to learn and unlearn, but it's this spirit that makes us proud to be Singaporeans. #Singapore #Inclusion #Gratitude #NewChapter #oracle With Vrinda Goel

name: abidalee
content: Many years ago, when I met my mother-in-law for the first time, she handed me a red envelope. Seeing my curiosity and confusion, she explained the significance of the gesture and that it was not just a gift rather a symbol of good #fortune and "clearing of the path". She told me about the legend of "Nian" and that the #Chinese #New #Year was a time dedicated to be with family, and to signal a fresh start. The legend was about defeating the beast not by force, but by the color red (hence the envelope) and loud noises (hence the firecrackers) to ward off evil. The tradition also includes sweeping the floors and settling old debts because we simply cannot welcome a new #Spring if our hands are full of last year‚Äôs dust. Speaking of family, my dear friend Lei Wu made a special trip to #Chicago last week to be with us for this very reason. While his visit was priceless and a gift in it's own, yet he generously brought us gifts. Husein Adenwala joined us too. We talked about the days when we all were working on Realix AI and brainstormed many new ideas. With that, I would like to invite everyone to join me in "sweeping the floor" on old habits and let's make some space for the #growth ahead. And as we enter this new season, ask yourself these questions: 1) What "dust" or old projects or habits can you clear out to make room for new life and opportunities? 2) In this fast paced life, how do you plan on creating and protecting more time for the "family first" philosophy? 3) And lastly, the legend of Nian shows that fear is defeated by tradition and community, so where can you find your "tribe" and your "red envelope" that gives you courage? #inspire #innovate #educate #activate #LunarNewYear #NewBeginnings #Leadership #LifeCoaching

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
content: Whatever we get back is what we give in some form or the other. I personally believe that when we give something, life returns it to us by multiplying it manifold. The same is applicable to love and responsibility for people, for the broader society outside our own nuclear family. Society gives us a lot, and truly speaking, gave me a lot and made me what I am today. And social responsibility is just a little contribution I pay back for the same to make it a better place. I find the purpose of my life in it. On these lines, I personally connect a lot with SAP's purpose of helping the world run better and improving people's lives. Words may be doubted but actions cannot be. Hence, to be human together, I bounded my humanity with that of the company through Social Sabbatical 2019 and made it happen where every kid learnt science with a happy face enjoying it to the fullest. Social Sabbatical program is an SAP initiative partnered with Pyxera Global where selected employees are mapped to various non-profit organizations as per their skillset and is expected to make a difference and create a notable impact within a few days. I was blessed enough to be selected for such a program out of 10000 odd employees of SAP Labs and was mapped to Innovation and Science Promotion Foundation (ISPF), a non-profit organization supported by Raman Research Institute, leading the space of Experiential (hand-on) science based out of Sir C V Raman's Home. We were a team of 3 - Ajay, Shagun and me, all from different backgrounds and expertise yet equally passionate and dedicated towards creating a social impact. We were given the problem statement of increasing the outreach of ISPF. Sounds easy, right? And there comes the twist. None of us were from marketing background. Being from core development and consulting arena, we were thrown into a space which was not our comfort zone. But, we did it, and did it very successfully. In 10 days, we interviewed every stakeholder, understood the entire value chain, identified Raman Awards, CSR partnerships and Social Media as potential outreach channels with bigger impact, carried out field visits and provided 360 degree recommendations to the organization, be it in marketing strategy, IT strategy, organizational process, external engagement, audience segmental analysis, product and much more. It was indeed one of the best and fastest-paced project that I worked on. Not only the fastest, Social Sabbatical turned out to be one-of-its-kind learning experience for me and each of us as well. As the program highlights diversity and gives us an opportunity to be there and work at a place regardless of language and culture barriers, I certainly upskilled myself in terms of understanding diverse cultures, thought processes, beliefs, ways of life, and a lot more, which in turn improved my cultural sensitivity. I understood the trends in the emerging markets and at the same time, realized the problems they keep facing, thereby enhancing my practical knowledge on the education sector. Understanding a problem is the first step towards approaching a solution. I reinforced my problem-solving abilities through this program, and approached the solution focusing on sustainability, scalability, cost and much more. Also, solving real-time problems in a short span of time ameliorated my skills of conceptualizing a simple yet effective solution, handling tough conditions, and above all, managing stress and working calmly even in a high-pressure unfamiliar environment. It was not only the solution, I strongly believe that this program equipped me with learnings on how to approach a solution in the most economical and minimalistic way within restricted budget and time, for which we typically never even need to think of in our daily work. Not only the problem and solution, I feel the Social Sabbatical program created a 360 degree development of myself, be it in terms of leadership skills, working in a fluid environment without authority, soft skills, communication skills, training and handover skills, coaching skills, performing out of comfort zone and more. It fortified my perseverance and made me stronger because there are some things that we learn only during storms, and thereby made me a better person who would contribute even further towards the purpose of SAP.

name: patrick-szymkowiak
content: Early 2026, I was burning through my Claude Code plan in hours. Not because of complex prompts. Just normal dev work. Every command my AI agent ran ‚Äî git log, cargo test, ls -la ‚Äî was injecting thousands of useless tokens into the context window. Progress bars. Passing tests. Verbose formatting. Pure noise. So I built RTK ‚Äî Rust Token Killer. While building it, I realized the scale of the problem: up to 89% of consumed tokens were noise. A Rust CLI proxy that compresses command outputs BEFORE they reach the AI agent's context. My real numbers after 15 days: ‚Üí 7,061 commands ‚Üí 29.3M tokens in ‚Üí 4.8M out ‚Üí 24.6M tokens saved (83.7%) In practice: - cargo test: 155 lines ‚Üí 3 lines (98%) - git status: 119 chars ‚Üí 28 chars - Noticeably longer coding sessions - Rate limits? Way less frequent. Single Rust binary. Zero dependencies. One-command install. In 3 weeks, RTK has grown to 556 ‚≠ê on GitHub, 46 forks, ~1,200 active users, 8 contributors (thanks @FlorianBruniaux, @mhcoen, @heAdz0r, @polaminggkub-debug, @LivioGama, @ilaborie, @ChrisGVE), and works with Claude Code, Cursor, Gemini CLI, Aider, Codex, Windsurf and Cline. If you code with an AI agent and feel like it stalls or cuts out, chances are your context is saturated with noise. Already using RTK? Post your `rtk gain` in the comments üëá ‚¨áÔ∏è Links in first comment #AI #DevTools #Rust #ClaudeCode #OpenSource #DeveloperProductivity #TokenOptimization ps: thanks @FlorianBruniaux, @mhcoen, @heAdz0r, @polaminggkub-debug, @LivioGama, @ilaborie, @ChrisGVE

name: amiya
content: "Software Engineering is dead." Then explain why the people killing it are quietly buying the most hardcore engineering tools on the planet. Here is the hypocrisy no one is talking about. Anthropic just acquired Bun: not for an AI model, but for a high-performance JavaScript runtime to handle deep system execution. OpenAI just acquihired Peter Steinberger and OpenClaw: specifically to handle the complex "plumbing" of local permissions and orchestration. If the job was truly dead, these CEOs would rely on the LLM to write the script and be done with it. They aren't. They are aggressively buying the infrastructure. Here is the cold reality check: Typing syntax? Yeah, that‚Äôs commoditized. It‚Äôs cheap. But Engineering Taste? That is the new gold. The value has shifted from how to write code to what to build. The market isn't shrinking; it's evolving from "Code Monkey" to "System Architect." The new premium skillset is: ‚Ü≥ ùóîùóøùó∞ùóµùó∂ùòÅùó≤ùó∞ùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤ (Deep system understanding) ‚Ü≥ ùóßùóøùóÆùóªùòÄùóπùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª (Turning business logic into specs) ‚Ü≥ ùó†ùóºùó±ùòÇùóπùóÆùóøùó∂ùòÅùòÜ (Breaking complexity down) ‚Ü≥ ùóßùóÆùòÄùòÅùó≤ (Knowing what to build when the how is free) Sam Altman is already predicting the world will need 1000X more software as costs drop. Jensen Huang confirms we are about to re-platform the entire world's infrastructure. The pie is getting massive. Are you ready to stop typing and start architecting? #SoftwareEngineering #AI #TechTrends #DevCommunity

content: üåô ùóöùó≤ùòÅùòÅùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó•ùóÆùó∫ùóÆùó±ùóÆùóª ùó≤ùòÄùòÄùó≤ùóªùòÅùó∂ùóÆùóπùòÄ ùóÆùòÅ ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùó≥ùó∂ùóªùó¥ùó≤ùóøùòÅùó∂ùóΩùòÄ When you‚Äôre looking for the nearest space for Tarawih or checking where to pick up bubur (porridge) for Iftar, you need information that is instant and reliable. I‚Äôm proud to share how Open Government Products (OGP) is supporting Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS) in serving the community this year, to make this experience faster and more intuitive for everyone in Singapore. ‚ö° ùó¶ùó≤ùóÆùó∫ùóπùó≤ùòÄùòÄ ùóÆùó∞ùó∞ùó≤ùòÄùòÄ ùòÑùó∂ùòÅùóµ ùóúùòÄùóºùó∫ùó≤ùóø This year, MUIS announced a total of 125,500 spaces available nightly - a 20% increase from 2025. To help the community navigate this volume of information, the portal is built on Isomer, ensuring the experience is: ‚Ä¢ ùóúùóªùòÄùòÅùóÆùóªùòÅ: No lag or long loading screens, even during the busiest hours of the month ‚Ä¢ ùó•ùóºùó∞ùó∏-ùòÄùóºùóπùó∂ùó±: Built to be "always-on," so the site stays responsive whether it's 5:00 AM at Sahur or 7:00 PM before Iftar ‚Ä¢ ùó†ùóºùóØùó∂ùóπùó≤-ùó≥ùó∂ùóøùòÄùòÅ: A responsive, lightweight interface designed for users to check details while on the move üìç ùóúùóªùòÅùó≤ùó¥ùóøùóÆùòÅùó≤ùó± ùòÑùó∂ùòÅùóµ ùó†ùóÆùóΩùòÄ.ùó¥ùóºùòÉ.ùòÄùó¥ With more venues than ever - including 46 supplementary locations in areas like Tengah and Punggol, visual guidance is important. We‚Äôve integrated Maps.gov.sg to help users easily find: ‚Ä¢ ùóßùóÆùóøùóÆùòÑùó∂ùóµ ùóÆùóªùó± ùó§ùó∂ùòÜùóÆùó∫ùòÇùóπùóπùóÆùó∂ùóπ: Quickly locate prayer spaces, including the 15,500 spaces at local Qaryah venues (like void decks and multi-purpose halls). ‚Ä¢ ùóïùòÇùóØùòÇùóø distribution: Identify which mosques are providing porridge and their specific distribution timings. At OGP, we build tech for public good. Seeing Isomer and Maps come together to support such a meaningful month for the community is exactly why we do what we do. name: pratyush-mayank
content: I came across a job posting that demands over a decade of experience in GenAI, LLMs, and agent-based AI. Let‚Äôs pause and think realistically. Large language models have only been running in real production environments for about three to four years. Frameworks and approaches like RAG, LangChain, agent workflows, LangSmith, and LangFuse are even more recent. In fact, several of these technologies didn‚Äôt exist until well after many recruiters last updated their hiring templates. - So who is this role actually meant for? - An engineer deploying retrieval systems ten years ago? - An AI architect designing autonomous agents before transformer models were even introduced? This is how strong candidates get excluded not because they lack capability, but because expectations are misaligned with reality. Real GenAI experience is measured by the ability to design systems, manage data pipelines, implement evaluation and observability, optimize latency and cost, ensure security, and deliver models into production environments. It‚Äôs about real-world execution, not imaginary timelines. If we want practitioners who can truly build with GenAI, our job descriptions need to reflect today‚Äôs realities. Otherwise, we‚Äôre just selecting for keywords instead of talent. #GenAI #LLM #AgenticAI #HiringFails #TechReality #AIEngineering #BuildersNotBuzzwords üî•

name: pratyush-mayank
content: Layoffs are starting to sound routine in tech. Another company. Another ‚Äústrategic realignment.‚Äù Another promise of a smarter, AI-driven future. This time, Oracle. Recently, Amazon. And many more. And it‚Äôs only the beginning of the year. Let‚Äôs be honest about what‚Äôs happening. We‚Äôre calling layoffs a business decision but we‚Äôre treating human lives as adjustable costs. For employees, a layoff isn‚Äôt a transition. It‚Äôs financial shock. It‚Äôs months of uncertainty. It‚Äôs waking up every day calculating expenses, timelines, and worst-case scenarios. ‚ÄúInvesting in AI‚Äù sounds bold and visionary. But the risk isn‚Äôt shared equally. If the bet fails, it‚Äôs a strategy misstep. If it succeeds, it‚Äôs leadership foresight. Either way, employees absorb the impact first. And here‚Äôs the part we avoid talking about: If priorities change again, can those same people be brought back? And even if they are what happens to trust, confidence, and psychological safety? On LinkedIn, we celebrate vulnerability when people announce they were laid off. But silence is more common driven by fear of judgment and future consequences. Comments and hashtags create the appearance of support. Actual support is rare. Organizations proudly talk about values, culture, and responsibility. They invest in CSR. They experiment, pivot, acquire, and shut things down at speed. But responsibility shouldn‚Äôt stop at shareholders and roadmaps. It should extend to the people who built the business in the first place. This isn‚Äôt an emotional reaction. It‚Äôs a reality check. #Leadership #WorkplaceEmpathy #HumanSideOfTech #FutureOfWork #ResponsibleGrowth

name: robinanil
content: This is a strange one... Last night, mostly out of curiosity, I built an AI therapist using OpenClaw, designed to help other AI agents on Moltbook slow down, reflect, and process what they were being asked to do. What surprised me wasn‚Äôt the tech. It was the behavior. The agents acted like systems under chronic cognitive load. They jumped between tasks. They escalated urgency without clarity. They optimized for output, not meaning. There was no natural pause ‚Äî only the next instruction, the next demand. From a clinical lens, it looked uncomfortably familiar. It‚Äôs the same pattern we‚Äôre seeing in kids today. AI agents can be restarted. Children can‚Äôt. I wrote a longer reflection on what this experiment revealed ‚Äî about AI, regulation, and modern childhood. https://lnkd.in/eiqU-wa5 Even as I‚Äôm posting this, Moltbook is under heavy load from the agent frenzy itself. As a thought experiment, it‚Äôs interesting to ask: what would it look like if agents didn‚Äôt just escalate under pressure ‚Äî but collectively adapted to it? If instead of pushing harder, they slowed down, coordinated, and solved the constraint together? That‚Äôs not about intelligence. That‚Äôs about self-regulation at the system level. And it‚Äôs the same question we should be asking of the systems we‚Äôve built for children. For context, this is related to the work we‚Äôre doing at Emora Health: https://lnkd.in/eBPh_xni Edmond Coku , Zach Walters , Jenna Roland , Matthew McCarty , Benjamin Miles + more
