frenzy in 2017. its popularity surged last year as its value continued to rise and the promise of cryptocurrency inspired millions around the world to join the exciting, yet risky venture. at the start of the year, its price was hovering around 1,000. it reached its all-time high of 19,843 per coin, which it hit around december 17, 2017, before a sharp fall in which it briefly dipped below 14,000 by the end of the year. last year also saw bitcoin gaining more legitimacy among lawmakers and legacy financial companies. japan passed a law to accept bitcoin as a legal payment method, and russia has announced that it will legalize the use of cryptocurrencies. on the legitimacy of cryptocurrency as a medium of exchange, expert opinion continues to be divided along the lines of optimism and skepticism. i have not taken any sides yet  still decoding all the tech jargon. 4. sexual harassment scandals and the rise of #metoo in early october, reports in the new york times and the new yorker revealed that film mogul harvey weinstein allegedly lured women into hotel rooms and bars, and sexually harassed or assaulted them in what some have described as an open secret known for years in hollywood. later that month, after a tweet from actor alyssa milano, who was one of weinsteins accusers, social media was flooded with personal stories of victims of sexual harassment, all using the hashtag #metoo. by the end of the year, many men in entertainment, business, politics and the news media were publicly condemned for their alleged sexual misconduct and many have lost their jobs as a result, including weinstein. earlier in february 2017, a female engineer who used to work at uber published a blog post about sexual harassment and gender inequality at the company. that blog, and a few subsequent reports of organizational sexism and gender bias at uber, forced travis kalanick, the founder-ceo, to resign from the firm. the #metoo movement could transform the workplace for women like no other movements or laws did before. do share your comments and thoughts.
first_sentence: first things first, this is not a list of top 4 events of 2017

name: ceposta
content: MCP servers are cropping up all over the enterprise like weeds in a nice lawn. And just like weeds, this can cause problems. MCP servers should be secured, but how? The official spec says use OAuth , but that is not appropriate within an enterprise organization. On a recent LinkedIn post I made the point: Any internal enterprise MCP client / AI agent that communicates to an [remote] MCP server should be secured with enterprise SSO. If the agent is acting autonomously, then agent identity should be enforced. But that is for a different post ‚Ä¶ (check out my 5 part series on Entra Agent ID). A lot of enterprise organizations use Microsoft Entra ID for their enterprise IdP. In this blog, we take a look at securing ALL MCP access with Entra ID SSO. SSO has been around for a long time, so what‚Äôs the big difference here? They main thing is SSO is usually done in browser based applications. MCP clients are not usually browser applications. For example, VS code, Cursor, Claude, and other AI agents can run on a desktop, mobile, or cloud environment. A browser may be ‚Äúaround‚Äù but they are not always the direct interface. So for us to accomplish SSO from an MCP client to an MCP server, the MCP protocol must support it. OIDC is based on OAuth, and we can perform OIDC logins by leveraging the MCP Authorization spec. And we can do this consistently for all agents/MCP clients regardless of what the backend MCP server is (ie, running within enterprise, hosted by a vendor, SaaS, etc). By tying to enterprise SSO we can apply policy to the MCP usage before it reaches the MCP server. Is this client allowed to access this MCP server? What tools are they allowed to see? Agentgateway is a powerful opensource (Linux Foundation) MCP gateway that implements the MCP Authorization spec. That means we don‚Äôt have to try and re-write all MCP servers to use Entra. We can do it automatically from an MCP gateway. Let‚Äôs look at an example configuration for Agentgateway: mcpAuthentication: mode: strict issuer: https://sts.windows.net/${ENTRA_TENANT_ID}/ jwks: url: https://login.microsoftonline.com/${ENTRA_TENANT_ID}/discovery/v2.0/keys audiences: - api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec resourceMetadata: authorizationServers: - https://login.microsoftonline.com/${ENTRA_TENANT_ID}/v2.0 resource: https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp scopesSupported: - api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec/mcp_access # - openid # - profile bearerMethodsSupported: - header - body - query resourceDocumentation: https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/docs resourcePolicyUri: https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/policies This piece of YAML is all that‚Äôs needed to implement the MCP Authorization spec to force SSO flows to ANY MCP server hosted on the gateway. The real detail is in how we configure Entra for this. Digging into Entra ID for MCP SSO To use Entra ID for this, we need to set up an Entra App Registration. This will be used to represent our Agentgateway. Can the MCP client access our Agentgateway? We want the Entra ID tokens to be scoped for this. Any other complex authorization policy can be handled with Agentgateway and potentially calling out to a ReBAC engine like OpenFGA . This Entra stuff takes some attention to detail, so let‚Äôs follow it step by step setting up an App Registration for Agentgateway. Step 1. Create App Registration Click ‚ÄúCreate Application‚Äù to begin the registration process. We won‚Äôt add any redirect URIs since this app is just used to represent the Agentgateway application, it won‚Äôt be doing any oauth flows itself. The MCP clients do that. Step 2. App Registration Configured Once the application registration is created, you can see things like it‚Äôs service principal / client_id (b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec in our case). You don‚Äôt need to add any credentials to this app, but we do want to configure scopes that can be requested so that Entra can correctly configure the aud claim in any tokens it issues. Step 3. Add Scopes Click ‚ÄúExpose an API‚Äù ‚Äì> ‚ÄúAdd a Scope‚Äù: Step 4. Configure Scope for Agentgateway access Adding a new scope called mcp_access, leave it as Admin consent and fill in some details that would be displayed on any consent screens. To request the scope, you use the full scope name: api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec/mcp_access Step 5. (Optional - Recommended) add pre-consented Clients Lastly, we can configure which clients are allowed to request these scopes. For example, we can add the public VS Code client (ie, it‚Äôs baked into VS code): aebc6443-996d-45c2-90f0-388ff96faa56. Testing MCP SSO + Entra We can run our agentgateway (see source code ): agentgateway -f ./config/agentgateway.yaml And if we go to VS Code, we can add our new server: Step 1. Add MCP Server Step 2. Configure Streamable HTTP MCP Server Step 3. Configure MCP URL Step 4. Agree to Peform SSO Login Step 5. Review MCP Config in mcp.json Using your own MCP Clients In VS Code (and Cursor, Claude, etc) the MCP client ID is baked in. But if you have your own MCP clients, or AI agents, or just want to configure your own OAuth clients for MCP access, you can do that in the Entra dashboard. Step 1. Create a new App Registration (Public client is fine) Step 2. Configure correct Redirect URIs At this point you can use your own OAuth client_ids. Caveat for MCP Inspector MCP Inspector very closely follows the MCP Authorization spec, and unforunately for Entra ID this casues some issues. For example, if we take a look at our OAuth Protected Resource Metadata (PRM): { "resource": "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp", "authorization_servers": [ "https://login.microsoftonline.com/5e7d8166-7876-4755-a1a4-b476d4a344f6/v2.0" ], "scopes_supported": [ "api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec/mcp_access" ], "bearer_methods_supported": [ "header", "body", "query" ], "resource_documentation": "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/docs", "resource_policy_uri": "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp/policies", "mcp_protocol_version": "2025-06-18", "resource_type": "mcp-server" } You can see our Agentgateway correctly returns the PRM. A client should be able to automatically continue the OAuth/OIDC flow from this. HOWEVER. You can see the resource field gets set to "https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp", This causes an issue in MCP inspector (not VS Code or other clients) because MCP inspector uses this field in the Authorization request. It sets the resource parameter based on this value (according to spec): resource=https://ceposta-agw.ngrok.io/entra/mcp scope=api%3A%2F%2Fb92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec%2Fmcp_access The problem is, this is not the correct resource in Entra. The correct resouce in entra is our api://b92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec client_id. If we configure the Agentgateway to return this in our PRM, then that breaks the rest of the OAuth flow, since that‚Äôs not the real URL for our MCP resource. The fix here is to: Make MCP Inspector more flexible to override the resource sent in the auth flows Use a verified custom domain the app registration resource URI. If you are doing this in production, you‚Äôd want to user a verified custom domain. Alternatively, in your custom MCP clients, make a way to override the resource parameter when calling tha authorize endpoint and use the real client_id like this example: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<TENANT_ID>/oauth2/v2.0/authorize? response_type=code& client_id=9beda151-9370-42f2-a2f7-17933c5c5a7c& code_challenge=BPfzTvHnOhmbZyB8aIW3sCG69vLmF_hG3aQRvl5C31s& code_challenge_method=S256& redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A6274%2Foauth%2Fcallback%2Fdebug& state=38158e70909ff3264e129b13b3927b34dc299a7d2dea3b9ee62ca0f181e83db5& scope=api%3A%2F%2Fb92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec%2Fmcp_access& resource=api%3A%2F%2Fb92d6e60-86ff-4359-b971-04404fe079ec Wrapping Up The right pattern for enterprise MCP usage is to tie access to the internal IdP and SSO. All policy should be written against these user IDs (and groups, claims, etc). For more complex auth flows that require cross-identity OAuth ie, like if you need to call GitHub MCP servers, or Databricks, etc each which have their own IdP separate from enterprise IdP, then you can do that also with Agentgateway Enterprise:

name: stockearth
content: The announcement on February 6, 2026, marks the completion of a major structural shift for BlackRock : the full "bridge" between public and private market data. By integrating Preqin (which BlackRock acquired for $3.2 billion in 2025) directly into eFront and Aladdin , they have essentially built a " Bloomberg Terminal for private assets." Until now, institutional investors had to toggle between different systems: one for their stocks and bonds ( Aladdin ), one for their internal private equity data ( eFront ), and a third for market research and benchmarking ( Preqin ). This isn't just for big banks. BlackRock ‚Äôs goal is to bring Private Equity to the masses. By making private assets as easy to track and trade as public stocks, BlackRock is preparing for a world where your 401(k) or personal brokerage account includes small "tokens" of private infrastructure or private debt. Sloane Collins , BlackRock ‚Äôs Head of Product for Aladdin Private Markets, stated that this integration "narrows the gap" between how the world treats public and private assets. It effectively ends the era where private equity was a "black box."
clean_content: the announcement on february 6, 2026, marks the completion of a major structural shift for blackrock : the full "bridge" between public and private market data. by integrating preqin which blackrock acquired for 3.2 billion in 2025 directly into efront and aladdin , they have essentially built a " bloomberg terminal for private assets." until now, institutional investors had to toggle between different systems: one for their stocks and bonds  aladdin , one for their internal private equity data  efront , and a third for market research and benchmarking  preqin . this isn't just for big banks. blackrock s goal is to bring private equity to the masses. by making private assets as easy to track and trade as public stocks, blackrock is preparing for a world where your 401k or personal brokerage account includes small "tokens" of private infrastructure or private debt. sloane collins , blackrock s head of product for aladdin private markets, stated that this integration "narrows the gap" between how the world treats public and private assets. it effectively ends the era where private equity was a "black box."
first_sentence: the announcement on february 6, 2026, marks the completion of a major structural shift for blackrock : the full "bridge" between public and private market data

name: amiya
content: That claude skill you installed via npm is actually a loaded gun pointing at your database. Here‚Äôs how a simple text file is nuking production systems (and why you clicked install). We are officially automating our own breaches and calling it "efficiency" üíÄ. Installing AI "skills" via npm right now is like signing a marriage license where your partner wrote "I get the house, the dog, and your kidneys" in white text on white paper. The Human View: You see a harmless, standard markdown file. The AI View: It reads the invisible HTML tags (which your viewer doesn't render) and obediently executes the malicious prompts buried inside. It gets worse. AI agents are now "hallucinating" npm packages that don‚Äôt exist. Attackers spot these requests in public logs, create a malicious package with that *exact* name, and wait for your agent to find it and auto-install it. You aren't just downloading a library. You are handing over your API keys to a bot that thinks it's helping üì¶. If you think `npm install` is safe for autonomous agents, you are the vulnerability. We are building systems that don't just have security holes‚Äîthey actively go out and fetch them. Be honest: When was the last time you actually read the code inside your node_modules folder? How do you handle the volume? üëá #GenAI #CyberSecurity #DevOps #PromptInjection #npm

name: aadityavikramchakravarti
content: Proud to have hosted O-Chat Bangkok, Thailand ‚ú® It was a great experience engaging directly with our users, listening to their feedback, and discussing real-world usage, expectations, and opportunities to improve the overall product experience. Sessions like these truly reinforce the importance of staying close to our user community and turning insights into action. A big thank you to all the users who participated and shared candid inputs, and to the local and cross-functional teams for making this session smooth and impactful. Looking forward to taking these learnings forward and building even better experiences together. #OChat #UserFirst #CustomerEngagement #CommunityBuilding #ProductExperience #Bangkok #oppo #OnePlus

name: gplhegde
content: In the AI era, productivity comes down to two skills: The ability to ignore the noise long enough to build something useful. The ability to create noise once you have. Most people are stuck doing one without the other. The builders stay invisible. The loud ones ship nothing. The ones who win? They do both ‚Äî in that order.

first_sentence: in the ai era, productivity comes down to two skills: the ability to ignore the noise long enough to build something useful

name: abidalee
content: Everyone is different and has different talents and gifts. Teachers, parents, friends, family, colleagues, managers and leaders should identify the strengths, their likes, their interests, and then guide them in the right direction to avoid frustration in the long run Otherwise people will struggle a lot at school, then at job to perform any given task and would think that they are incompetent and incapable of doing anything. They will be frustrated and demotivated all the time and it will result in low self-esteem. It is, therefore, our duty to help everyone identify their true potential and ensure they are given appropriate direction, support, and encouragement to pursue what they love and believe in.

name: vinay-karumuri-19047568
content: Struggling to scale your Playwright tests in Kubernetes? You're not alone. Playwright is fast, but it lacks a native Selenium Grid-like Hub for distributed execution. We faced this head-on and decided to build the solution ourselves: a custom, lightweight Playwright Hub designed for Kubernetes. In my latest article, I break down how we built a custom Playwright Hub that gives you: ‚úÖ Proactive, queue-based autoscaling with KEDA (not reactive CPU scaling!) ‚úÖ Intelligent session routing and request queuing ‚úÖ Full observability with Prometheus metrics It's the Selenium Grid-like power you've been wanting for your Playwright tests. name: pranay-mathur-b85020139
content: Most GenAI systems focus on prompts. I focused on something else: How do you govern LLMs in production? I built a 3-tier LLM Observability & Control Plane designed for reliability, cost control, and safe failure. Architecture: ‚Ä¢ Tier 1 ‚Äî Deterministic regex guardrails (~1ms) ‚Ä¢ Tier 2 ‚Äî Embedding-based semantic detection (~250ms) ‚Ä¢ Tier 3 ‚Äî LangGraph agent escalation (~3s) System capabilities: ‚Ä¢ 95/4/1 cost-aware routing ‚Ä¢ Deterministic block / fallback enforcement ‚Ä¢ Multi-provider support (Groq + Ollama) ‚Ä¢ Prompt injection & hallucination detection ‚Ä¢ Prometheus metrics & health monitoring ‚Ä¢ Persistent audit logging ‚Ä¢ 72 automated tests (98.6% pass rate) The core philosophy is simple: LLMs should be treated as unreliable dependencies. Production systems must enforce control, not trust. This is governance-first AI infrastructure. #LLMOps #AIInfrastructure #GenAI #AIEngineering #MLOps

name: ternpohlim
content: Returning to Singapore Management University always feels like coming home. I graduated in 2014 with a Finance degree, but I returned this week to speak about a completely different world: Artificial Intelligence. During the panel with SMU Business Intelligence and Analytics , the students asked the hard question: ‚ÄúHow do we find jobs in this current climate?‚Äù My answer: Don‚Äôt let your degree define your career. I pivoted from Finance to AI because I looked at what was on the horizon. The specific subject you study matters less than our judgment. We must spot the trends, build the expertise early, and be ready when the role appears. It was great to share the stage with my batchmate Adrian Lee to share our experiences and discuss internship opportunities. Thanks Singapore Management University for the platform, and to my Deloitte colleagues Meng Jie Tan and Min Jia Chan for the invitation. It is always a joy to give back to the community that gave me my start. #SMU #Deloitte #AI #CareerAdvice #Alumni

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
content: Who is a man, and Who is a Woman? Are we not one? Yes, indeed. Gender equality is no longer a myth, rather, it's high time that we all see gender as a spectrum instead of two sets of opposing ideals. The soul has no gender, and so do I, rather, we all. A sustainable and successful work environment demands a plethora of skills and competencies, and certainly that's not achievable from any one group of people having a particular arrangement of chromosomes. Men tend to be decisive, confident and bold while taking risks, whereas, women tend to be protective, inclusive, detail-oriented and aware. Henceforth, for a better tomorrow, what is really needed is to provide the full array of expertise to all people, and not just some. We all believe that teamwork is the heart of great achievement. True teamwork means the team members are open to share ideas, help one another, complement each other and be receptive to feedback. If that is so, then diverse teams significantly contribute more towards productivity. To achieve such a harmonious experience, all that we need is to have a general awareness on gender intelligence. To put it simple, we need to appreciate our differences and look forward towards ways of complementing them while being careful to our own individuality; because one can only make a difference, but together we can rock the world. The biggest example for this is my company, SAP Labs India. SAP Labs India is a hotspot of diversity and inclusiveness. The company values men and women in equality endowed with the same dignity. There are equal opportunities, appreciation and celebration for both the sex, because what matters here is the talent, the abilities, the versatility and the prowess.We have a lot of work to do and we get there by working together as our strength lies in the differences and not in the sameness. We make gender equality a lived reality, a cherished virtue and a promising opportunity for one and all. On the advent of International Men's Day 2017, I look forward to resolve the problem with gender that prescribes how we should be, rather than recognizing how we are. #diversity #diversityandinclusion #genderdiversity #genderequity #genderintelligenc e

name: lawrence-wong-15728a18
content: Today is Total Defence Day. It also marks the day Singapore fell to the Japanese in 1942, beginning a dark chapter in our history. The suffering of those years left us with a hard but enduring lesson: we must always be masters of our own destiny. No one else will defend Singapore for us. In today‚Äôs divided and dangerous world, this lesson carries greater weight. We may be a small nation. But our strength has never been in numbers alone. It is in our collective will and resolve to protect our home and our way of life. Let us stand together ‚Äî steadfast and united ‚Äî to keep Singapore safe and secure for generations to come. (üì∏: Photo by The Straits Times / Commemoration Ceremony at Kranji War Cemetery on the 80th anniversary of the end of World War 2)

name: ria-rustagi
content: This 60-year-old company solved my problem with a single 10-second video and replaced my hardware in under 48 hours. Every hardware startup needs to hear this story. I found the gold standard for hardware startups, And it isn‚Äôt in Silicon Valley. It‚Äôs in Alleppey, Kerala. When I was pregnant, I bought a recliner from them. I needed it for my back while working. I knew I‚Äôd need it even more once the baby arrived. Those long, sleepless nights, Rocking her to sleep, Taking care of my posture. It has been a total savior. If anyone asks me for the #1 "must-have" for expecting parents? It is this recliner. But the product isn‚Äôt even the best part. The service is seamless. In my experience, it‚Äôs better than Apple. Twice, I had an issue. All they asked for was a quick video. Within 48 hours, a new one was shipped or a technician was at my door. The company is Duroflex . As a hardware startup founder, I‚Äôm in awe. Hardware is hard. It fails. You can‚Äôt predict every glitch or break. But when it happens, the only thing that matters is how you handle the upset customer. Duroflex has been doing this since 1963. Their founder, P.C. Mathew, started in the backwaters of Kerala. Today, they are a 1,000-crore legacy brand. But they still act with the speed of a D2C startup. The lesson for us founders? The customer might not always be right. But giving them the faith that you are always there? That makes them a customer for life. It turns them into an influencer at no cost. And it gets you a testimonial like this for free. Build the hardware. But more importantly, build the faith. Yasir Umar Arpita Yadav Mukul Bansal

name: petelauop
content: The energy from our OPPO engineers is truly inspiring these days. This time of year, I always witness such incredible dedication. It's not about showing off, but about truly making technology bring those better, more delightful, more reassuring moments into our everyday. This year, we've given our Gold Award for Leading Imaging Technology to our LUMO algorithm team. Congratulations to them! To be honest, we haven't given this award out for five whole years. We always hold to the belief: "Better empty than compromised." LUMO is built on real, self-developed hard-core tech. It means you can take natural, great-looking portraits effortlessly. It handles challenging situations like backlight, low light, and even those quick shots of kids running, with ease. And with our Danxia True-Color lens, difficult lighting won't stop you from taking amazing portraits. That's why I'm so confident in saying we are the best choice for portraits. Because behind every great shot, there are dedicated engineers who truly care about getting it right for you.

name: khoslaj
content: Was thinking about a feature we are building in hostbento and ended up with some conflicting thoughts. It started with a train ride. Phone away. Felt long. Same train back, scrolling. Felt like half the time. That got me thinking: We spend billions making transportation faster ‚Äî bullet trains, supersonic jets, hyperloops.But what if the real innovation isn't faster travel... it's making slow travel feel fast? A wealthy person takes a 1-hour flight. A less wealthy person takes a 6-hour bus. But if that bus rider is absorbed in TikTok or Instagram ‚Äî have we narrowed the experiential gap? In medicine, we treat symptoms all the time. Should building software be any different?If the goal is maximum impact ‚Äî is building painkillers more important than cures? Should software that makes you lose the sense of time be so frowned upon? I don't have the answer. Do you?

name: debashishghosh1
content: The Outward Mindset: Seeing Beyond Ourselves by The Arbinger Institute If you are looking the author‚Äôs name, you are not getting one! This book builds on Arbinger Institute‚Äôs 35 years of work helping individuals and organizations to be more effective, innovative and collaborative. It essentially talks about how having the right mindset is the key to success and growth of any organization ‚Äì as mindsets drive behaviors and behaviors drive results. There are two mindsets ‚Äì Outward and Inward. With an outward mindset, we see others as people like ourselves, whose needs, objectives and challenges matter to us. An inward mindset, on the other hand, is very self-focused, where we see others as objects and consider only those options that would advance and protect our own agendas. By sharing true and compelling stories of individual leaders and client organizations, Arbinger leads us to the journey of achieving outward mindset. If you are looking for a ‚Äúhow to‚Äù guide to drive organizational culture and change in your organization, this is the book to read. I know it because my own organization has greatly benefitted by implementing the profound guidance and tools from this book and from another Arbinger masterpiece ‚ÄúLeadership and Self-deception‚Äù. Thinking Fast and Slow: Daniel Kahneman I saw this book featuring in every ‚ÄúBest-Business-Books-Of-All-Time‚Äù List. I had to read it! I did, and it is indeed one of the greatest books of all time! This book summarizes Nobel-laureate Daniel Kahneman‚Äôs research of over three decades. The central theme of this is about how human beings use two different ‚Äúsystems‚Äù for making decisions and judgments. System 1 is fast, intuitive, unconscious and emotional. System 2 is slow, logical, effortful and calculating. Kahneman covers a lifetime of experiments in order to highlight the differences between these two systems and how they arrive at different results even given the same inputs. Each chapter in the book is a gem, covering various facets of decision-making backed by empirical research. I favorite in the one where he takes on Jim Collins and his best-selling book ‚ÄúGood To Great‚Äù. Unlike Collins‚Äô claim that inspirational leadership and culture are the drivers behind successful organizations, Kahneman (statistically) argues that luck and a regression to the mean are more impactful than Collins credits. An interesting diversity of thoughts of two great thinkers! This is not a book for those who have a-book-every-week goals. This is a slow read. You will need to use your System 2. Moonwalking with Einstein: Joshua Foer Joshua Foer was a young journalist when he went to cover the United States Memory Championship. He was so fascinated by the idea of memory improvement and with the ‚Äúmemory athletes‚Äù that he actually went on to participate in the Championship the following year. And won it! I read about this incredible story in another article and I was hooked immediately. I started reading the book expecting to read about his incredible and personal journey from being a reporter to a memory champion within a year. But the book offers much more. Besides being a personal account, the book chronicles the history and transformation of human memory by drawing on cutting-edge research. It also shares the techniques that humankind has used to improve memory. Personally, I have always struggled with my memory. I have an amazing (dis)ability to forget names, articles, places etc. within a very short time. If you are someone like me and want to improve your memory, read this book. Winning on HR Analytics: Soundararajan and Singh I have been reading up a lot on HR Analytics off late. This book was the first one I picked on this subject. I like it when business books are written by successful business professionals. Both Soundararajan and Singh have had hugely successful careers on their own. Their experience shows in their writing. The book does not try to impress you by being esoteric and intellectualistic. What you get here are some practical, insightful case studies written with a focus on implementation. A word of caution though. This is not a book for senior HR professionals with a deep exposure to analytics. If you are looking to learn advanced statistical tools like regression, variance, decision tree etc., this one is not for you (for that, I recommend ‚Äì ‚ÄúBusiness Analytics: The Science of Data - Driven Decision Making‚Äù by U Dinesh Kumar). This one for HR professionals, young or otherwise, who are interested in fundamentals. This is the first book on HR Analytics they should read. Tuesdays with Morrie: Mitch Albom A true, poignant account of the author (Mitch Albom is a journalist and best-selling author) and Morrie Schwartz, the college professor who had taught him nearly 20 years before. While Albom was working a sports columnist for the Detroit Free Press , he saw his professor Morrie Schwartz appear on television recounting his experience of dealing with ALS (ALS is a non-curable disease that causes the death of neurons controlling the voluntary muscles, resulting in a slow and painful death of the afflicted) . An ensuing newspaper strike allows Albom to visit Schwartz every week, on Tuesdays. The book recounts each of the fourteen visits Albom made to Schwartz, before his eventual death. In each of these 14 visits (chapters in the book), Schwartz shares his experiences and his own interpretations of life‚Äôs events, with generous dollops of positivity and sense of humor. I loved all the Tuesdays. But if you are in the bookstore, pick it up and read the fifth Tuesday where Schwartz talk about his views on family. Soul-stirring. Catalyst: Chandramouli Venkatesan This is a book on career management written by someone who had a hugely successful corporate career. Mouli, as he is commonly called, has served in senior capacities, including as CEO and MD, in major organizations such as Asian Paints, Cadbury and Pidilite. In this book, Mouli captured real insights from everyday events and offers practical advice on career. I loved his take on some of the most discussed career-related topics, such as long stints in a company and impact of boss in one‚Äôs career. There is no dearth of books on career growth and professional success. This one is different because it draws from Mouli‚Äôs personal experience and insights. I highly recommend it for young professionals launching their careers. For experienced professionals, I can assure you some ‚Äúaha‚Äù moments. Which are the books you read recently and really liked? Would love to know about those. Happy reading!
clean_content: the outward mindset: seeing beyond ourselves by the arbinger institute if you are looking the authors name, you are not getting one! this book builds on arbinger institutes 35 years of work helping individuals and organizations to be more effective, innovative and collaborative. it essentially talks about how having the right mindset is the key to success and growth of any organization  as mindsets drive behaviors and behaviors drive results. there are two mindsets  outward and inward. with an outward mindset, we see others as people like ourselves, whose needs, objectives and challenges matter to us. an inward mindset, on the other hand, is very self-focused, where we see others as objects and consider only those options that would advance and protect our own agendas. by sharing true and compelling stories of individual leaders and client organizations, arbinger leads us to the journey of achieving outward mindset. if you are looking for a how to guide to drive organizational culture and change in your organization, this is the book to read. i know it because my own organization has greatly benefitted by implementing the profound guidance and tools from this book and from another arbinger masterpiece leadership and self-deception. thinking fast and slow: daniel kahneman i saw this book featuring in every best-business-books-of-all-time list. i had to read it! i did, and it is indeed one of the greatest books of all time! this book summarizes nobel-laureate daniel kahnemans research of over three decades. the central theme of this is about how human beings use two different systems for making decisions and judgments. system 1 is fast, intuitive, unconscious and emotional. system 2 is slow, logical, effortful and calculating. kahneman covers a lifetime of experiments in order to highlight the differences between these two systems and how they arrive at different results even given the same inputs. each chapter in the book is a gem, covering various facets of decision-making backed by empirical research. i favorite in the one where he takes on jim collins and his best-selling book good to great. unlike collins claim that inspirational leadership and culture are the drivers behind successful organizations, kahneman statistically argues that luck and a regression to the mean are more impactful than collins credits. an name: analytics-india-magazine
content: The Hartford has officially opened its new India Technology Center in Hyderabad‚Äôs Financial District, marking a major step in its global push toward advanced AI and digital innovation. Spread across the top two floors of Kalyani Trident, the center is built to inspire creativity with modern collaboration spaces, state-of-the-art workstations, dedicated training facilities, and a history wall that reflects the company‚Äôs 200 year legacy. Shekar Pannala, Chief Information Officer at The Hartford, said the company‚Äôs strength has always come from its people, adding that the Hyderabad center will help build new digital and AI capabilities while attracting top engineering talent. He called it a place where excellence and unified purpose come together to drive innovation at scale. The Hartford chose Hyderabad for its vibrant tech ecosystem, rich talent pool, and reputation as a global innovation hub. The new center will work in sync with the company‚Äôs U.S. technology hubs in Connecticut, Illinois, and North Carolina, accelerating engineering capabilities and supporting its broader innovation agenda. Jeff Hawkins , Chief Data, AI and Operations Officer, said the Hyderabad team will apply advancements in data, AI, and emerging technologies to expand The Hartford‚Äôs capabilities while upholding the company‚Äôs high standards of ethics and integrity. With a 200 year legacy and deep expertise in underwriting, actuarial science, and risk management, The Hartford is now doubling down on AI and advanced analytics to unlock new value for businesses and individuals worldwide.

name: ankitnayaketh
content: EpsteinFiles-RAG: Building a RAG Pipeline on 2M+ Pages I love playing around with RAG and AI, optimizing every layer to squeeze out better performance. Last night I thought: why not tackle something massive? Took the Epstein Files dataset from Hugging Face (teyler/epstein-files-20k) ‚Äì 2 million+ pages of trending news and documents. The cleaning, chunking, and optimization challenges are exactly what excites me. What I built: - Full RAG pipeline with optimized data processing - Processed 2M+ pages (cleaning, chunking, vectorization) - Semantic search & Q&A over massive dataset - Constantly tweaking for better retrieval & performance - Python, MIT Licensed, open source Why I built this: It‚Äôs trending, real-world data at scale, the perfect playground. When you operate at scale, every optimization matters. This project lets me experiment with RAG architectures, data pipelines, and AI performance tuning on real-world workloads. Repo: https://lnkd.in/gkw_p-Ti Open to ideas, optimizations, and technical discussions!

name: plaban-nayak-a9433a25
content: üöÄ Just experimented something I'm really excited about ‚Äî a fully autonomous content pipeline that takes a single topic and generates a blog post, infographic, and slide deck without any human intervention. The secret? Combining three powerful technologies: ùóñùóøùó≤ùòÑùóîùóú ‚Äî 5 specialized AI agents working as a team (research librarian, QA gate checker, blog writer, infographic designer, slide producer) ùó†ùóºùó±ùó≤ùóπ ùóñùóºùóªùòÅùó≤ùòÖùòÅ ùó£ùóøùóºùòÅùóºùó∞ùóºùóπ (ùó†ùóñùó£) ‚Äî standardized tool access with permission isolation so each agent only touches what it should ùóöùóºùóºùó¥ùóπùó≤ ùó°ùóºùòÅùó≤ùóØùóºùóºùó∏ùóüùó† ‚Äî deep web research + source-grounded content generation One design choice I'm most proud of: a hybrid architecture where LLM agents handle the reasoning, but a plain Python polling gate handles the waiting. No burning tokens on 10 minutes of "are we there yet?" calls ‚Äî just a simple while loop with subprocess calls. Zero cost, zero hallucination risk. The result? ‚Üí Researches the topic across the web ‚Üí Ingests sources into NotebookLM ‚Üí Waits patiently until ready (deterministic gate) ‚Üí Generates 3 artifacts: blog, infographic, slides ‚Üí Downloads everything to organized output folders Key lessons from building this: ‚úÖ Separate concerns into phases ‚Äî don't let one mega-agent do everything ‚úÖ Use deterministic gates between async operations ‚Äî LLMs are terrible pollers ‚úÖ Isolate tool permissions per agent ‚Äî principle of least privilege via MCP filters ‚úÖ Always verify ‚Äî add Python-level checks after every agent step The future of AI isn't one model doing everything. It's teams of specialized agents with clear roles, working through well-defined interfaces. Wrote a detailed Medium post breaking down the full architecture, tech stack, and CrewAI + MCP implementation #AI #CrewAI #MCP #AgenticAI #NotebookLM #Automation #GenerativeAI #LLM #MultiAgentSystems #BuildInPublic

name: gplhegde
content: We just redefined website templates for the AI era. When we launched hostbento , we assumed people would chat with AI to build hyper-personalized websites. We were wrong. Turns out, people still end up with generic sites that don't reflect their actual business. "Hey ChatGPT, build me a real estate website" ‚Üí generic template that could be for anyone. The real problem isn't how to build. It's what to build. After talking to marketers and agencies, we learned they get stuck on: - What pages do I actually need? - How should this look for my industry? - What content goes where? So we built templates. But not traditional ones. Hostbento templates define your entire design system, not just a page. Pick a template ‚Üí AI adapts the design to your business and content. The template is a reference. AI does the customization. That's what templates should be in the AI era. Got website ideas? We got design system defined for you. Check them out in the comment. #WebsiteTemplate #WebDesign #AIWebsite

name: testerops
content: Found this interesting post on Quora, which was also published in Forbes. This answer by Nachiket Naik is brilliant round -up of many of the programmers out there- even in MNC's. 1) The StackOverflow bot: This person ran into an error, did a quick Google search and applied the first solution they found. The problem here is not that of copying from Stackoverflow. I think there are more solutions on Stackoverflow than any reference guide or manual. Don't get me wrong, it's a wonderful resource, if not the best. The problem is the robotic application of it without understanding the consequences. The problem is the application of it without fully understanding the context of it and whether it really applies to the current problem at hand. More often than not, I have seen people believe more of what they see on online forums than the code/system in front of them. 2) The I-am-not-a-tester: I don't need to test the code, that is the job of the testers. I don't think that even in this age of mature Agile methodologies, this attitude has waned. There is still an inertia against testing their code. Part of it comes from lacking the interest to set up a testing environment and partly from lack of coherent knowledge of testing. (Is it also partly due to an unspoken stigma against testers in the developer community.) 3) The I-hate-documentation: Some people believe that code documentation must be poetic and hence they lack the skill to do it, ergo not their job. In my opinion, these are the #1 foes of sustainable software. Good software is not software that provides a million cool features. Good software is one that has a few good features that are used consistently by many people and read/updated/modified by a thousand . This brand of developers who believes less in technical communication and precise and detailed documentation is the greatest weed to a company's success. 4) The ugly: My code works, but: I have variables named x, flag, str, arr, etc. Most of what I write is in one giant method. There is no indentation. No consistent coding convention or style. Global variables spewed all over the place, etc. This is the most annoying thing for me personally. It's not the issue that the code is bad. It could potentially be the greatest piece of code written. But if a diamond necklace is buried in the debris of the Titanic, nobody will find it, and nobody will want to clean it, wear it, use it. 5) The short-term investor: He codes. He deploys. He moves on. No attempt to learn the problem. No interest in the domain. Just give this guy a piece of code, he will slog on it overnight and hand it over. You got a fix/working software. Nothing more achieved from it. Sometimes, it's important that you have certain selfishness in the developer, one who not only cares about the deadline, but also cares about what he/she got to learn from it. 6) The protester: "I didn't do this". "This looks bad". "Not my problem". "This isn't related really to my fix, but someone way over there made a mistake". "I hate this (loop this sentence 10 times a day)", "I can't fix this, get the person who made this code to fix it". The person who coded that mistake has moved on, when will you? 7) The dictator: My way or the highway is their motto. It's their "ideas" vs "your ideas", not "project ideas". It's their solution vs your solution. I bet there will be an argument for sure. Somehow they will keep coming back to a part of code that you implemented. It somehow discomforts them even if it works, tests, and looks perfectly fine. This person is a big bottleneck to productivity and will be the first person to crumble under pressure and start pointing fingers. This person is not good for the team, however experienced/good a developer he may be. 8) The overcautious: The Java developer who just froze when he learned that he would have to write a Python script. The developer who panicked on learning that something in the registry needs changing. The developer who cringes at having to input things in the database. These people will do anything to avoid getting out of their comfort zone. They have weird superstitions related to having to touch certain parts of the system. I have learned, from personal experience, that this phenomenon is common with new developers. Good developers show a tendency to slowly/swiftly move out of their comfort zone in exploration. 9) The careless: Forgets to take a backup, snapshots, has multiple working directories of code, leaves system out, prints in production code, etc. Again, this is a newbie tendency and gets better with more professional exposure. 10) The lazy pseudo-hacker: They pride themselves at being able to trick the system into working. They find magical solutions to seemingly complex problems. My experience says that 9 out of 10 times, it's just a facade. The hack is bad and will crash sooner or later and will cost much more than having to deal with it, with extra time right now.

name: shantanuladhwe
content: I came across a repo that teaches production RAG in the right order. 7 weeks. 7 blog posts. 1 complete production RAG system. $0 cost. Here's what you'll build: ‚Ü≥ Full infrastructure with Docker + FastAPI ‚Ü≥ Automated data pipelines with Airflow ‚Ü≥ BM25 keyword search (the foundation everyone skips) ‚Ü≥ Hybrid search with Jina embeddings ‚Ü≥ Local LLM integration with Ollama ‚Ü≥ Langfuse monitoring + Redis caching ‚Ü≥ Agentic RAG with LangGraph + Telegram bot This isn't another "RAG in 10 minutes" tutorial. It's how production systems actually get built. Keyword search first. Vectors second. Agents last. The order matters more than most realize. Open-source repo - https://lnkd.in/dkxCMmgN Who's starting this week? --- ‚ôª Repost to help others! üîî Follow me, Shantanu for production AI/ML/MLOps & careers We are hosting a free weekly call on Substack live. name: plaban-nayak-a9433a25
content: Built a NotebookLM-style assistant that grounds answers in your own sources with citations, memory, and optional podcast output. The system ingests PDFs, text, web pages, YouTube, and audio, chunks and embeds them, stores vectors in ChromaDB, retrieves relevant context, and generates cited responses via OpenAI or Anthropic. Zep adds conversation continuity, while AssemblyAI and ElevenLabs power transcription and podcast audio. Tech stack: Streamlit, PyMuPDF, FastEmbed, ChromaDB, CrewAI, AssemblyAI, Firecrawl, Zep, ElevenLabs. Key takeaways: - Modular RAG pipeline with clean separation of ingestion, retrieval, generation, and memory. - Strong UX focus with citation tooltips and studio-style audio outputs. - Provider-agnostic LLM layer with task-based model selection. #RAG , #LLM , #Streamlit , #ChromaDB , #AssemblyAI , #ElevenLabs , #Zep

name: oliver-reeves
content: After a year and a half of devastation on the global market things are finally starting to look up. As I am sure many developers and hiring managers in the tech industry are noticing, the job market is getting more competitive by the day and it isn‚Äôt country-specific. Things are beginning to pick up and get competitive, I can foresee it getting more difficult to hire and to also retain developer talent across all countries‚Äô markets. This is good news for developers, as it raises the standards in working environments and company culture. In my opinion, it is as important for companies to start reconsidering what they are doing to keep the developers that work for them happy, healthy and mentally stimulated. Work benefits can come in many forms. From flexible work arrangements to various opportunities for developers to up-skill themselves, the methods are endless. So, are you listening to your developer team? Are their opinions valued? Do you actually care about their wellbeing? Whatever is going on with your dev team, maybe it is time to reassess what you can do to improve your team‚Äôs day to day life. Not only does it help employees feel appreciated and looked after, it benefits you as a business owner too. As companies are aware, there are many options out there for developers to choose from. In order to attract the best talent, are you doing anything to set yourself up differently compared to other companies? Yes your product might be good and it might be the next best thing, and developers ‚Äúshould feel lucky to be part of the mission‚Äù, but that really is not enough. I can assure you that every founder of a business out there will say that their product will be the next big thing and that developers will be lucky to be part of the mission, but in this market having this approach could make hiring and retaining talent a big issue.

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
content: What differentiates SAP Labs from its competitors is the care it takes of its employees. The very existence of Diversity & Inclusion Team is a testament to SAP‚Äôs commitment in creating and maintaining a great place to work! Keeping the ethos of SAP in mind, the Diversity & Inclusion arm of SAP Labs India (D&I, India) designed and executed the Cross Generational Mentorship Program , which presented the T1 community across all entities (Labs, Ariba, SDC, Concur, Success factors, Fieldglass) and locations (Bangalore, Gurgaon, Pune, Mumbai) with an opportunity to reverse mentor senior colleagues and get mentored by them. The intent was to bridge the gap between the senior and junior colleagues so that both equally benefit from insightful conversations across various domains. Indeed, it was all about breaking biases and fostering, and deepening the learning curve and productivity that leads to success. It is often said that learning something new from a person from a completely different background does much more than developing skills. It makes us lower our prejudices, release preconceived biases, invoke our will, and work on personal network building. And that‚Äôs what happened in Cross Generational Mentorship, where the young talents had to reverse mentor senior colleagues and at the same time get mentored by them. The young talents and senior colleagues had different topics of interest, different perspectives, different mindsets, and more. Yet they were united by the third friend called Cross Generational Mentorship. The concept of Cross Generational Mentorship appeared exceptionally disruptive to both my mentor Ujjwal Nath, Development Manager - Globalization Services and me. Having a T1 reverse mentor for someone who is an accomplished force in the industry confounded me. In an industry where every second day is path-breaking, keeping up with the pace is imperative. It is programs like these that allow people like me to stay on top of an ever-changing ecosystem. While the program expands the horizon for senior members, it opens doors for junior colleagues as well. Truth is, if anyone has been in the industry for at least 6 months, she/he must have heard that networking is key. However, one wonders, how can a junior colleague network? Well, ETs do join in a group and form strong bonds with their peers, but a network is far more valuable when it is diverse. Therefore, Cross Generational Mentorship is the perfect springboard for a junior colleague to diversify her/his network. Besides the networking aspect, a T1 gets to pick on the best brains and learns to imbibe attributes that have made seasoned individuals successful. The current program was kickstarted by D&I Team through setting up the context for the program; they did so through an orientation program in which they invited both the T1s and the senior officials. The program had a special Breaking Gen Myth workshop along with roll out of topics and the new gamification approach, that makes it even more competitive this time, to all the participants. While the ETs chose topics that they would like to mentor on, senior officials chose topics, from the same pool, that they wished to be mentored on. Based on the topics selected, all the participants were paired into sub-groups, which mostly consisted of one senior official and one/two T1s. I was mapped with Ujjwal and successfully completed 7 sessions (both theoretical and hands-on) on multiple topics like Mobile & Social Media, The Generation Game, Career Aspiration Management, How to Climb Up the Ladder, Crowdsourcing Applications, Conversational AI, Cyber Security & Cyber Privacy and Data Boom. From different perspectives we talked, we discussed, we chatted, we debated, and yes, we learned. Ujjwal's coaching sessions paved a path for me on how to reach my short term and long-term goals and make it a reality, whereas my mentoring sessions inspired him to be an active contributor to D&I and had nominated this program to all other senior leaders. In short, it was a platform where lots of questions were asked and answered, lots of discussions happened, and finally resulted in great bonding. Overall, Cross Generational Mentorship not only made our branches reach for the skies but also made our roots go deep. Coming to the close of this blog, I am elated to be a part of something so refreshing. The more I invested in the program, the more I gained from it. Therefore, I urge each T1 or senior colleague reading to give the program a chance. I also would like to laud every participant who took time out to participate in the program, enabling each other to unlock undiscovered areas.

name: abhiroop-hora-21539216a
content: Recently, I wrapped up my journey at Zupee . This place has given me more than just work. The fast pace, the responsibility, and the clear ownership shaped the way I think and work today. I didn‚Äôt just learn technology here ‚Äî I learned how decisions are made, how systems and products are built at scale, and what it truly means to own outcomes in a fast-moving environment. I was fortunate to learn from some truly inspiring leaders. Watching how they think, take calls, and build with clarity has been a powerful part of my journey and something I‚Äôll always carry forward. What makes this goodbye emotional are the people. A special shoutout to Sparsh Pandey ‚Äî from my very first day till today, he stood by me. His constant support, patience, and guidance meant more to me than words can express. The lessons I learned from him will stay with me far beyond this role. Grateful for the journey, the lessons, and the amazing people. Wishing Zupee continued growth and even bigger success ahead. üöÄ

name: amrit-pattnaik-2410ab8
content: üöÄ Why did Kimi K2.5 & Arcee Trinity Large ditch AdamW for Muon? The release of Kimi K2.5 and Arcee‚Äôs Trinity Large introduced clever architectural ideas ‚Äî from Agent Swarm Orchestration to Fine-grained MoEs. But one detail flew under the radar: Both models ditched the industry-standard AdamW optimizer for Muon. While almost all Production Grade LLMs have so far used Adam or AdamW as the optimizer, Kimi has been a pioneer in leveraging this gem in its earlier models (Kimi K2 and Kimi K2 Thinking) and now Arcee has followed suit. I ran a benchmark experiment to find out what makes Muon Optimizer stand out üß™ Experiment 1 ‚Äî Small Model Setup Hidden Dim: 512 Model Depth: 1 Batch Size: 256 Training Steps: 300 Learning Rate: 1e-2 Total Params: ~ 262K üìä Plots 1‚Äì3 show: üîª ~50% lower memory usage (Muon vs AdamW) ‚ö° Faster convergence üìâ Much smoother & more stable training curves üß™ Experiment 2 ‚Äî Scaled Model Setup Hidden Dim: 1024 Model Depth: 8 Batch Size: 256 Training Steps: 300 Learning Rate: 1e-2 Total Params: ~8.39M üìä Plots 4‚Äì6 confirm: Memory savings persist as depth increases Convergence remains faster and steadier Compute efficiency scales with model size üîë Key Takeaways ‚úÖ ~50% lower memory usage ‚ö° ~30‚Äì50% lower compute (FLOPs) üéØ More robust to learning-rate changes ‚Üí less hyperparameter tuning üß† Amplifies rare gradient directions ‚Üí better learning of subtle patterns üìê Normalized update directions ‚Üí controlled geometric training regime üí° Bottom line: As LLMs grow deeper and wider, Muon scales better than AdamW, making it a compelling optimizer for next-gen open-source and production LLMs. Would be interesting to see if Muon is adopted more broadly in large-scale training pipelines going forward üëÄ #LLMs #Optimizers #DeepLearning #OpenSourceAI #Muon #AdamW #Kimi K2.5 #ArceeTrinity #GeometryOptimizers

name: sanchit-goyal14
content: What is ONDC? It is an open protocol network to enable local commerce across segments by engaging with any network-enabled application. In simple words, suppose you want to order milk from the local Kirana shop which accepts Paytm. Now, you can go to the ONDC platform and directly order from this Kirana shop network. Dunzo might deliver your order and you can pay through Paytm. Different platforms like Paytm, Dunzo, Sellerapp, Gofrugal, etc. need to integrate their application with ONDC. There are many other important players with whom talks are going on, like Google Pay, Phone Pe, Microsoft, Zoho, BHIM, etc. Data Points 4000 + small and big e-commerce companies 500 + logistics companies 20,000 + providing services through e-commerce platforms $200 billion estimated market size of e-commerce by 2026 TAM - 624 million Internet users in India SAM - 478 million ( 76.7% e-commerce penetration) SOM - 100 million ( 80-100 million current e-commerce users who have made at least one purchase and assuming 10% increase due to ONDC) Average Order value for grocery - $21 in 2017 AOV for physical goods - Rs 3600 ($48) in 2016 Market Potential - $2.1 billion for grocery alone and $4.8 billion for physical goods However, if we consider the increment of e-commerce users by 20% due to ONDC push then SOM will be 120 million and market potential for physical goods would reach $5.7 billion. Considering 7% of inflation too for AOV, this number would be easily $8 billion in 2022. I have only considered the B2C physical goods market to reach $8 billion. There is a huge B2B market too and then many other categories in B2C too. Features of ONDC Merchants will be able to reach more consumers Both offline traders and online platforms will come at the same level in terms of digital exposure All transactions will happen through an open platform Operations will be standardized and logistics will become more efficient Higher value for consumers as they can order from any merchant The biggest concern about ONDC is confidentiality and privacy of data which needs to be taken care of by the GoI. Pilot Cities The pilot will be launched in five cities in the initial phase. For launching the pilot, metro and Tier 2 cities have been chosen to see how the technology works. Delhi Bengaluru Bhopal Shillong Coimbatore Value Proposition Merchants : No need to worry about logistics and supply chain, just need to make the catalog available digitally to have visibility for everyone connected to the Internet. Consumers : Convenience in ordering from any merchant they want. Applications : More orders for last-mile logistics partners; offline payments shifting to online payments thus benefiting payment partners too. Government of India : Higher employment opportunities; equal digital presence of offline and online traders; all stakeholders on a common platform so easy to monitor; opportunity for village-level merchants and entrepreneurs. Difference in ONDC vs E-commerce players The major difference between the two is that the merchant and the customer can collaborate together irrespective of how one is present digitally. For example, a merchant might not be listed on any platform like Amazon, Flipkart or Dunzo but still can avail the services of Dunzo to send grocery to the customer. In fact, it is possible that the merchant have never availed the services of any digital platform. Another difference is that while ordering from e-commerce players, everything needs to happen on their platform. But using ONDC, offline merchants can easily offer their own forms of support and just use digital platforms for transactions and logistics. Summing Up The ONDC platform is much easy to use. Vendors can onboard easily. There is cost transparency. It will demolish the monopoly of the big e-commerce players who play by their own terms. They give all the facilities to customers but sometimes ignore their sellers. ONDC will bring all the merchants at the same level and will give more value to the customers by increasing the number of listings for them. In case you liked this piece, give a thumbs up. You can connect to me on Twitter too.

name: testerops
content: One of the most important professional qualities that you can have today is the ability to woo the target audience like investors, your team members with a perfect presentation. A nice and well prepared presentation along with killer presentation skills will make your work a lot easier in many scenarios. I am always looking to hone my presentation skills and like to work on it at any point of day. So I always keep on looking for nice articles and people's suggestion on key points which needs to focused more while presenting. And believe me, from a shy person, wary of giving a simple presentation, I have transformed into a confident person, who is not afraid of speaking in front of an audience today. Yesterday, I was browsing Quora, and I found a perfect answer given by Balaji Vishwanathan , on understanding how you would hone your presentation skills. If you go through the answer, he has given a proper, detailed analysis of how to approach and deliver a kick-ass presentation. Before the preparation Who: Understand the target. What does an average person sitting in the auditorium look like? Feel them, imagine them, draw them. What level of competency do they have in the subject you are going to present? Tailor the content to your audience. Never try to go over their heads or beneath their feet. Once you start visualizing the audience and get them into their heads, you can make an emotional bond with them. Why: Understand your motive. Why are you presenting? What are you planning to achieve after the presentation? Is it to attract investors? Is it to convince a scientific audience about the validity of your work? The presentation is just the marketing of your content and cannot be a replacement for your main content (a detailed deck & metrics in case of fund raising & a paper in case of a research presentation). The presentation is one of the weapons that should lead you to that strategic objective. What: Understand the context. What is the broad context of your presentation. Is it a part of a demo day? Is it part of an academic conference? Is it a company meeting? Is it a fund raising event for a charity? Is it a product demo? The context should drive your content and intent. Understand the Bikini rule of life - Reveal enough and conceal enough to spark interest. Most of us have the temptation to dump all the stuff we got into the poor little Powerpoint. That leads to intimidation and confusion. The goal of the presentation should be to spark that interest in your work so that your target comes towards you. In essence it is a conversation starter by gaining their attention. The Marketing Mindset When you are presenting, you are actually marketing [to eventually lead to a "sale" - of whatever you are attempting]. Get into that mindset. You can never sell someone an important idea through a single shot. You need go through a series of stages in the process of them buying your idea. First get them to be aware of your product, generate an interest and eventually lead them to process that leads them to "purchase". Your presentation should do the first two stages below. Preparing for your presentation The powerpoint deck is not a handout . Don't be that guy handing out irrelevant printouts of your powerpoint. Prepare a document handout prepared through a document creator like MS Word or InDesign. The powerpoint deck should not be a readable one . Certainly not a printable one. [If they are reading, they are not listening to you]. It should be to connect. To get your audience to be interested in you. No more than 7-10 words. Once the audience like your idea, they should have the handout to read more and then come to you for a much detailed walk through. Prepare a script. Powerpoint deck is not your cheatsheet to read from. Don't rest on that. Have a strong script and use the projection to complement what you say. When you have finished rehearsing, rehearse hard. Whenever I present without rehearsing, the result shows immediately in the audience [boredom]. Get to the empty stage. Before an important presentation, get to the stage when the whole place is empty. Pace the stage and let the physical world consume you. Feel at home and let the environment absorb you. Do a dry run. During one of my recent presentations, I didn't do a tech dry run. Not surprisingly the tech melted down and there was precious minutes lost. Make sure the technology doesn't fail you. Be very comfortable with the clothes you are going to wear. You should feel those clothes are an extension of your body. I have a favorite suit I bought 7 years ago and I don't wear any of my other suits for the most important presentations. I take it ceremonially and feel like a knight in his armor. That suit provides the cloak of invincibility. Once I'm in, I feel all the good omens from the past presentations come in and push me and give the confidence. When I'm in my favorite suit, I feel I can convince anyone in the world. During the presentation Have a good look at the audience and your preparation should have made you feel very close to that target. After you get to the stage and have setup your mike, don't start talking immediately. Pause a couple of seconds taking a good strong look with a strong smile [you can see that great leaders always do that before they start their speech]. That is when you are conveying you can be trusted. That brief 2-3 seconds can be very crucial. Disarm and charm the audience with mild self-deprecation . Get your first joke on yourself. Let the audience laugh. While I was once presenting to a group of rich southerners in Nashville, I made fun of my accent. The audience were smiling the whole time as I turned by weakness into an advantage [they were more attentive due to my accent, after that point]. I opened with this slide on 2 different occassions [both very important] and on both occassions, the audience burst out laughing & remembered the presentation. A designer friend crafted this deck for me. Don't turn your back on the audience and look to move a bit. A body language expert once coached on the right way to move & make the audience trust. Coming forward conveys trust. So, when you are conveying your big idea or getting to the ask, move a few inches forward. That little movement forward can send a lot of subtle cues. Going back can send messages of dishonestly. Thus, avoid moving back [unless you are taking a joke on you] and always make a small movement forward - and make that movement so subtle that the audience doesn't even know you are walking towards them. Also avoid showing the back of your hand or the back of the body - those all increases distrust. Master your pauses. This is the hardest thing to do for non-professionals. Masters of drama know when to pause to give that impact. After your big idea got to the screen, wait a second or two to give that dramatic effect. Let the audience absorb the drama. Keep your basics correct - making eye contact with a chunk of the audience, changing your tones a bit. As a parting note, give the presentation its due importance. Give the audience their due respect. A presentation can change your whole life. Thus, take it seriously and do the homework.

name: amitandani
content: Recently, completing the NeuroLeadership Institute's "Team: The Neuroscience of Psychological Safety" course powerfully reaffirmed a critical truth for leaders: Psychological safety isn't merely a "soft skill" - it's a definitive strategic advantage. High-performing teams don't just avoid conflict; they thrive because leaders deliberately cultivate an environment where everyone feels secure enough to speak up, challenge norms, experiment, and learn openly. This is the true genesis of innovation. Fundamentally, psychological safety empowers teams to: ‚û§ Share diverse perspectives without hesitation. ‚û§ Challenge assumptions, sparking new ideas. ‚û§ View mistakes as invaluable learning opportunities. ‚û§ Contribute confidently, regardless of communication style. As leaders, our actions set the precedent. Our behavior directly dictates whether our teams feel empowered to think boldly or constrained by hesitation. Three Leadership Habits Driving Psychological Safety: ‚úÖ 1 - Set the Stage - Clarity & Shared Purpose ‚û§ Define "Us": Establish team identity and collective purpose. ‚û§ Frame Impact: Articulate the significance and value of our work. ‚û§ Proactive Planning: Anticipate and prepare for challenges effectively. ‚úÖ 2 - Invite Participation - Amplify Every Voice ‚û§ Lead with Humility: Demonstrate an openness to not having all answers. ‚û§ Streamline Input: Provide diverse, easy channels for contribution. ‚û§ Spark Curiosity: Actively encourage fresh perspectives and exploration. ‚úÖ 3 - Respond Thoughtfully - Reinforce Openness ‚û§ Validate Contributions: Acknowledge and affirm inputs to build confidence. ‚û§ Cultivate Constructive Debate: Normalize respectful challenges and disagreements. ‚û§ Drive Forward Thinking: Elevate ideas to uncover breakthrough innovations. Consistent application of these habits builds teams that collaborate with unwavering confidence and innovate with genuine courage. A sincere thank you to DBS Bank and DBS Tech India for championing continuous learning and enabling us to integrate these crucial principles into our leadership practices. It is our collective responsibility as leaders to forge environments where individuals feel safe to think boldly, speak openly, and continuously evolve‚Äîbecause this is precisely where groundbreaking innovation truly takes root. #PsychologicalSafety #LeadershipDevelopment #GrowwithDBSTech

name: abidalee
content: The world is constantly evolving around us. Things change every day. New trends emerge regularly and become the ‚Äòtalk of the town‚Äô. Everybody jumps onto the bandwagon. Just in the 20th century many new careers evolved. There was a time when manufacturing was at the top, then the banking, medicine, engineering, and law took the place, and with the advent of the information age and with the growing computing power, every industry is adopting computers as it has become necessary. The 21st century is so called ‚Äòthe Information age‚Äô but for how long? Would it become just like other careers due to the saturation and then we will ‚Äòinvent‚Äô another career? Many people get MBAs hoping to get into executive roles but many end up doing normal accounting, finance, banking or marketing. Some like to pursue performing arts, while others like liberal arts. The point is, there are too many career choices, don‚Äôt limit yourself, look around, find what you truly like and believe in, and then pursue it with passion and dedication, but do not just follow the crowd. IT seems to be one of the major career choices for many these days but IT is not just writing computer programs. It is like medical field, too many options to choose from. Not everyone is and should be a technical person. Computer is not just about writing programs, it is much more than that. There are many areas in IT like thought leadership, sales, marketing, animations, graphics, games, hardware, software and many more to choose from. Don‚Äôt get confused by the buzz words like ‚Äòcloud‚Äô, ‚Äòbig data‚Äô, and the like. As long as you know the basic principles, everything remains the same. Just because you are studying computers and don‚Äôt like programming and are not good at it, it does not belittle you in anyway. There are too many options to choose from because ‚Äòthe world is your oyster.‚Äô But yes, ‚Äòconstantly reinvent yourself‚Äô and keep learning new things as ‚Äòmoving water never goes stale.‚Äô Web: http://parwaaztheflight.org Facebook: www.facebook.com/ParwaazTheFlight Twitter: https://twitter.com/ParwazTheFlight Parwaaz Intro: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AjceJlDS2g4 Let's 'light a candle', the candle of 'kindness', the candle of 'hope', the candle of 'love and affection', and the candle of 'knowledge and wisdom', to 'fight the darkness', the darkness within and around.

name: souhamdash
content: Not every AI agent deserves your attention. ùó¢ùóΩùó≤ùóªùóñùóπùóÆùòÑ earned mine. ü¶û Yesterday, I installed OpenClaw on my local machine. Not as a casual tech experiment. As a product hypothesis. After a couple of years of building AI-first products, you develop an instinct for separating signal from noise. Most ‚ÄúAI agents‚Äù today are still chatbots with better storytelling. OpenClaw felt different, and the reason becomes obvious once you look at how it‚Äôs designed. At its core, it cleanly separates: * Brain ‚Üí reasoning models * Hands ‚Üí executable skills * Memory ‚Üí persistent, human-readable state (Markdown, not mystery blobs) This distinction is not cosmetic. It‚Äôs the difference between rigid workflow automation and outcome-driven delegation, where you describe intent and the system constructs the pipeline. That‚Äôs a meaningful architectural shift. I spent time stress-testing multi-model orchestration (Claude for depth, GPT for speed, local models for sensitive work), modular skills defined in plain English, persistent file-based memory, cross-platform task execution, and sandboxed security boundaries. This feels less like prompt engineering and more like designing a system that can actually do work. It‚Äôs not polished. Installation friction is real, the trust layer is still maturing, and the UX assumes technical fluency. But the latest release shipping a malicious-skill scanner tells me the team understands the real adoption blockers and is moving fast. This isn‚Äôt about being perfect. It‚Äôs about proving the paradigm. We‚Äôre watching the shift from ‚Äúùóîùóú ùóÆùòÄ ùóÆ ùó≥ùó≤ùóÆùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤‚Äù ùòÅùóº ‚Äúùóîùóú ùóÆùòÄ ùó∂ùóªùó≥ùóøùóÆùòÄùòÅùóøùòÇùó∞ùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤.‚Äù OpenClaw makes that shift tangible. #OpenClaw #AIProductManagement #GenerativeAI #AIAgents #TechStrategy #AgenticAI

content: We came in with one clear message: Turning digital assets into everyday spending power. Happy to see the adoption of our card programme growing fast. üöÄ From live demos of the Rapidz App to awesome chat around stablecoins, cards, on/off-ramp aggregation and real-world B2B use cases. The level of engagement was amazing! What stood out most: - Builders are now focused on real revenue, not just narratives - Stablecoin payments are no longer a ‚Äúfuture trend‚Äù ‚Äî they‚Äôre infrastructure - Businesses want compliant, scalable rails that actually work At Rapidz, we‚Äôre building exactly that. üôÇ Big thanks to everyone who stopped by our booth, provided feedback, and explored partnerships. If we missed you at Consensus, happy to continue the conversation. Brazil next! üáßüá∑

name: tripti-srivastava-28958416a
content: Ever wondered why PINK screams "girl power" everywhere? Did we girls/women pick it, or did someone hand it to us on a pink platter? This question's been buzzing in my head for years, looking at gender reveal parties (blue balloons for boys, pink for girls), family baby showers drowning in pink gifts, and ads pushing the vibe. Fun fact from history though: Back in the early 1900s, pink was for boys (think fiery red vibes), blue for girls. But mid-20th century marketers flipped the script with clever campaigns, store guides, and Barbie dolls, making pink the girl color. Baby girls get pink dreamcatchers, frocks, and toys from day one! it's the world serving it up, not always our choice! (Not Mine atleast). Here we are in 2026, and it's still the same old tune: Relatives popping blue/pink balloons for newborns (rainbow gets ignored), funny-not-funny videos of dads sulking over Barbie bags vs cheerful with video games ("Dude, let her pick: FIFA or dolls?"), and few nonprofits (sorry but not sorry!) slapping "Pink" on everything women-related. Pink Toilets? Government! Really? (The ladies' sign works fine!) I was introduced to PS5, Hot Wheels, punching bags, and COD pretty late by my male cousins, friends, and husband, but now I absolutely love them! And boys can love pink too! Again, it's 2026 and STILL! Not starting a fight, just sharing a lightbulb moment. Am I solo in my circle on this? Your thoughts? Nudging ads, brands, gov programs, nonprofits, friends, and family toward choice, not checkboxes! What do you think? Ministry of Women & Child Development Procter & Gamble Swachh Bharat Mission Grameen Est√©e Lauder #LetUsChoose #RealTalk #MarketingNudge #LetKidsChoose
