name: testerops
content: Here is an excellent post I found on Quora, posted by Oliver Emberton. Our brains are the most bug ridden pieces of junk since Internet Explorer. To replicate one common bug, try telling your brain to ‚Äúgo to the gym‚Äù. Most brains will respond by updating their Facebook status, and watching cat videos. This is not the desired behaviour. Fortunately I‚Äôve developed a fix. Let me just explain how the whole human brain works first. This code is a mess Looking at our brain, it‚Äôs clear it was developed by a team of ten thousand monkeys with a serious drinking problem. You know, like Windows 8. The brain is event-driven , which is to say it does almost nothing until an event occurs, and then it responds to the event. Your hand gets hot, you pull it back. Your stomach rumbles, you look for food. Unfortunately there are a lot of events. There are events for shiny objects coming into view, or for scary monsters, or for boobs ‚Äì actually, there are 856 different events for boobs, but I digress ‚Äì and all of these events are firing in our brain and competing for our limited processing ability. Too late the developers realised this would leave us bouncing between distractions like a cat chasing a laser pointer, and they hacked in a priority system. Unfortunately, our priority system is a bit pants: the default priority for sitting down is higher than the priority for working out. But wait! We‚Äôre smarter than ‚Äì ooh, a squirrel Don‚Äôt we have some kind of clever, conscious brain though? The part that does math and plays chess and copies Sally‚Äôs homework? Well, yes. But that part is event driven too, which is to say it‚Äôs not on all the time. It turns out our brains were optimised for energy efficiency, and they only turn on their CPU (Consciousness Processing Unit) when absolutely necessary. If you‚Äôve ever realised you‚Äôve been driving for an hour and hadn‚Äôt even noticed, that was your consciousness going into Standby Mode. It‚Äôs your consciousness that tells you to exercise, even if you don‚Äôt want to, because it can see the long term benefits are greater than the short term pain. And when it‚Äôs in control, you do so. But consciousness demands a lot of power. When your mental battery is low, it‚Äôs easily overpowered out by higher priorities, like playing Hearthstone or squeezing a particularly awkward spot. The bug fix We‚Äôre going to add a new event of our own to fix things. Non-programmers might call this a ‚Äòhabit‚Äô. Our new event is triggered by a transition . For example, if you wake up, that‚Äôs a transition. Arrive at your desk ‚Äì that‚Äôs a transition. Arrive home ‚Äì that‚Äôs a transition. It‚Äôs at the transition that our behaviour is most likely to be hijacked by the highest priority event that happens to be in our brain at the time. If you‚Äôve arrived home, chances are that event is ‚ÄúI‚Äôm knackered‚Äù and you‚Äôll fall onto the sofa. We need to stop that. Don‚Äôt worry if you‚Äôre not fluent in Brain Programming (B#) ‚Äì just remember three words: ‚ÄúNo. Right. Now.‚Äù Let‚Äôs break it down: ‚ÄúNo‚Äù Firstly, we need to interrupt all other events. There‚Äôs a trick for overpowering mental distractions, and that‚Äôs to make your intention insanely simple . No is about as simple an intention as you can get. No means simply reject everything . If you want to check Facebook, the answer is no. If someone is asking you if you have 5 minutes, the answer is no. If this will piss someone off, it‚Äôs still no. Don‚Äôt complicate this with exceptions. Exceptions will happen anyway ‚Äì if your house is on fire, primal instincts will take over. But 99.9% of the time, in our comfortable modern lives, the greatest danger to you is that you live by your outdated survival impulses. Start by saying no to everything. You might worry that by declining everyone and everything you‚Äôll become some kind of sociopathic robot. You‚Äôll still have time for those distractions later. Tell people that . The trick is to get done what matters first . ‚ÄúRight‚Äù Now ask yourself what is the one ‚Äòright‚Äô thing you should be doing now. I did not say three things . There can be only one. You shouldn‚Äôt need to think about this much, because your conscious brain should already have decided for you the night before: it‚Äôs usually the one thing you want to do all the time, but never find time for. A crucial distinction here is importance versus urgency . The most important things in life ‚Äì like eating healthy ‚Äì are rarely urgent. And our brain‚Äôs buggy events are great at dealing with urgent things ‚Äì like the phone ringing ‚Äì all by themselves. So when given the choice, choose importance over urgency . It makes the most difference in the long run. ‚ÄúNow‚Äù Start doing the right thing immediately. Not after you‚Äôve checked your email ‚Äì immediately . Don‚Äôt give yourself time to even think about it , just start . Starting is always the hardest part; the very inertia which makes something hard to start can make it equally hard to stop. This simple fix works because when you transition from one place to another, your brain is unusually receptive to events. It needs to decide on a new course of action, and once it chooses one it tends to stick to it. Unfortunately we tend to make stupid decisions at transitions, because we don‚Äôt think about them: Interrupt your transitions with the right choices, and you‚Äôll find yourself doing what matters far, far more often: Just remember: ‚ÄúNo. Right. Now.‚Äù Three short words to program a life changing habit. Here is the link to the complete answer- with awesome images : http://abetterlife.quora.com/How-to-debug-your-brain

name: swatiichandak
content: As I swayed with the mustard fields, a thought kept returning to me, leadership reminds me of Farming... A farmer understands that growth does not come from giving equal attention to every patch of land, it comes from patiently nurturing what carries the promise of a good harvest. When focus shifts toward distractions rather than nurturing potential, the healthiest plants quietly lose their strength‚Ä¶ ...and sometimes, they are replanted where the soil supports their growth. A farmer eventually turns to new land when the soil no longer nurtures the crops that are ready to grow. In the same way, people who work with purpose know when to raise their voice for what truly matters, and when to remain quiet and let their work speak for itself. They continue with sincerity, hoping the environment aligns with vision but when meaning fades, they move forward with grace. Perhaps leadership lies in recognising what deserves nurturing, what needs direction, and what should not distract us from collective growth.

content: Designing a Fiery üî• identity for : Mirch√°n üå∂Ô∏è a modern dining brand built around fire-led cooking, bold flavours, and spice that invites you in rather than dares you. Rooted in Indian kebab and grill traditions but viewed through a contemporary lens, Mirch√°n reimagines what premium dining can feel like when you strip away the pretense and add genuine personality. From the visual identity and spice card system (check Behance) to story-driven menus and playful touchpoints, every element was designed to make guests feel like they belong to something not just another restaurant reservation. This project pushed me to think about how brands can build community, how design can guide experience, and how the right tone can turn a meal into a memory. I've put together the full case study on Behance with the design process, and all the collateral that brings Mirch√°n to life. üîó link in comment. #brandidentity #restaurantbranding

name: plaban-nayak-a9433a25
content: Building AI Agents That Actually Learn From Experience Most AI agents today are static. They execute tasks, return results, and forget everything by the next session. But what if agents could genuinely learn and improve over time? I've been exploring a continual learning framework built on a simple but powerful loop: ACT ‚Üí RECORD ‚Üí REFLECT ‚Üí LEARN The agent doesn't just complete tasks‚Äîit captures every action, analyzes its own performance, and extracts reusable knowledge. This happens through three distinct learning mechanisms: 1. Memory Learning The agent remembers facts, user preferences, and behavioral patterns. No more repeating yourself across sessions. 2. Prompt Optimization Through self-reflection, the agent identifies what worked and refines its own instructions. It literally rewrites how it thinks. 3. Skill Creation Successful multi-step workflows get extracted into reusable skills (SOPs). What once required step-by-step guidance becomes a single command. The key insight: learning isn't a separate training phase. It's woven into the operational loop. Every interaction is an opportunity to improve. This mirrors how humans develop expertise‚Äîthrough deliberate practice and reflection, not just repetition. The gap between "AI assistant" and "AI colleague" isn't more parameters. It's memory, self-improvement, and accumulated skill. Curious to hear from others building in this space‚Äîhow are you approaching agent learning and long-term memory?

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
content: It‚Äôs really great that you have decided to work on one of the most prominent DI frameworks of today. Before going into the content flow, I will give a short introduction. So, what is Spring? The Spring Framework is an application framework and inversion of control container for the Java platform. The framework's core features can be used by any Java application, but there are extensions for building web applications on top of the Java EE platform. How should you study Spring? Every technology is better understood when you are clear with its concepts. So, I will recommend you to study Spring, dividing the curriculum in nine different modules as below. Introduction: Difference between Spring and EJB, Java Beans, Factory Design Pattern, Spring Architecture, Spring Modules, New Features of Spring, Installation, Directory Structure, Spring Namespaces Aspect Oriented Programming: Definition, Advantages, AOP Terminologies, Advice Types, Static and Dynamic Pointcuts, Proxy Based AOP, Declarative Based AOP, Annotation Based AOP Minimizing Spring Configuration: Explicit Wiring, Autowiring, Annotation Based Wiring, Autodiscovery, Java Based Configuration Spring Middle Layer: Spring DAO, Template Callback Design Pattern, Spring JDBC, Spring with Hibernate, Programmative and Declarative Transactions with differences, Propagation Behavior, Isolation Levels Spring MVC: Introduction, Spring MVC Architecture, HandlerMapping, ViewResolver, Controller Classes, MVC Workflow, Annotation Driven Controller, Form Binding and Processing, Validations Spring with REST API Spring Security Spring with STRUTS Integration Spring Boot Once you are thorough with all these above topics, you are all set in Spring. Hope by now, you have figured out how to plan your Spring studies‚Ä¶ Enjoy Learning!!! Happy Coding!!!

name: abidalee
content: For last several months I have seen these and similar hashtags, never in my wildest imaginations I had thought that I would be using them myself. I read many stories over the months, some based on science, others based on conspiracy theories. The former I found to be useful and full of hope, and the later, full of ignorance. I say this because of my first-hand experience with #covid19. The year 2020 ended with bad news for our family, my father was tested positive on December 31st. The year 2021 brought another bad news, i.e. my mother was tested positive on Jan 1st (followed by several of my siblings getting the virus). We were hopeful because both my parents (and the entire family) were fighting it. The battle started at home, moved quickly to the hospital, and within a few days we lost our dear mother yesterday to this deadly disease. It is hard to believe that just a few days ago I was speaking with her on the phone, and she was full of life and hope, and now she is not among us. She was a very strong woman and fought till the last minute. She was fully determined to beat it but unfortunately she lost the battle and the virus took her life. All the recent and advanced medications couldn‚Äôt save her. My father and other family members are recuperating and we as a family continue to fight this battle (hence need all the prayers). I wanted to take a moment and remind everyone that please do not listen to the ignorant people who think of #covid19 as a hoax. It is a deadly disease, from speaking with my mother on phone a few days ago to seeing her losing her battle just in a matter of days proves one thing to me that this disease is NOT a joke, and it is not going anywhere until it has done enough damage. You need to protect yourself and your loved ones. The easiest thing is to ‚Äòwear a mask!‚Äô. I also want to mention that we often focus on the patients and forget the caretakers, who are the #realheroes, and by caretakers, I don‚Äôt mean the medical professionals (yes they are indeed heroes), but I mean the family members, who are fighting the battle alongside their loved ones. My mother has always been my hero and source of strength and inspiration, but today, my even a bigger hero is #Neelum, our little sister, who did not give up till the last minute, who was rushing from ward to ward, pharmacy to pharmacy, 24x7, without any sleep or even caring for her own health. She is the #realwonderwoman of the family because she was the #lastonestanding while everyone else got the virus. She, just like our mother, was fully determined to defeat the virus but it did eventually take away our mother. All power to you #Neelum and thanks for being the source of hope and strength for the entire family during these trying times

name: kristen-kehrer-datamovesme
content: The biggest pain point or challenge I hear when people are writing their resume is that they want concise, crisp, effective content that sounds impactful. But they‚Äôre not sure how to write that wonderful content they want. There is so much to consider when thinking about your content. There are many different traits you want to showcase on your resume that the business values for any given position. There is much more to a successful data science hire than just technical and machine learning ability, and we‚Äôll want to think about how to best position these skills as well. Here are some quick examples of how you can up-level the content on your resume to get you started. Here we‚Äôre going to cover: Starting with a verb Ending with the value you provided STARTING WITH A VERB Strong statements start with an action verb. A short list of some verbs that you can try to apply to your experience include: Built Delivered Developed Increased efficiency Created Evaluated Trained Try to vary your verbs as well. Don‚Äôt use the same one over and over again throughout your resume. So we have some words, let‚Äôs look at some real examples from resumes and how the statements improve by starting with a verb. This first example comes from a math teacher who is learning data science through MOOCs and is planning to make a career change. Original: ‚ÄúI ran live lessons on Blackboard Collaborate and attended meetings via the computer.‚Äù Updated: ‚ÄúPresented math training virtually, delivered mathematical concepts in a way that students could easily comprehend and learn.‚Äù This shows that she is able to break down material and communicate well. The following would also work: Updated (another version): ‚ÄúConducted virtual meetings with expert communication. Provided students the ability to receive one-on-one guidance to keep them on pace in a way that fit their schedule.‚Äù The next example is from a BI professional who is also looking to make a move to data science: Original: ‚ÄúParticipation in Global Transformation Program as Commercial Finance Business Intelligence (BI) expert (Credit and Collections), in the definition of KPIs and Global template Reports. Testing, Business Readiness and Post Go live support for Ecuador implementation (Releases 1, 2 and 3). Support to front office area (sales and distribution).‚Äù Here, our example owned the definition of KPIs and reporting. She also contributed cross-functionally to help make this project a success. Talking about ownership of KPIs, and being a strong contributor cross-functionally sounds stronger when we begin with a verb instead of ‚Äúparticipation‚Äù (noun). Updated: ‚ÄúOwned definition of KPIs and reporting, ensuring accuracy and allowing for self-service of key metrics by stakeholders.‚Äù I‚Äôd certainly need to create more bullet points to capture all of the information in the original, but this is an idea of what we‚Äôre trying to achieve. ENDING YOUR STATEMENTS WITH THE RESULT OR VALUE Let‚Äôs look at an opportunity for improvement that was on my resume for a while. Original: ‚Äú Built Neural Network models to forecast hourly electric load.‚Äù Cool story, but did I just build it for fun? Or was it useful? Especially in a space where businesses are all too familiar with someone building a fancy model, and then it never gets used for anything, it is of utmost importance that you clearly demonstrate how your work was utilized. Spell. it. out. Updated: ‚ÄúBuilt Neural Network models to forecast hourly electric load. Model output was imperative during extreme weather and was used for capacity planning decisions.‚Äù Now I have a statement that shows not only that I delivered a model, but that model delivered value to the business. Maybe your previous work experience doesn‚Äôt involve building a model. Maybe you built a dashboard. Did that dashboard allow your stakeholders to get valuable information on their own (referred to as self-service)? That‚Äôs value. Did the dashboard reduce the amount of time spent on ad-hoc, low value data aggregation so you could focus on higher value initiatives? That‚Äôs value, because here you‚Äôre increasing efficiency. In my resume course I go into much deeper detail, but I hope this gives you a great starting point on how to begin creating strong content. Using verbs as your starting point and demonstrating the value your work provided is a great step towards marketing yourself and showcasing your talents. If you‚Äôd like to learn more about my resume course you can find that here. Originally posted on https://datamovesme.com

name: stephenthomashiggins
content: Thinking about vibe coding your own version of HubSpot? Here‚Äôs why it might be a good idea. You‚Äôre technical. You‚Äôre efficient. AI can scaffold a clean CRM in a weekend. No bloat. No subscription fees. Fully customized to your motion. On the surface, it makes sense. Until you remember: a CRM isn‚Äôt a database with stages. It‚Äôs your: ‚Ä¢ System of record ‚Ä¢ Forecasting engine ‚Ä¢ Revenue governance layer ‚Ä¢ Attribution model ‚Ä¢ Automation hub ‚Ä¢ Integration spine ‚Ä¢ Compliance surface And it has to work at scale. Vibe coding works when the blast radius is small ‚Äî internal tools, workflow prototypes, lightweight automation, reporting overlays. If it breaks, nothing fundamental breaks. A CRM is different. The failure cost compounds over time: ‚Ä¢ Data integrity degrades. ‚Ä¢ Forecast accuracy erodes. ‚Ä¢ Integrations become technical debt. ‚Ä¢ Security and permissions become your problem. ‚Ä¢ Adoption becomes a behavioral battle. Most homegrown CRMs don‚Äôt fail immediately. They fail at scale. And here‚Äôs the real issue: opportunity cost. If you‚Äôre a founder or revenue leader, your leverage isn‚Äôt writing CRUD logic. It‚Äôs improving win rates, cycle time, ACV, talent density, and forecast precision. Every hour spent maintaining infrastructure is an hour not spent increasing revenue throughput. Platforms like HubSpot outperform custom builds not because they‚Äôre perfect ‚Äî but because they compound: ‚Ä¢ Institutionalized GTM best practices ‚Ä¢ Reliability under scale ‚Ä¢ Deep integrations ‚Ä¢ Continuous iteration without engineering lift ‚Ä¢ Board-level credibility in forecasting The trap is ego disguised as efficiency: ‚ÄúWe can build it cleaner.‚Äù Maybe. For a while. But you‚Äôll eventually pay in technical debt, migration pain, or both. Vibe code the experiments. Configure the infrastructure. Your CRM isn‚Äôt a side project. It‚Äôs your revenue operating system.

content: Nothing beats in person. The past few weeks made that clear. Our new CRO, Greg , has been commuting while preparing to move his family from Boston to NYC. That is real commitment. This photo says it better than I can. Moving a career is one thing. Moving a family is another. When Greg is in the room, you feel it. Faster decisions, sharper debate, tighter alignment. Remote works. In person accelerates. Excited to have Greg here. A genuine thank you to his wife Amberly and wonderful kids. Big moves like this are a team effort.

name: ybernstein
content: Process is a skeleton. Culture is the muscles that attach to that skeleton. Without muscles to move it, the skeleton is inert and useless. Without a skeleton to attach to, the muscles are an amorphous and undirected mass. It is easy to assume that an organisation lacking in process will be fixed simply by the addition of and adherence to that process. I made that assumption, but it turns out to be wrong. Process needs to be introduced in tandem with a concerted initiative to evolve the culture such that the process becomes embedded within the culture. I've spoken about code review before. Code review was one of my favourite things about working as a software engineer at Google. When I joined Flare, there was no code review, so I thought the fix was easy: introduce code review! And I did. But although this was necessary, it turned out not to be sufficient. Code reviews felt more like a rubber stamp than robust forums for discussion and upholding the values and norms of software quality. We had the skeleton, but without the muscle code review seemed more like an impediment than something really valuable. Only with a lot of hard work alongside the team have we started to develop a culture of code review. The stronger the culture, the more value we get.

name: mikendeva
content: The AI landscape is shifting here in Oz. Over the last few weeks, this is what‚Äôs consistently coming up in the nDeva CTO Community and in conversations with CTOs. ‚Äì AI is embedded. Cursor, Claude, Copilot. Daily workflow now. Nobody is debating whether to use it. ‚Äì Autonomous agents look impressive. Deterministic workflows are what actually ship. ‚Äì RAG gets messy quickly once documents are interlinked or regulated. It‚Äôs harder than most people think. ‚Äì Integrated cloud stacks are starting to win over fully custom builds once complexity kicks in. ‚Äì AI cost is becoming a real line item. It‚Äôs no longer magic. It‚Äôs infrastructure. ‚Äì In Australia, region and compliance genuinely shape architecture decisions. What I‚Äôm noticing is the conversation is getting more practical. Architecture. Constraints. Costs. Compliance. Curious what others are seeing inside their teams right now?

name: ybernstein
content: One of the things that excites me about working in technology is the subtle but deep interplay between technology, product, and market. Making the right decision on a matter as seemingly technical as how to set up indexes on a database table requires an understanding of how the product is used, and what the key drivers of the business are. What are the most common patterns of access to the data going to be? Which queries sit behind latency-sensitive conversion drivers and must be optimised at any expense? And so on. At the same time, product and business decisions cannot be made well without meaningful technical input. A particular product decision might be really easy to implement, or it might be very hard. Is doubling the number of events being logged simply a matter of adding a couple of lines of code? Or does it involve refactoring a complex module to remove a performance bottleneck? In the latter case, perhaps a simple workaround (shard to two different logs) would obviate the need for a huge amount of work. Software development is an endless series of decisions and tradeoffs, large and small. Attempting to centralise this decision-making with product management or engineering leadership results in disastrous micromanagement. Most likely, many of the decisions are taken by developers anyway---but without the necessary context and thus suboptimally. The only way to build great products is to empower developers to act like product owners. What does this mean? At the most basic level this requires that developers have a good understanding of the product they are building. Software development takes place within a broader context. If you deny software developers the context they need to make good technical decisions, the result will be much like an historical novel written by somebody with no knowledge of the relevant period in history; perhaps satisfactory in superficial form, but filled with incorrect details and misapprehensions. It is imperative that developers are both expected and afforded the opportunity to understand their users and customers---and indeed to think of them as their users and customers. Beyond understanding, a true developer-as-product-owner mentality means constructively questioning the product and making suggestions about how the product (as opposed to just the software) could be built. As a technical leader, I often see myself as the yin to a Product Manager's yang. Both of us are in a sense paid to think about how to build a good product; but whereas the PMs job is to think expansively and creatively about what could be, the technical lead's job is to keep that vision of the future grounded to realities of technology and limited resources. But I hate being a bottleneck, so a much better way of scaling this dynamic is for all developers to take this approach. At Google, one of the dimensions along which a developer's performance was measured was the impact of their work. When this new rubric was first introduced, I was quite unhappy with it. I even wrote a long internal blog post called "impact considered harmful" that argued it was unfair to judge a developer's performance based on something that was in many cases beyond their control. As time passed, though, I realised that having impact as part of my job description was actually very empowering. If I'm required to optimise my impact, that means that all sorts of things are now part of my job! This realisation instantly made me feel more like a product owner, because bad product decisions or strategic indecisiveness had the possibility to drag down my performance score. Ultimately thinking like a product owner means caring about the end result, not just about an intermediate output. Whether you are in a small startup (where this comes naturally) or a hulking multinational (where it takes real effort to instill the culture) there is no doubt that having everybody keeping their eye on what their organisation is actually trying to achieve leads to more accountability and better decision-making across the board.
clean_content: one of the things that excites me about working in technology is the subtle but deep interplay between technology, product, and market. making the right decision on a matter as seemingly technical as how to set up indexes on a database table requires an understanding of how the product is used, and what the key drivers of the business are. what are the most common patterns of access to the data going to be? which queries sit behind latency-sensitive conversion drivers and must be optimised at any expense? and so on. at the same time, product and business decisions cannot be made well without meaningful technical input. a particular product decision might be really easy to implement, or it might be very hard. is doubling the number of events being logged simply a matter of adding a couple of lines of code? or does it involve refactoring a complex module to remove a performance bottleneck? in the latter case, perhaps a simple workaround shard to two different logs would obviate the need for a huge amount of work. software development is an endless series of decisions and tradeoffs, large and small. attempting to centralise this decision-making with product management or engineering leadership results in disastrous micromanagement. most likely, many of the decisions are taken by developers anyway---but without the necessary context and thus suboptimally. the only way to build great products is to empower developers to act like product owners. what does this mean? at the most basic level this requires that developers have a good understanding of the product they are building. software development takes place within a broader context. if you deny software developers the context they need to make good technical decisions, the result will be much like an historical novel written by somebody with no knowledge of the relevant period in history; perhaps satisfactory in superficial form, but filled with incorrect details and misapprehensions. it is imperative that developers are both expected and afforded the opportunity to understand their users and customers---and indeed to think of them as their users and customers. beyond understanding, a true developer-as-product-owner mentality means constructively questioning the product and making suggestions about how the product as opposed to just the software could be built. as a technical leader, i often see myself as the yin to a product manager's yang. both of us are in a sense paid to think about how to build a good product; but whereas the pms job is to think expansively and creatively about what could be, the technical lead's job is to keep that vision of the future grounded to realities of technology and limited resources. but i hate being a bottleneck, so a much better way of scaling this dynamic is for all developers to take this approach. at google, one of the dimensions along which a developer's performance was measured was the impact of their work. when this new rubric was first introduced, i was quite unhappy with it. i even wrote a long internal blog post called "impact considered harmful" that argued it was unfair to judge a developer's performance based on something that was in many cases beyond their control. as time passed, though, i realised that having impact as part of my job description was actually very empowering. if i'm required to optimise my impact, that means that all sorts of things are now part of my job! this realisation instantly made me feel more like a product owner, because bad product decisions or strategic indecisiveness had the possibility to drag down my performance score. ultimately thinking like a product owner means caring about the end result, not just about an intermediate output. whether you are in a small startup where this comes naturally or a hulking multinational where it takes real effort to instill the culture there is no doubt that having everybody keeping their eye on what their organisation is actually trying to achieve leads to more accountability and better decision-making across the board.
first_sentence: one of the things that excites me about working in technology is the subtle but deep interplay between technology, product, and market

name: stephaniehillsphd
content: You don‚Äôt need more credentials. You need more clarity . That‚Äôs what actually moves your career forward. üöÄ When I first started my business, I felt completely stuck. I was running the business, trying different things, juggling ideas‚Äîbut I wasn‚Äôt making the kind of progress I wanted. I had the skills. The drive. But I was lacking clarity , direction , and momentum . That‚Äôs when I found Think and Grow Rich by Napoleon Hill. I didn‚Äôt expect a book from 1937 to shift how I thought about my entire career. But it did. üèÅ And it started with Chapter 1‚Äî Desire . Maybe you're in that place right now. üí™ You‚Äôre ambitious. üí™ Smart. üí™ Capable. But...you‚Äôre second-guessing your next move. You‚Äôre not sure what the right role is‚Äîor if the one you're in is even aligned. üö´ You‚Äôre busy, but not fulfilled. üö´ Moving, but not advancing. And it‚Äôs not your fault . Most career advice tells you to follow the next shiny title, build your r√©sum√©, or chase whatever‚Äôs trending in the job market. You‚Äôre told to "do more," ‚Äúbe realistic,‚Äù and ‚Äúwait your turn.‚Äù But that‚Äôs the problem. üö´ We‚Äôve been trained to work harder‚Ä¶ not to think deeper. üö´ We‚Äôve been taught to fit into a role‚Ä¶ not to design a life. ‚ö°Ô∏è The moment I stopped asking what should I do? and started asking what do I truly desire? That‚Äôs when everything shifted. Not just in my business, but in how I showed up‚Äîin my energy, my confidence, and the kind of clients and opportunities I attracted. You don‚Äôt grow your career by doing more. You grow by getting clear on what you want. üî• Overview: The 13 Principles of Think and Grow Rich üî• Napoleon Hill studied hundreds of the most successful people of his time and distilled their success into 13 principles . This book isn‚Äôt just about money. It‚Äôs about becoming the kind of person who creates success intentionally‚Äîwith clarity, purpose, and belief‚Äîfor your life, career, and financial freedom. The 13 Steps to Riches (and your dream life) are Desire Faith Auto-Suggestion Specialized Knowledge Imagination Organized Planning Decision Persistence Power of the Mastermind The Mystery of Sex Transmutation The Subconscious Mind The Brain The Sixth Sense Each of these applies to your career journey , and I‚Äôll be walking through all of them‚Äîone article at a time. üèÅ Let‚Äôs start at the foundation: Step 1: Desire ‚Äì The Starting Point of Career Success üî• Hill calls Desire the starting point of all achievement‚Äînot hope, not wish, not luck. A burning desire. Crystal-clear, all-in, uncompromising. In your career, that means this: You have to know what you want before you can attract it, create it, or get promoted into it. Most people skip this part. They stay vague: ‚ÄúI just want something better.‚Äù But vague desires produce vague results. Hill outlines six steps to turn desire into results. Let‚Äôs expand on those and apply them directly to your career: ‚úÖ 10 Career-Driven Ways to Apply Napoleon Hill‚Äôs Principle of Desire: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Get specific. What exactly do you want? Promotion? Pivot? Leadership role? Your own business? Name it. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Attach meaning to it. Why does this matter to you personally ? What would it change in your life? The moment you attach deep emotion to your vision‚Äîit becomes a MUST. And when it‚Äôs a MUST, your brain finds the way. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Decide what you‚Äôll give in return. Time? Focus? Learning? Growth? This is about investment, not sacrifice. It is time to invest in yourself. To commit fully. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Set a target date. When will this happen? ‚ÄúSomeday‚Äù is not a strategy. Imagine it was a year from now and you are looking back at the past year. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Create a career statement. ‚ÄúI will become a Director of Engineering by July 2025 and lead a high-impact global team.‚Äù I print mine out and put it on my vision board. Read it out loud daily. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Visualize it. See yourself doing the work. Feeling fulfilled. Living the life that aligns. Imagine the freedom it brings. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Write a simple plan. A roadmap that includes the next 3 actions you can take. Take daily massive imperfect action. 8Ô∏è‚É£ Cut the noise. Remove one obligation that doesn't align with your desire. Reclaim that energy. I like to call this my "not to do" list. What can you eliminate? 9Ô∏è‚É£ Surround yourself with belief. Join communities, follow leaders, and get mentors who reinforce what‚Äôs possible. Remember, you are who you surround yourself with. üîü Refuse to settle. Desire is only powerful when you back it with action and commitment‚Äîeven when doubt shows up. üöÄ Desire isn‚Äôt just the first step in growing rich and having the career and life of your dreams‚Äî It‚Äôs the first step in becoming fully aligned. Ready for the next step? In the next article, I‚Äôll break down Faith ‚Äîwhat Hill calls the power behind your belief‚Äîand how to use it to power every career move with confidence. üî• Until then, don‚Äôt chase titles. Chase what sets you on fire. üî• ‚ôª Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. ‚ûï Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment # leadershipdevelopment #worklifebalance #careeralignment #careerIlove #thinkandgrowrich #desire #dreamlife

name: avi-chawla
content: 9 MCP, Agents, and RAG projects for AI engineers: (covered with step-by-step code) 1) Build a multi-agent content creation system: - This project builds a multi-agent content creation system that is also exposed via APIs. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gRGe-eXM 2) Building efficient RAG systems with binary quantization: - Binary quantization is a simple yet effective technique that makes RAG up to 40x faster & 32x memory efficient! - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gKsWQaCE 3) Corrective RAG: - Corrective RAG (CRAG) introduces a self-assessment step of the retrieved documents, which helps in retaining the relevance of generated responses. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gZercxKY 4) Build a Reasoning LLM using GRPO: - GRPO is a reinforcement learning method that fine-tunes LLMs for math and reasoning tasks using deterministic reward functions, eliminating the need for labeled data. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gaS8Dety 5) Multiplatform Deep Researcher: - This project builds an MCP-powered multi-agent, multi-platform deep researcher; it can perform deep web searches using Brightdata's Web MCP server. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gakhf59K 6) Building a Browser Automation Agent: - The browser is still the most universal interface, with 4.3B pages visited daily! The project demos how to completely automate it with a local stack. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gq6k7RZn 7) Context engineering workflow: - LLMs aren‚Äôt mind readers. They can only work with what you give them. Prompt engineering primarily focuses on ‚Äúmagic words‚Äù with an expectation of getting a better response. - CE creates dynamic systems that offer the right info, the right tools in the right format. This ensures LLM effectively completes a task. - https://lnkd.in/ghAZgkFH 8) Build and deploy Agents to production: - This project builds and deploys a Coding Agent that can scrape docs, write production-ready code, solve issues, and raise PRs, directly from Slack. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gfpVVUPj 9) Building trustworthy Agentic/RAG workflows: - RAG systems often produce inaccurate/unhelpful responses. - This project shows how to use Cleanlab Codex to automatically detect and resolve RAG inaccuracies. - Learn here: https://lnkd.in/gVNHq8zQ ____ This post is a little preview of what we cover every day in our newsletter. Join here and get a free visual guidebook to learn MCPs from scratch (with 11 projects): https://lnkd.in/giEV5gkV ____ Find me ‚Üí Avi Chawla Every day, I share tutorials and insights on DS, ML, LLMs, and RAGs.

name: dharmesh
content: I've been experimenting with AI prompting techniques for years now (time flies!), and there's one useful technique that I'm genuinely surprised isn't more widely known. It's called "meta prompting," and it's simple: you ask the AI (like ChatGPT or Claude) to rewrite your prompt and make it better, giving it permission to ask clarifying questions that will make the prompt more specific. This technique works so well that I actually built a tool around it: Metaprompt.com . (The tool used some of the recommended techniques by OpenAI and used in their free developer-focused tool). How Meta Prompting Works (And Why It's Almost Magical) Let's start with a definition. What is meta prompting? Meta prompting is the practice of writing instructions that guide how an AI should interpret and respond to prompts , rather than just what answer to give. In other words, it‚Äôs prompting about prompting‚Äîsetting the rules, tone, or strategy the AI should use when generating responses. The concept behind Meta Prompting is simple but highly effective. Instead of struggling to write the perfect prompt yourself, you ask the AI to rewrite (optimize) your personally written prompt and make it better. You give it permission to ask any clarifying questions that will make the prompt more specific. You can do this manually with any system, but I found myself using this technique so often that I decided to build a dedicated tool for it: Metaprompt.com . Here‚Äôs how the tool works: Step 1: Write your initial prompt (even if it's rough or incomplete). I often start with a short sentence like "Write a research report on HubSpot". Step 2: Normally, you prompt the system to ask you questions about your prompt to make it more effective. Then it generates a series of questions for you to answer first. But if you use Metaprompt.com , the tool generates optimization questions for you automatically and presents them as simple checkboxes and dropdowns - no need to type lengthy responses. Step 3: Based on your selections, it creates an optimized prompt automatically, and you can either copy the optimized prompt, or run it with GPT-5 directly in the app. The difference in output quality when you use the tool is dramatic. A rough initial prompt gets you generic advice, while the optimized prompt gives the model far more context, getting you better responses with the right tone and specificity. What I love about turning this into a tool is that it makes meta prompting more accessible to anyone -- even to those just trying ChatGPT for the first time. No need to study prompting techniques or memorize frameworks, just click a few checkboxes and get better results immediately. It's a one-time investment, but a lifetime of value (if you use it for a prompt you use all the time). Why This Technique Deserves a Spot in Your AI Toolkit The whole craft of writing good prompts is known as prompt engineering, and it's been around for a while now. But most people find prompt engineering intimidating or overwhelming. Meta prompting solves that problem. It's a way for anyone -- even someone trying ChatGPT for the first time -- to immediately start getting better results without studying prompting techniques or memorizing frameworks. If you're a power user like me who interacts with AI multiple times per day, you won't always need to meta prompt because you develop an "AI intuition" for what works. But I do find myself using this technique often, especially when tackling something outside my usual use cases or I use a prompt frequently (as is the case when I'm writing prompts for an AI agent). What's particularly valuable is how meta prompting functions as a learning tool. By watching how AI systems restructure and improve your prompts, you naturally absorb what makes prompts more effective. You start noticing patterns: the importance of context, the power of specificity, the value of clear constraints and desired outcomes (more on all this later!). Over time, you'll find yourself writing better initial prompts because you've internalized these lessons. Happy prompting!

name: kpowerinfinity
content: Seventeen Years Today Capillary Technologies goes public. Seventeen years since three kids fresh out of college decided to start something in the wreckage of 2008. I wasn't there for the second half.. the harder half. Aneesh steered this ship through storms I can only imagine. I'm grateful beyond words. What I remember most isn't the milestones. It's the texture of those early days. Merchants in Kolkata who humored us when we had nothing. Durga Puja 2008, camped outside police headquarters chasing traffic updates. Pan IIT at IIT Madras where our scrappy SMS service caught fire. That first angel check of ‚Çπ15 lakhs from IIT Kharagpur that we paid back in crores. We had no idea what we were doing. Just energy, naivety, and this strange refusal to think small. Then Aditya Birla and Future Group said yes. Right after Lehman fell. I still don't know why they trusted us. The apartment in CV Raman Nagar with no water during the day. Chai walks in BTM Layout with Shubh , Abhilash , Prakhar , Piyush .. trying to figure out if we were building something or just fooling ourselves. Then loyalty took off. That first campaign‚Äî‚Çπ11 lakhs in incremental sales, one weekend, fully attributed. That's when we saw it. A chance meeting with Karthee at CCD led to the Qualcomm QPrize. We were shocked when we won. The business grew, but we stayed scrappy. That tiny hotel in Dadar because it was cheapest. The Bangalore home-office. The Gurgaon apartment where Ajay held the fort. Holed up in Bur Dubai searching for product-market fit. The exhilaration when Sequoia Capital and Norwest bet on us, alongside angels like Rajan , Venkat , KS , and Harminder . But what I really remember are the crazy things. Flooding someone in Gujarat with hundreds of thousands of texts. The new hire who nearly wiped our database on day one‚Äîlater led all of engineering (take a bow, Piyush ). Anant building a POS system on an Excel sheet to close a deal. Sujatha , our first female hire, making sure our office was no longer a dorm room. Building loyalty systems where internet barely worked‚Äîthe magic of "nightly sync." We were pirates, not professionals. That's what made it magic. Like humans, companies find their early years most thrilling. The teenage years? Brutal. But at seventeen, she's finally ready‚Äîscarred, wiser, infinitely stronger. We remember our failures more than our wins. We carry the scar tissue. But today, we celebrate. What a journey, Capillary family. What a journey.

name: kristen-kehrer-datamovesme
content: Asking questions can sometimes seem scary. No one wants to appear ‚Äúsilly.‚Äù But I assure you: You‚Äôre not silly. It‚Äôs way more scary if you‚Äôre not asking questions. Data Science is a constant collaboration with the business and a series of questions and answers that allow you to deliver the analysis/model/data product that the business has in their head. Questions are required to fully understand what the business wants and not find yourself making assumptions about what others are thinking. Asking the right questions, like those you identified here is what separate Data Scientists that know ‚Äòwhy‚Äô from folks that only know what (tools and technologies). -Kayode Ayankoya We‚Äôre going to answer the following questions: Where do we ask questions? What are great questions? I had posted on LinkedIn recently about asking great questions in data science and received a ton of thought provoking comments. I will add a couple of my favorite comments/quotes throughout this article. WHERE DO WE ASK QUESTIONS? Basically every piece of the pipeline can be expressed as a question: And each of these questions could involve a plethora of follow up questions. To touch the tip of the iceberg, Kate Strachnyi posted a great assortment of questions that we typically ask (or want to consider) when scoping an analysis: Kate‚Äôs questions spanned both: Questions you‚Äôd ask stakeholders/different departments Questions you‚Äôd ask internally on the data science/analytics team. Any of the questions above could yield a variety of answers, so it is imperative that you‚Äôre asking questions. Just because you have something in your mind that is an awesome idea for approaching the problem, does not mean that other people don‚Äôt similarly have awesome ideas that need to be heard an discussed. At the end of the day, data science typically functions as a support function to other areas of the business. Meaning we can‚Äôt just go rogue. In addition to getting clarification and asking questions of stakeholders of the project, you‚Äôll also want to collaborate and ask questions of those on your data science team. Even the most seasoned data scientist will still find themselves creating a methodology or solution that isn‚Äôt in their area of expertise or is a unique use case of an algorithm that would benefit from the thoughts of other data subject matter experts. Often times the person listening to your proposed methodology will just give you the thumbs up, but when you‚Äôve been staring at your computer for hours there is also a chance that you haven‚Äôt considered one of the underlying assumptions of your model or you‚Äôre introducing bias somewhere. Someone with fresh eyes can give a new perspective and save you from realizing your error AFTER you‚Äôve presented your results. Keeping your methodology a secret until you deliver the results will not do you any favors. If anything, sharing your thoughts upfront and asking for feedback will help to ensure a successful outcome. WHAT ARE GREAT QUESTIONS? Great questions are the ones that get asked. However, there is an art and science to asking good questions and also a learning process involved. Especially when you‚Äôre starting at a new job, ask everything. Even if it‚Äôs something that you believe you should already know, it‚Äôs better to ask and course-correct, than to not ask. You could potentially lose hours working on an analysis and then have your boss tell you that you misunderstood the request. It is helpful to also pose questions in a way that requires more than a ‚Äúyes/no‚Äù response, so you can open up a dialogue and receive more context and information. How we formulate the questions is also very important. I‚Äôve often found that people feel judged by my questions. I have to reassure them that all I want is to understand how they work and what are their needs and that my intention is not to judge them or criticize them. -Karlo Jimenez I‚Äôve experienced what Karlo mentioned myself. Being direct can sometimes come off as judgement. We definitely need to put on our ‚Äúbusiness acumen‚Äù hats on to the best of our ability to come across as someone who is genuinely trying to understand and deliver to their needs. I‚Äôve found that if I can pose the question as ‚Äúlooking for their valuable feedback‚Äù, it‚Äôs a win-win for everyone involved. As you build relationships with your team and stakeholders, this scenario is much less likely to occur. Once everyone realizes your personality and you‚Äôve built a rapport, people will expect your line of questioning. Follow up questions, in its various forms, are absolutely critical. Probing gives you an opportunity to paraphrase the ask and gain consensus before moving forward. -Toby Baker Follow-up questions feel good. When a question prompts another question you feel like you‚Äôre really getting somewhere. Peeling back another layer of the onion if you will. You‚Äôre collaborating, you‚Äôre listening, you‚Äôre in the zone. IN SUMMARY The main takeaway here is that there are a TON of questions you need to ask to effectively produce something that the business wants. Once you start asking questions, it‚Äôll become second nature and you‚Äôll immediately see the value and find yourself asking even more questions as you gain more experience. Questioning has been instrumental to my career. An additional benefit is that I‚Äôve found my ‚Äòvoice‚Äô over the years. I feel heard in meetings and my opinion is valued. A lot of this growth has come from getting comfortable asking questions and I‚Äôve also learned a ton about a given business/industry through asking these questions. I‚Äôve learned a lot about diversity of viewpoints and that people express information in different ways. This falls under the ‚Äúbusiness acumen‚Äù piece of data science that we‚Äôre not often taught in school. But I hope you can go forward and fearlessly ask a whole bunch of questions. Also published on KDNuggets: link Originally posted on https://datamovesme.com

name: ybernstein
content: I'm just starting my fourth week at Flare , a two-year-old startup with about 30 people, after a ten year career at Google which, with north of 40,000 employees and a market cap of half a trillion dollars, is definitively not a startup. Flare is awesome, by the way. A great team, great business plan, lots of interesting challenges, and a real openness to all perspectives on the best way to achieve our goals. Anyway. As part of getting started I decided to share some early observations about the software development process at the company. One of my slides had this diagram: What I had observed was that every company is on a journey, and for every step on that journey there is a "right" amount of process to have in place. Good processes (e.g. documenting what you do, or having approval checklists for product launches) allow your organisation to operate at a larger scale, build higher-quality and more complex systems, reduce risk, and increase predictability. Well-considered and well-implemented processes support teams and individuals in doing their jobs. However, processes come at a cost in terms of raw productivity and throughput, and in the early stages of a startup many of them are too expensive to implement or are simply unnecessary. When you're two ramen-fuelled developers in a basement, the right amount of process is "not much". When you're a globe-straddling mega-corporation, the right amount of process is "quite a lot". And of course, when you're starting out then "not much" is a natural default. If you're growing, then, generally the actual amount of process you have in place is going to trail the amount of process you need. I suspect the diagram above describes a large majority of successfully-growing startups. This "process lag" generally manifests in a certain degree of chaos, communication breakdowns, and dropped balls. This is often characterised as "growing pains". If you're in a role that is responsible for scaling and growing an organisation, what this means is that you're in the business of adding and refining process. Ideally, you get the red ball in the diagram above to catch up with the green ball, and then to keep up with it as your organisation goes on its journey. Knowing about good processes is something most experienced managers should not have too much trouble with. The art of it, and one that I look forward to learning, is how to roll them out at just the right pace that they are always supportive, never stifling.

name: danmoskowitz1
content: Everyone is excited about what AI can do. Fewer teams are honest about why their AI hasn't gone to production yet. Here is one of the clearer pattens that I've noticed. 1. Most companies aren't stuck on "does AI work?" They're stuck on "can this safely run in prod?" AI experimentation is mostly solved. The real bottleneck is everything that comes after the fancy demo: security, durability, and observability. That's the last mile where adoption stalls. 2. AI failures don't look like normal software failures. Also, the blast radius is potentially bigger. Model outages, silent hallucinations, prompt injection, general API weirdness that throws agents off. If you can't get a handle on these things, then it isn't safe to let your agentic workflow touch sensitive live data. 3. The next wave of AI value comes from infrastructure, not prompt engineering. The biggest winners in production will be teams that invest early in the tooling that makes agentic workflows secure, durable, and observable at scale. Not just better prompt chains that make great demos. üëá For more thoughts on this, read the full blog post in the comments. üëá Diagrid Mark Fussell Yaron Schneider Zenity Ben Kliger DataGrail Daniel Barber Kentik Avi Freedman

name: kristen-kehrer-datamovesme
content: Setting up your hypothesis test for success as a data scientist is critical. I want to go deep with you on exactly how I work with stakeholders ahead of launching a test. This step is crucial to make sure that once a test is done running, we‚Äôll actually be able to analyze it. This includes: A well defined hypothesis A solid test design Knowing your sample size Understanding potential conflicts Population criteria (who are we testing) Test duration (it‚Äôs like the cousin of sample size) Success metrics Decisions that will be made based on results This is obviously a lot of information. Before we jump in, here is how I keep it all organized: I recently created a google doc at work so that stakeholders and analytics could align on all the information to fully scope a test upfront. This also gives you (the analyst/data scientist) a bit of an insurance policy. It‚Äôs possible the business decides to go with a design or a sample size that wasn‚Äôt your recommendation. If things end up working out less than stellar (not enough data, design that is basically impossible to analyze), you have your original suggestions documented. In my previous article I wrote: ‚ÄúSit down with marketing and other stakeholders before the launch of the A/B test to understand the business implications, what they‚Äôre hoping to learn, who they‚Äôre testing, and how they‚Äôre testing. In my experience, everyone is set up for success when you‚Äôre viewed as a thought partner in helping to construct the test design, and have agreed upon the scope of the analysis ahead of launch.‚Äù Well, this is literally what I‚Äôm talking about: This document was born of things that we often see in industry: Hypothesis I‚Äôve seen scenarios that look like ‚Äúwe‚Äôre going to make this change, and then we‚Äôd like you to read out on the results‚Äù. So, your hypothesis is what? You‚Äôre going to make this change, and what do you expect to happen? Why are we doing this? A hypothesis clearly states the change that is being made, the impact you expect it to have, and why you think it will have that impact. It‚Äôs not an open-ended statement. You are testing a measurable response to a change. It‚Äôs ok to be a stickler, this is your foundation. Test Design The test design needs to be solid, so you‚Äôll want to have an understanding of exactly what change is being made between test and control. If you‚Äôre approached by a stakeholder with a design that won‚Äôt allow you to accurately measure criteria, you‚Äôll want to coach them on how they could design the test more effectively to read out on the results. I cover test design a bit in my article here . Sample Size You need to understand the sample size ahead of launch, and your expected effect size. If you run with a small sample and need an unreasonable effect size for it to be significant, it‚Äôs most likely not worth running. Time to rethink your sample and your design. Sarah Nooravi recently wrote a great article on determining sample size for a test. You can find Sarah‚Äôs article here. An example might be that you want to test the effect of offering a service credit to select customers. You have a certain budget worth of credits you‚Äôre allowed to give out. So you‚Äôre hoping you can have 1,500 in test and 1,500 in control (this is small). The test experience sees the service along with a coupon, and the control experience sees content advertising the service but does not see any mention of the credit. If the average purchase rate is 13.3% you would need a 2.6 point increase (15.9%) in the control to see significance at 0.95 confidence. This is a large effect size that we probably won‚Äôt achieve (unless the credit is AMAZING). It‚Äôs good to know these things upfront so that you can make changes (for instance, reduce the amount of the credit to allow for additional sample size, ask for extra budget, etc). Potential Conflicts: It‚Äôs possible that 2 different groups in your organization could be running tests at the same time that conflict with each other, resulting in data that is junk for potentially both cases. (I actually used to run a ‚Äútesting governance‚Äù meeting at my previous job to proactively identify these cases, this might be something you want to consider). An example of a conflict might be that the acquisition team is running an ad in Google advertising 500 business cards for $10. But if at the same time this test was running another team was running a pricing test on the business card product page that doesn‚Äôt respect the ad that is driving traffic, the acquisition team‚Äôs test is not getting the experience they thought they were! Customers will see a different price than what is advertised, and this has negative implications all around. It is so important in a large analytics organization to be collaborating across teams and have an understanding of the tests in flight and how they could impact your test. Population criteria Obviously you want to target the correct people. But often I‚Äôve seen criteria so specific that the results of the test need to be caveated with ‚ÄúThese results are not representative of our customer base, this effect is for people who [[lists criteria here]].‚Äù If your test targeted super performers, you know that it doesn‚Äôt apply to everyone in the base, but you want to make sure it is spelled out or doesn‚Äôt get miscommunicated to a more broad audience. Test duration This is often directly related to sample size. ( see Sarah‚Äôs article ) You‚Äôll want to estimate how long you‚Äôll need to run the test to achieve the required sample size. Maybe you‚Äôre randomly sampling from the base and already have sufficient population to choose from. But often we‚Äôre testing an experience for new customers, or we‚Äôre testing a change on the website and we need to wait for traffic to visit the site and view the change. If it‚Äôs going to take 6 months of running to get the required sample size, you probably want to rethink your population criteria or what you‚Äôre testing. And better to know that upfront. Success Metrics This is an important one to talk through. If you‚Äôve been running tests previously, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve had stakeholders ask you for the kitchen sink in terms of analysis. If your hypothesis is that a message about a new feature on the website will drive people to go see that feature; it is reasonable to check how many people visited that page and whether or not people downloaded/used that feature. This would probably be too benign to cause cancellations, or effect upsell/cross-sell metrics, so make sure you‚Äôre clear about what the analysis will and will not include. And try not to make a mountain out of a molehill unless you‚Äôre testing something that is a dramatic change and has large implications for the business. Decisions! Getting agreement ahead of time on what decisions will be made based on the results of the test is imperative. Have you ever been in a situation where the business tests something, it‚Äôs not significant, and then they roll it out anyways? Well then that really didn‚Äôt need to be a test, they could have just rolled it out. There are endless opportunities for tests that will guide the direction of the business, don‚Äôt get caught up in a test that isn‚Äôt actually a test. Conclusion Of course, each of these areas could have been explained in much more depth. But the main point is that there are a number of items that you want to have a discussion about before a test launches. Especially if you‚Äôre on the hook for doing the analysis, you want to have the complete picture and context so that you can analyze the test appropriately. I hope this helps you to be more collaborative with your business partners and potentially be more ‚Äúproactive‚Äù rather than ‚Äúreactive‚Äù. No one has any fun when you run a test and then later find out it should have been scoped differently. Adding a little extra work and clarification upfront can save you some heartache later on. Consider creating a document like the one I have pictured above for scoping your future tests, and you‚Äôll have a full understanding of the goals and implications of your next test ahead of launch. Originally posted on https://datamovesme.com

name: stephaniehillsphd
content: I once had a team of engineers who were stuck in a cycle of doing things ‚Äúthe way they‚Äôve always been done.‚Äù Every idea was met with ‚Äúthat won‚Äôt work‚Äù or ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt have time.‚Äù Sound familiar? I knew something had to change. So, I took a page from Amazon‚Äôs playbook. Their famous ‚ÄúTwo-Pizza Teams‚Äù ensure teams are small, agile, and empowered to innovate without bureaucracy slowing them down. I applied that concept‚Äîgiving my team the autonomy, tools, and confidence to experiment. The results? Ideas that had been buried under red tape came to life. Productivity soared. Engagement increased. Most importantly, we created solutions that made a real impact. üî• 10 Ways to Build a CULTURE OF INNOVATION in Your Team üî• 1Ô∏è‚É£ Empower Small, Agile Teams ‚Äì Keep teams small enough to be fed by two pizzas. Autonomy fuels creativity. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Encourage Risk-Taking ‚Äì Innovation thrives where failure isn‚Äôt punished but seen as a step toward success. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Implement a ‚ÄòDay 1‚Äô Mindset ‚Äì Never get comfortable. Stay in startup mode, always challenging the status quo. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Make Experimentation the Norm ‚Äì Have a budget for testing new ideas. Not every experiment wins, but all drive learning. 5Ô∏è‚É£ Remove Bureaucracy ‚Äì Long approval chains kill momentum. Enable teams to act fast. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Recognize and Reward Innovation ‚Äì Celebrate bold ideas, not just successful ones. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Listen to Your Customers ‚Äì The best ideas come from solving real problems. Be obsessed with their needs. 8Ô∏è‚É£ Lead by Example ‚Äì If leaders aren‚Äôt innovating, teams won‚Äôt either. Model the behavior you want to see. 9Ô∏è‚É£ Prioritize Speed Over Perfection ‚Äì Get ideas into the real world quickly. Iterate and improve based on real feedback. üîü Create Psychological Safety ‚Äì A culture of innovation starts with people feeling safe to speak up, take risks, and challenge norms. Innovation isn‚Äôt an event‚Äîit‚Äôs a habit. The best teams don‚Äôt wait for inspiration; they build systems that make innovation inevitable. Which of these actions resonates most with you? ‚ôª Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. ‚ûï Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. üöÄ #Innovation #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment # hashtag#careerfreedom hashtag#leadershipdevelopment #cultureofinnovation

name: davekrupp
content: I keep hearing that AI search is about to change everything. Maybe. But when I look at how younger consumers actually find products, the shift has already happened. OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT has scaled to 100M+ weekly users which of course is impressive. But most of that behaviour is task based and informational. On the other hand, TikTok has 1B+ monthly active users, and studies show roughly 40 percent of Gen Z prefer TikTok or Instagram for discovery over traditional search engines. If you work in FMCG or CPG, I think that‚Äôs the part that really matters. When someone searches ‚Äúbest chocolate‚Äù or ‚Äúhigh protein ice cream‚Äù on TikTok, they want taste tests, reactions, real people giving opinions. Not a neat AI summary. This is why I think food brands should be flooding TikTok with creator content - not for conversion but to own search inside the platform. Creator content indexes. It stacks over time. The more content you have out there, the more searchable your brand becomes in the moments that actually influence store purchases. AI search will evolve but right now social search is already driving buying decisions.

content: Last night, Certis was honoured to receive the esteemed ‚ÄúService Partner of the Year Award‚Äù at the Annual Changi Airport Celebration 2026 event. This recognition belongs squarely to our team members‚Äî the frontline officers, supervisors and support teams who show up every day with professionalism, resilience and an unwavering commitment to excellence. Operating in one of the world‚Äôs most complex and high‚Äëtrust environments demands consistency, discipline and heart. Our teams at Changi Airport embody all of that, delivering trusted outcomes while keeping passengers, partners and the airport community safe and moving. We are grateful to Changi Airport Group for the partnership and the confidence placed in us. As part of the ONE Changi initiative, we are proud to stand alongside the over 200 airport partners & agencies, and collectively collaborate together to uphold Changi‚Äôs global reputation. A special call out to our Service Operations Executive, Rowena Dorado, for winning the Silver Award in the Outstanding Service Staff of the Year category. To Alvin Lim and our Certis Aviation Security team ‚Äî thank you for your dedication & commitment. This award is a reflection of what you do, day in and day out üôè Ronald Poon Lee Hock Heng Zunjie Chong Daniel YONG #Certis #ChangiAirport #Partnership #ServiceExcellence #ProudTeam #SaferSmarterBetter

name: dharmesh
content: One thing that I wish I had learned earlier in my entrepreneurial career is this: Tools are bought, transformations are sold. Here's a clip of a talk I gave at the SaaStr Conference in San Francisco. First, let's talk about the difference? What do I mean by tools, and what do I mean by transformations? Tools Sometimes, the product you are selling is in a category that is well understood. Customers know the category, they know what other products are in that category, and they may previously have used another tool in the category. They don‚Äôt have to learn a ton to understand what the tool does. They don‚Äôt have to go through an existential crisis to adopt the tool -- it solves a specific problem, and can be implemented without having to rethink how they do things. Examples of tools are a to-do list app, or a time tracking system. I‚Äôm not saying that these products can‚Äôt be sophisticated or differentiated, what I am saying is that customers have a pretty good sense for what the product is going to do for them and why they might need it. Transformations Sometimes, the product you are selling is transformational . Adopting it requires customers to rethink all or parts of their business. Often it requires rethinking their career . It requires transformational change. Example: The ‚Äúinbound marketing platform‚Äù HubSpot was selling in our early years. The premise of our product was: ‚ÄúThe way you‚Äôve been doing marketing is fundamentally broken and doesn‚Äôt work as well anymore. You‚Äôre going to have to do it very, very differently. Our product can help.‚Äù Convincing professional marketers that all the things they had spent their careers doing (and getting good at) was less relevant now (like buying lists, putting up a booth at a tradeshow, etc.) was not an easy thing to do. We were asking for a transformative change in their thinking. It's hard to change. Convincing someone else to change is even harder. Tools Are Bought, Transformations Are Sold If you‚Äôre selling a tool, you might be able to put a great website up, explain what your product does, perhaps contrast it to other tools in the market, tell customers the price and provide a way for them to buy it. Easy-breezy. If you‚Äôre selling a transformation, a website is not going to be enough. If you‚Äôre asking someone to make a massive change to how they do things, you‚Äôre going to likely have to sell . First, you‚Äôll have to sell them on the reason why change is necessary. Without making that sale, you‚Äôre not going to be able to sell them on your particular product. So, if you've got a transformational product, you're likely going to need sales people to sell it. Not ones that have aggressive sales tactics and worry about how quickly they can close -- but ones that know that the prospective customer has to be sold on the change first before you can even start to have a conversation about the product. Tips On Selling A Transformative Product If ever there was a time you needed marketing, this is it. You need to tell the story of how the world has changed and what companies need to do to leverage the change (or at a bare minimum, adjust to it). When it comes to recognizing the need for change, you don‚Äôt have to go it alone. Chances are, there are other companies that also benefit from the particular change you are advocating (just like there were many companies pushing for ‚Äúinbound marketing‚Äù when HubSpot first got started. Work with other companies (even if they‚Äôre competitors) to spread the word, and increase the size of the pie. As you build a base of ‚Äúconverts‚Äù that are aligned with how you see the world, work to pull those people into a community . Help them connect to each other. Support them in their efforts. Recognize their achievements. When hiring sales people, remember that you need people that can help teach people about the change. Why it‚Äôs important. What happens if they don‚Äôt make the change. Without first convincing the customer that change is necessary, it is impossible to sell them on your product. If you start with ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù sales people that are only interested in selling the product, you are unlikely to be successful. In the early days/weeks/months, recognize that your customers are likely going to need a lot of hand-holding and help. It will feel uncomfortable, because there‚Äôs a voice in your head telling you ‚Äúthis won‚Äôt scale‚Äù. The voice is right -- it won‚Äôt. But you still need to do it right now . For those early customers, you have to go as far as you need to in order to help them be successful. You can worry about scaling later. If you have so many customers that you can‚Äôt afford to give them the same level of help anymore, that‚Äôs a high quality problem. Much better problem to solve than ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have anybody that‚Äôs really succeeded with our product yet.‚Äù It's easy for people to buy a tool. Buying into a transformation is a journey. Help guide them, and pack some snacks.
