name: stephaniehillsphd
content: The Painful Reality You wake up dreading Monday. You sit in meetings, watching the clock, counting the hours until Friday. The paycheck is good, the work is fine, but deep down, you know‚Äî this isn‚Äôt it . You tell yourself it‚Äôs too late to switch careers. That stability is more important. That you should be grateful. But here‚Äôs the hard truth: staying in a job you don‚Äôt love is the biggest risk of all‚Äîbecause one day, you‚Äôll run out of time. My Leadership Journey From researcher to software engineer to engineering manager to program manager to technology executive to coach and consultant... I have worked in academia, as a defense contractor in the Pentagon, and in companies from small 100+ employees to 2 Fortune 500 companies and eventually launched my own business. What has held true throughout is that my passion is helping others, mentoring, teaching‚Ä¶To see an engineer or executive or team grow, find their passion, and succeed in what they love is what drives me. When I mentor or coach someone, the first thing I ask is ‚ÄúWhat is your Passion?‚Äù? Why Your Career Should Align with Your Passion Here‚Äôs why doing work you love isn‚Äôt just a luxury‚Äîit‚Äôs a necessity: üîπ You‚Äôll perform better ‚Äì When you love what you do, you naturally excel at it. üîπ You‚Äôll be more fulfilled ‚Äì No more Sunday night anxiety or counting down to retirement. üîπ You‚Äôll make a bigger impact ‚Äì Passion fuels persistence, and persistence drives success. üîπ You won‚Äôt regret the years ‚Äì Time is the one thing you never get back. üöÄ Tools & Surveys to Discover Your Passion & Ideal Career Path Instead of just saying "Follow your passion," use science-backed tools to uncover what actually excites and energizes you . üî• 1 Ikigai Framework: The Japanese Secret to Finding Purpose Instead of thinking "What do I love?" ‚Äîuse the Ikigai framework to find the intersection of ‚ùì What You Love (Passion) ‚ùì What You‚Äôre Good At (Talent) ‚ùì What the World Needs (Impact) ‚ùì What You Can Be Paid For (Sustainability) üëâ Try This: Draw 4 overlapping circles for these categories and write in answers for each. Your Ikigai is the sweet spot in the middle. üìñ Book: Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life ‚Äì H√©ctor Garc√≠a & Francesc Miralles üî• 2 The "Sparketype" Assessment: What Truly Energizes You? The Sparketype Assessment (by Jonathan Fields) helps you discover the type of work that makes you come alive. üîπ Primary Sparketype: Your core driver (e.g., The Scientist, The Advisor, The Maker) üîπ Shadow Sparketype: A secondary work style that complements your primary. üëâ Take the Free Test Here: https://www.sparketype.com/ üìñ Book: Sparked: Discover Your Unique Imprint for Work That Makes You Come Alive ‚Äì Jonathan Fields üî• 3 The VIA Character Strengths Test: Your Superpower at Work This scientifically validated test from positive psychology helps you find your top strengths‚Äîso you can align your work with what makes you feel naturally confident and fulfilled . üëâ Take the Free Test Here: https://www.viacharacter.org/ üìñ Book: The Power of Character Strengths: Appreciate and Ignite Your Positive Personality ‚Äì Ryan Niemiec & Robert McGrath üî• 4 The ‚ÄúRegret Minimization Framework‚Äù ‚Äì Jeff Bezos' Decision-Making Hack Instead of stressing about ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the perfect career?‚Äù ask yourself: üìå "At 80 years old, will I regret NOT doing this?" If the answer is yes , it‚Äôs time to act. üìñ Book: Invent & Wander: The Collected Writings of Jeff Bezos üî• 5 Take Action: What‚Äôs Your Passion Score? Ask yourself these three innovation-driven questions : ‚ùì When do I feel fully energized and in flow at work? ‚ùì If I had financial security , what would I spend my time doing? ‚ùìWhat‚Äôs something I can spend hours learning about and never get bored? What‚Äôs Next? Now that you truly understand your passion take these next steps! ‚úÖ Explore the Market ‚Äì How can you monetize your strengths? What careers or business opportunities align with them? ‚úÖ Start Small, Test the Waters ‚Äì Don‚Äôt quit today‚Äîstart learning, networking, or even side hustling first. ‚úÖ Take the Leap ‚Äì When you‚Äôve built a foundation, go all in. Your future self will thank you. Whether it is in another role at your current company, working for another company, or starting your own business, you should wake up every day excited for the day ahead! If you feel like you‚Äôre meant for more , you probably are. Don‚Äôt settle. You have one life‚Äîmake it count. üí¨ What‚Äôs stopping you from pursuing a career you love? Drop your thoughts below. #CareerChange #DoWhatYouLove #CareerGrowth #WorkWithPurpose #PassionAndSuccess

name: patrick-szymkowiak
content: The migration to the cloud is still difficult if you have a low internet access or no internet access. In this case you have to do on premise architecture. Microsoft has the good idea to unify the public cloud and the on premise world with azure stack. In this new feature of Microsoft we could create a small azure on premise. the benefit is to create the same application for any region, any country public or on premise. We can also migrate legacy applications to a new azure architecture and stay on premise. As a result it will be easier to sell solutions for on premise or public cloud on the azure market place. Here the list of azure stack features: azure stack white paper azure stack datasheet azure stack website

name: ybernstein
content: Ownership is a state of mind. It is a fire in your belly. Ownership drives a laser focus on delivering valuable outcomes for the business. Autonomy and accountability both factor into this. Set lofty goals, work hard to come up with an optimised plan, demand the autonomy and resources needed to achieve those goals. Advocacy to leadership is a key part of having ownership. Things that individuals and teams with a true sense of ownership have: A sense of urgency. All your work counts for nothing until it is delivering value. Therefore, a true sense of ownership also drives a sense of urgency. Teams with a sense of ownership can‚Äôt wait to start delivering value to their users and their business. This impatience should drive a ruthless desire for efficiency within the team, a bias towards delivery, and a hunger for learning. However, a sense of urgency does not and should not mean burning oneself out, nor does it mean taking damaging shortcuts. High expectations of each other. Your team‚Äôs success is your success, and your team cannot succeed unless all functions are doing their jobs well. Therefore having low expectations of others is equivalent to having low expectations of yourself. Teams with a sense of ownership generate ‚ÄúGood‚Äù pressure. Bad pressure comes from outside the team. Bad pressure causes stress and fatigue. Bad pressure is a crushing force and makes a team smaller . Good pressure comes from inside a team, and makes it bigger . It creates energy and motivation, a sense of agency. Think of a balloon, or a tyre. Pressure from within is what allows them to take shape and perform their job. Without pressure they are flaccid and useless. A sense of ownership generates good pressure. Owners escalate frequently. Teams that are driven to deliver value do not tolerate obstacles that stand in the way of doing so. Those that they can remove themselves, they remove themselves. Other obstacles are escalated to their leaders for swift resolution. Obstacles come in many forms: under-resourcing, lack of clarity, missing context, inability to reach a decision, and more. Teams that own see it as their duty to bringing those obstacles to the attention of those who can remove them. They understand that otherwise they are not doing their jobs. Justified conviction in their course of action. A team with a sense of ownership knows the best plan to achieve valuable outcomes in their domain. They know this because they are the world experts in their area of the product, and have the data to justify their beliefs and convictions. Because of this, they are not diverted easily. They are open to feedback and questions from company leaders, but more often than not they defend their position because they know more and have thought more about their domain that their leaders have.

name: marinawu
content: Earlier this week I said yes to a dinner where I had zero clue who'd be on the guest list üòÖ As someone who gets a little nervous about social events, walking into a room of potential strangers isn't exactly a hell yeah every time. But the organiser Nathaniel Diong üöÄ was someone I'd seen in the LinkedIn-verse for years but we'd just never had the chance to actually meet so may as well go. Turns out it was the best kind of surprise. A mix of old friends and new ones, founders, VCs, social entrepreneurs all around the same table What made it special wasn't just who was there, it was how Nathaniel ran it. The "We're Not Really Strangers" conversation prompts that completely changed the energy. A few of us got to shoutout our parents and share a bit about them (genuinely wholesome ü•π), and we even got an impromptu Bob Dylan performance Big networking events have their place. But curated, intimate dinners with thoughtful conversation? That's where you skip the surface level stuff and get to the real person behind the LinkedIn profile Shoutout Nathaniel Diong üöÄ for putting this together and to everyone around the table for making it such a great night ü§ù When's the last time saying "yes" to something unexpected paid off for you? üëÄ

name: stephaniehillsphd
content: We all have dreams, goals, and aspirations‚Äîbut how often do we delay taking action? Years ago, I had big ambitions to start my own business to help others in their career. I found myself stuck in a cycle of overthinking. I kept telling myself, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start when I‚Äôm ready.‚Äù But ready never came. Instead, weeks turned into months, and months into years. Opportunities slipped away‚Äînot because I lacked ability, but because I hesitated. Sound familiar? Maybe you‚Äôve been meaning to launch that business, apply for that leadership role, or start building your personal brand. But something keeps holding you back‚Äîthe fear of failure, the endless search for the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù time, or the voice in your head whispering, ‚ÄúWhat if I‚Äôm not good enough?‚Äù The real enemy? Procrastination. It disguises itself as preparation and perfectionism , but in reality, it‚Äôs just a thief stealing your future. It keeps you comfortable but costs you progress. It convinces you that tomorrow is better‚Äîbut tomorrow never comes. üî• Here‚Äôs the truth: Success doesn‚Äôt wait for you to be ready. The most successful people take action before they feel prepared. They move despite the fear. They build momentum, one imperfect step at a time. If you want to change your life, start today. Not tomorrow. Not someday. Now. Take one step forward, no matter how small. Send that email. Make that call. Start that project. üö® 3 Easy Ways to Beat Procrastination & Take Back Control Every Day ‚úÖ The 5-Minute Rule ‚Äì If a task feels overwhelming, commit to doing it for just 5 minutes. Action kills anxiety. Once you start, the resistance fades, and you‚Äôll feel the relief of progress instead of the guilt of delay . ‚úÖ Future Pain vs. Present Pain ‚Äì Ask yourself: How will I feel if I don‚Äôt do this? Imagine the regret, stress, and frustration of staying stuck. Now flip it‚Äîpicture the confidence, momentum, and freedom you‚Äôll feel when it‚Äôs done. Choose progress over regret. ‚úÖ Make It Public ‚Äì Tell someone your goal. Accountability forces action. When you follow through, you gain pride and self-trust instead of the shame of broken promises to yourself . üî• Every time you delay, you make the pain of inaction stronger. But every time you act, you widen the gap between your old, stuck self and your new, unstoppable self . üî• Procrastination is the assassination of your destination. Action ends anxiety‚Äîmove now, win later. üî• üí° What are your procrastination hacks? ‚¨áÔ∏è

name: samueltyang
content: Excited to share some big news: I've joined Diagrid as President! I'm excited to step into this leadership role at the forefront of Agentic AI, helping enterprises move from AI experimentation to production. Diagrid is building the most trusted platform making AI agents and complex workflows truly durable, secure and resilient at scale. Powered by Open Source #dapr project, Diagrid Catalyst enables developers to orchestrate autonomous agents with multi-step reasoning and highly reliable agent execution without the underlying distributed systems complexity. A huge thank you to Diagrid founders ( Mark Fussell and Yaron Schneider ) and the entire team for the trust and opportunity. I'm honored to join at this pivotal moment. I'm looking forward to connecting with builders, enterprises and leaders in AI infrastructure, agentic systems and distributed applications. If you're working on scalable AI agents, durable workflows or intelligent systems at scale, let's chat! #Diagrid #AgenticAI #Catalyst #Dapr #AWS #GCP #Azure #Agents

name: robertroskam
content: Many of us software engineers got into this field because we preferred the rigid predictability of machines. We prefer the dialog with the machines via code. But your code involves people at every stage. A person wrote the ticket. A person will review your pull request. A person will use it. A person will maintain it after you have moved on. Even the code you write alone on a side project is a conversation with your future self. You can try to fight this reality. Treat meetings as a waste of time. Bristle at code reviews you get and rubber stamp every one you give. Treat user complaints as largely edge cases. Some engineers do this their entire career. The code is not the work. It is part of it, but not all of it. The work is always with other people, though. Always.

name: tom-fanara-2553326
content: After a period of reflection, I‚Äôve decided it was the right time for a transition. The role had evolved in a direction that no longer aligned with the architecture, systems thinking, and platform‚Äëbuilding work I‚Äôm most energized by. I‚Äôm grateful for the experience and proud of what was accomplished. I‚Äôm now shifting my focus to the next chapter ‚Äî including a robotics‚Äënative platform I‚Äôve been developing that addresses a meaningful gap in the market. I‚Äôm excited for what‚Äôs ahead and open to conversations, collaboration, and new opportunities that align with my strengths in technical architecture, modular systems, and platform strategy.

name: abidalee
content: ‚ÄòAn empty vessel makes the loudest sound‚Äô -- Plato Knowledgeable people are often humble and consider themselves the least knowledgeable among others. Such people have the benefit of learning the most from others. To the contrary, people who believe they know it all, lose a greater opportunity to learn from others. It is necessary to ‚Äòlisten‚Äô more than ‚Äòtalk‚Äô. We can never learn enough as the learning continues a life time. Unfortunately, we live in a competitive world and the life around us is constantly evolving. Several new things are invented every day. In order to play along the competition, it is necessary to stay abreast of the new trends and emerging technologies. We should ‚Äòstay hungry and foolish‚Äô as it helps in acquiring the new knowledge. ‚ÄòConstantly re-inventing self‚Äô means we should learn new things but also ‚Äòunlearn‚Äô the things which are obsolete, as it will create room for new learning. Sometimes past knowledge is useful, while other times, it can hinder the acquisition of the new knowledge. We should, therefore, ‚Äòempty our minds, be formless, shapeless, like water, water can flow, water can crash‚Ä¶‚Äô , and, ‚Äòkeep on moving as the running water never goes stale.‚Äô #ParwaazTheFlight #LightACandle #FightTheDarkness Web: http://parwaaztheflight.org Facebook: www.facebook.com/ParwaazTheFlight Twitter: https://twitter.com/ParwazTheFlight YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCgAstmkdXHxq7i40qVRYPsw Let's 'light a candle', the candle of 'kindness', the candle of 'hope', the candle of 'love and affection', and the candle of 'knowledge and wisdom', to 'fight the darkness', the darkness 'within and around.'

name: caseybhawkins
content: üî• TOP 5 HUBSPOT UPDATES FROM FEBRUARY 17, 2026 üî• We're back! A few days off from the show and HubSpot dropped twenty-four updates on us. Chris had some technical difficulties getting the stream going this morning, George and I held it down for about 30 seconds, and then we were off to the races. Twenty-four updates is a LOT to cover, and honestly? Picking just five was tough. There are some heavy hitters in this batch. Here's what made the cut, but check out the blog for the full breakdown on all twenty-four. Here's what dropped: ‚öôÔ∏è Add Line Items to Deals via Workflow Actions (Request Beta) This one is huge. You can now select a product from your library, set a quantity, and automatically attach line items to deals when a workflow fires. No more manual deal setup or custom-coded actions. Chris called out that this replaces a ton of custom code people have been maintaining, and he's right. üëâ Request beta: https://hubs.li/Q043nyLv0 üéØ Conditional Scoring with "and" for Lead Scores AND Health Scores (Live) Finally. Scoring rules now support compound "and" criteria, so you can award points only when multiple conditions are met. I've been waiting for this one. One caveat: the "and" rules are within a single action type right now, so cross-object conditions (like form submission + job title) still need a list or workflow. But this is a major step. üëâ Learn more: https://hubs.li/Q043nwPb0 üìã Enhanced Multi-Step Form Logic (Beta) New hide and show step-level actions let you dynamically control which steps visitors see based on their responses. Skip to Step is deprecated, and if all remaining steps get hidden, the Submit button surfaces automatically. George's reaction: "Getting pretty powerful over there with the forms." üëâ Join beta: https://hubs.li/Q043nry20 üîÑ Workflow CRM Property Data Restore (Beta, Enterprise) If a workflow accidentally updates thousands of records with the wrong value, you can now undo those changes within fourteen days. Built on HubSpot's unified backup system. This is the safety net ops teams have needed. üëâ Join beta: https://hubs.li/Q043nyTW0 üîç Granular Filter Insights in Segments (Beta) You can now see exactly how each filter shapes your segment as you build it, in real time. Zero-match filters get flagged. No more saving, checking, tweaking, saving again. üëâ Join beta: https://hubs.li/Q043nw650 The theme today? Confidence. Scoring with precision, building segments with transparency, restoring data after mistakes, and automating deal setup without manual cleanup. The tools are getting smarter AND safer. Which update are you testing first? Catch Chris Carolan, George B. Thomas, and me live weekdays at 8:30am ET on LinkedIn, or on Apple or Spotify. #HubSpot #HubSpotUpdates #HubSpotCRM #Automation #CRM #WakeUpCustomerPlatform

name: dharmesh
content: There's a big mistake I make as a public speaker. It's a mistake I think many amateurs make that the pros usually don't. The mistake is that I'm hesitant to reuse and refine content/messages I've used in prior talks. I feel like I need to create fresh, never-before-shared content for every speaking gig. But, that's not the right way to go about it. If you're solving for the audience (which you should be), then ask yourself what would be most useful/impactful. Trying a new set of messages/content for each audience, or refining and iterating on the most important messages you have and making those better? I think there's power in repetition and refinement. Keep polishing the message and the idea so it's easier to absorb, easier to apply, easier for others to share. That's a much better use of time than trying to just conjure up new material every single time. Also, the audience is never the same, even if it's exactly the same people a few months later. Even if your material hasn't changed they have likely changed and it's not a waste of their time to hear some parts again. They may see things from a different perspective. Professional speakers and standup comedians make their material better and better with each iteration. Impact is not always about novelty and newness. It's sometimes about weaving in the right nuance.

name: stephaniehillsphd
content: I had COVID. And it hit hard. Not just physically‚Äîbut mentally and emotionally. Six weeks of being down and out. And even when I ‚Äúrecovered,‚Äù I didn‚Äôt feel like myself. Covid fatigue lingered. Some days I felt great. Other days, just walking around felt like a win. But in the stillness, something powerful happened‚Ä¶ ü§î I had an epiphany. I wasn't going to let COVID win, yet I didn‚Äôt want to just get back to how things were. Because how things were wasn‚Äôt really working. My life before was full. Busy. ‚ÄúSuccessful.‚Äù But it was all about doing . Checking boxes. Managing everyone else‚Äôs needs. But never really putting myself first, my needs, my MUSTS. Always productive‚Äîbut rarely present. And I realized: I had been leaving myself out of my own life. üò± ‚ùìIs this you? üö´ You‚Äôre always ‚Äúon.‚Äù üö´ You show up for everyone‚Äîbut barely for yourself. üö´ Your to-do list runs your day. üö´ You move fast, but never feel fulfilled. üö´ You feel guilty if you pause. üö´ But exhausted if you don‚Äôt. üö´ You keep thinking you‚Äôll get to you‚Ä¶ later. üö´ But later never comes. Because you‚Äôve been wired to serve, succeed, and survive. Not to slow down , heal , or be . And here‚Äôs the problem... The world praises overachievers. üö´ We applaud people who grind through fatigue. üö´ We normalize skipping sleep, numbing emotions, and ‚Äúpowering through.‚Äù But no one talks about how that lifestyle eats away at your health, your joy, and your identity‚Äîuntil something forces you to stop. Until your body says no more. Until your mind can‚Äôt focus. Until your soul feels distant. We‚Äôve been conditioned to hustle through the warning signs. To believe rest is weak. To wear exhaustion like a badge of honor. üí™ What I decided instead? That moment when I realized I had been leaving myself out of my own life changed me. I decided I wasn‚Äôt going back to the old version of my life. üéâ I wanted to live with intent. üéâ To be present ‚Äîfor myself, for my sons, and for the life I still had ahead. So I rebuilt my days from a new foundation. Not around urgency. But around alignment . üî∫ The Wellness Triangle: My New Non-Negotiable I returned to the basics, the things that really matter: üß† Mind üèãÔ∏è‚ôÄÔ∏è Body üå± Soul ‚úÖ Every day, I nourish all three: Mental Priming to clear my thoughts and set my intention Pilates + Cardio to strengthen and energize my body Hydration ‚Äîwater, water, water Eating Healthy ‚Äîwhole foods, no processed oils, plant-based proteins, smaller meals Presence ‚Äîtruly showing up with the people I love Gratitude, Faith, and Joy ‚Äîbecause my soul needs nourishment too Then I zoomed out even further... üå± The 7 Elements of a Fulfilled Life Once I rebuilt my foundation around the Wellness Triangle ‚ÄîMind, Body, and Soul‚ÄîI realized there was more to balance than just personal health. Living with intention means being present and on purpose in every part of life that matters. ‚ùìI thought, what are the elements of my life that really matter? Here are the 7 core elements where you can show up, engage, and experience fulfillment . These are the areas where we invest our time, energy, and heart. ‚úÖ And while you might not give all of them equal time every day, you can make space for them all consistently. 1. Relationships / Community ü§ù Quality time, emotional presence, & love. This is where connection lives. The people we care about. The ones we show up for‚Äîand who show up for us. 2. Work / Career / Mission üíº Meaningful impact that aligns with your purpose. We all want to build something that matters. Fulfillment comes when your work reflects your values and your gifts. 3. Health & Energy üí™ Movement, nourishment & feeling your best. This is the fuel that powers everything. It‚Äôs not about perfection‚Äîit‚Äôs about feeling strong, energized, and well. 4. Faith / Spirituality üôè Trust, gratitude & connection. This is your inner compass. Whether it‚Äôs through faith, prayer, or quiet reflection‚Äîit‚Äôs what keeps you grounded in something deeper. 5. Growth & Learning üìò Curiosity, growth & becoming your best. When we grow, we feel alive. Stretching your mind and expanding your skills keeps life exciting and evolving. 6. Giving üåç Helping others, paying it forward with heart. Whether it‚Äôs mentoring, supporting, or simply showing up‚Äîgiving is how we live beyond ourselves. 7. Fun & Adventure üéâ Laughter, travel & joy. Play matters. So does exploration. Make space for what makes you feel alive. ‚Üí When these 7 elements are honored‚Äînot perfectly, but intentionally‚Äîyou begin to feel aligned. Not pulled in every direction. Not surviving, but thriving . üî• Final Thoughts ‚ú® It‚Äôs not about balance. It‚Äôs about making space for what truly matters.The life you want isn‚Äôt found in the hustle‚Äîit‚Äôs built in the balance. 1Ô∏è‚É£ Be WELL . Honor your mind. Care for your body. Feed your soul. ‚ù§Ô∏èü©π 2Ô∏è‚É£ FULFULL all the areas of your life, Relationships/Community, Work/Career/Mission, Giving, Fun & Adventure, Growth & Learning, Health & Energy, Faith & Spirituality üéâ This changed my life. This is the foundation of everything. Let‚Äôs stop just doing. And start living with intention. ‚ÅâÔ∏è Are you living a WELL and FULFILLED life? üöÄ I challenge you to make just one change a week and watch your joy skyrocket! ‚ôª Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. ‚ûï Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment #balancedlife #fulfilledlife #worklifebalance #dreamlife

name: dalianaliu
content: Only 1% of LinkedIn users post regularly. 99% are missing out on opportunities because "self-promotion" sounds like a dirty word. They worry colleagues will judge them. That friends will roll their eyes. That their content will be met with silence‚Äîor worse, ridicule. So what? Those people aren't your audience anyway. Even if 99% ignore your post, but just 1% find it useful or inspiring, you're making an impact. You're planting seeds for future opportunities. You don't need a huge audience to attract high-quality opportunities ‚Äî you just need the right people to discover your unique perspective: ‚Ä¢ More visibility in the job market ‚Ä¢ Conference speaking invitations ‚Ä¢ A potential customer base for future ventures Even if you want to "self-promote," there's nothing wrong with that. You worked hard for your achievements. Share what makes you proud! Here's the truth: if you only care about your image, you'll fail at this. The best "self-promotion" benefits others: ‚Ä¢ Explaining complex concepts in plain language ‚Ä¢ Sharing unique opinions that help others avoid mistakes ‚Ä¢ Being vulnerable about struggles that make people feel seen and understood Remember this: you'll never fully live your own life while obsessing over what exists only in other people's minds. Worried nobody will read your post? That fear is normal. Most content gets minimal engagement at first. But what if one person reads it and wants to work with you? That single connection could change everything. Your voice matters. The world needs your unique perspective, and someone out there is waiting to hear exactly what you have to say. --- Want to build your personal brand in 2026? I've distilled *everything* I've learned from building an audience of 300K into a 90-min live course. name: kristen-kehrer-datamovesme
content: I often see similar questions in my inbox or asked in webinars. I‚Äôd like to set the record straight with data. However, I didn‚Äôt need to start from scratch, there was an excellent article on KD Nuggets by Jeff Hale. Here is the link to his article: ‚ÄúThe Most in Demand Skills for Data Scientists‚Äù. He had already scoured multiple job search site and aggregated data on the demand for different skills for data scientist. I recreated some of his analysis myself, so that I could come up with some points for this article, and to make sure his numbers matched mine before posting. The charts I created below are based on data from searches on indeed.com only. A search for ‚ÄúData Scientist‚Äù was the denominator, and the numerator would be ‚ÄúData Scientist‚Äù plus another term I was looking to see results for. I‚Äôm not sure how many job descriptions listed on indeed.com might be duplicates, so this is not gospel, but still interesting. This article will cover a couple of ‚ÄúFrequently Asked Questions‚Äù using the methodology above (that was adopted from Jeff). Questions I‚Äôm frequently asked: Should I learn R or Python? As a Computer Science major, can I get into data science? How important is SQL? Should I learn R or Python? This would most likely be the most frequently asked question (although I‚Äôve never analyzed the questions that I‚Äôm asked). In Jeff‚Äôs article, you were able to see that Python has the edge in terms of coming up in job listings. I recreated the methodology for myself to look at this a little further. 55% of the job listings actually list both tools, as in the company would like to see that you have experience with ‚ÄúPython and/or R‚Äù. That should make those who have a preference for one tool feel better. If you‚Äôre looking to pick up either R or Python and you‚Äôre just getting your hands dirty, I‚Äôd suggest python. For listings that only specify one tool, Python is almost 5x more likely to be listed as the tool of choice compared to R. I was happy to see this, as I‚Äôve mentioned in a number of webinars and comments on social media that it ‚Äúfeels like‚Äù Python is slightly more popular. It would have been a bummer if I had been giving misinformation this whole time. % of Data Science Positions Mentioning a Particular Skill on Indeed.com Pulled this data by doing a search on indeed.com 11/2018 As a Computer Science major, can I get into data science? I‚Äôm always surprised when I see this question, because as someone who‚Äôs been in the field for a long time, it just seems clear that this is a fantastic skill as your foundation for moving into data science. Data science requires a number of different skills to be successful, and being able to program is definitely one of the core pillars. Analytics and Statistics are coming in first, but Analytics and Statistics could easily be mentioned somewhere in the job description other than specifically where preferred degrees are mentioned. If a job description says ‚Äúcomputer science‚Äù they‚Äôre most likely speaking to the degrees they would prefer from candidates. More than 50% of job descriptions mention ‚Äúcomputer science‚Äù. There you have it, a degree in computer science is something ‚Äúin demand‚Äù for getting into data science. % of Data Science Positions Mentioning a Particular Skill on Indeed.com Pulled this data by doing a search on indeed.com 11/2018 How important is SQL? I‚Äôm frequently asked this question, and I was honestly surprised that SQL came in third behind Python and R in terms of skills. However, 51% of jobs do mention SQL. So it is certainly desired for the majority of positions, but I expected it to rank higher. Is it possible this skill is becoming assumed as a prerequisite? Or are companies figuring that SQL is easily learned and therefore not necessary to list on the job description? I wouldn‚Äôt mind a job where all the datasets were aggregated for me before data cleaning and applying machine learning, I‚Äôm just not sure how many of those jobs exist. If you‚Äôre a data scientist, and you haven‚Äôt had to understand relational databases at any point, let me know. I‚Äôd love to hear about it. Conclusion: We saw that Python is preferred over R, but that either tool will allow you to apply to the majority of data science jobs in the US. Computer science degrees are a great stepping stone to getting into data science, and the majority of listings will expect you to know SQL. I also want to point out that ‚Äúcommunication‚Äù was very much in the top list of skills. 46% of job descriptions listed communication in the job description. This means I‚Äôll continue to keep writing about how I use softer skills to be effective in my job. I think we sometimes do not talk about communication enough in data science, it‚Äôs really imperative to delivering models and analysis that are aligned with what the business is looking for. If you‚Äôd like to see how Jeff used the data from the job search websites to discuss most in demand skills, here is the link one more time. Link. Originally posted on https://datamovesme.com

name: stephaniehillsphd
content: When I was in my tech exec role, I looked successful on paper. Big title. Big team. Global projects. But deep down? I felt boxed in. Meetings that didn‚Äôt matter. Metrics that didn‚Äôt move me. And a constant tug in my chest that whispered, ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt it.‚Äù I kept asking myself, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the next role?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat promotion should I chase?‚Äù But every step up just felt like more pressure‚Äînever more purpose. Until I stopped chasing the next title‚Ä¶ And started designing the life I actually wanted. You don‚Äôt start reevaluating their career because you have a 10-step plan. You do it because you're done . üò± Done feeling stuck. üò± Done being overlooked or underpaid. üò± Done living on someone else‚Äôs schedule. üò± Done wondering, ‚ÄúIs this really it?‚Äù You don‚Äôt always know what they want next‚Äî You just know: Something has to change. So you start searching‚Ä¶ ‚û°Ô∏è You scroll LinkedIn. ‚û°Ô∏è You update your resume. ‚û°Ô∏è You ask ChatGPT: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the best career to go into in 2025?‚Äù And the internet answers: ‚ùóÔ∏èGo into tech. ‚ùóÔ∏èTry product management. ‚ùóÔ∏èStart consulting. ‚ùóÔ∏èBecome a coach. ‚ùóÔ∏èGet certified. ‚ùóÔ∏èPivot to AI. Whatever‚Äôs trending this week. So you pick something. ‚úî Apply for roles. ‚úî Maybe even get promoted. ‚úî Land the job. But a few months in? That old feeling creeps back in. üò± Still stuck. üò± Still unfulfilled. üò± Still not living the life you imagined. You changed the job... But not the approach. Here‚Äôs why that happens: Because you started with the wrong question. You asked: ‚ÄúWhat role will get me ahead?‚Äù Instead of: ‚ÄúWhat kind of life do I want‚Äîand what path gets me there?‚Äù One leads to the next title. The other leads to long-term freedom, growth, and purpose. Because the right next move? Isn‚Äôt always a new job. It‚Äôs not always a promotion. And it‚Äôs definitely not whatever the algorithm is pushing. üî• It‚Äôs alignment. üî• Between who you are and how you show up in your work. Your career isn‚Äôt just a ladder. It‚Äôs a vehicle . A way to create the life you want to live. But you have to know what that life looks like first. So instead of asking: ‚ÄúWhat should I do next?‚Äù Start asking: ‚ÅâÔ∏è How do I want to wake up every day? ‚ÅâÔ∏è What kind of work energizes me? ‚ÅâÔ∏è What kind of problems do I love solving? ‚ÅâÔ∏è What kind of people do I want to work with? ‚ÅâÔ∏è What would my career look like if it bent around my life‚Äînot the other way around? Because once you answer that‚Ä¶ ‚ö°Ô∏è The clarity shows up. ‚ö°Ô∏è The right roles become obvious. ‚ö°Ô∏è The growth becomes sustainable. ‚ö°Ô∏è And the fulfillment becomes real. Not because you followed the trend‚Äî But because you followed your truth. So what‚Äôs it going to be? Another title that looks good on paper but leaves you drained? Or a path that gives you the IMPACT, FREEDOM, MEANING you‚Äôve been craving? üí™ Once you choose you , you get to choose everything else. Why did I write this? I‚Äôve been hearing from so many professionals lately‚Äî People who are brilliant, capable, experienced‚Äî But stuck in decision loops. Debating between titles. Overthinking every option. Trying to guess what will finally feel right. But clarity doesn‚Äôt come from a job title. It comes from you . So I wrote this to shift the conversation. Back to what actually matters. So you stop building your career from pressure, comparison, or ‚Äúshoulds‚Äù‚Ä¶ And start creating from alignment, purpose, and real inner clarity. Because that‚Äôs where the momentum lives. That‚Äôs where the MAGIC happens. üí´ Need a place to start? ‚úÖ Try this: ‚ÄúRemind Me Who I Am‚Äù Career Prompt (ChatGPT) ‚ÄúAct as a motivational coach who helps people get clarity‚Äînot by telling me what to do, but by helping me remember who I am. Guide me through a powerful reflection to reconnect with: üî∑ What I actually want from life üî∑ What kind of work lights me up üî∑ The kind of days I want to live üî∑ What I‚Äôve been afraid to admit I want üî∑ What kind of role I‚Äôd pursue if I stopped chasing approval and started trusting myself Ask me deep questions, push past surface answers, and reflect back what you see in me‚Äîand what‚Äôs possible if I stop playing small.‚Äù üöÄ Your next move isn‚Äôt in a job board. It‚Äôs in YOU. Let‚Äôs start there. ‚ôª Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. ‚ûï Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment # leadershipdevelopment #worklifebalance #careeralignment #careerIlove

name: stephaniehillsphd
content: Back in college, I waited tables to make ends meet. I was fast, sharp, and proud of how I handled things under pressure. But one day, I noticed the other waitresses whispering. I finally asked, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up? Why are y‚Äôall always talking about me?‚Äù One of them looked me straight in the eye and said: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre really smart. But every time something goes wrong, you make excuses instead of owning it.‚Äù üò± That hit me hard. They were right. I thought being smart meant I always had an answer. But smart isn‚Äôt the same as being a problem solver . üëâ Ever been in that position? üëâ When things go wrong, do you explain‚Ä¶ or do you take action? üëâ Do you try to protect your ego, or do you focus on fixing the problem? The truth is‚Äî your value isn‚Äôt always in what you know. It‚Äôs in how you solve problems. From that day forward, I changed how I showed up‚Äîat work, in life, in leadership. I became solution-focused, and it completely shifted my growth trajectory. üî• 10 Steps to Become a World-Class Problem Solver üî• 1Ô∏è‚É£ Own the problem. Don‚Äôt blame. Don‚Äôt deflect. Take responsibility, even if it‚Äôs not entirely yours. Be the "top cover" for your team to own the problem with the "buck stops here" attitude. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Stay calm in the crisis. Emotion clouds judgment. Leaders breathe, then lead. Your emotional temperature sets the environment for the rest of the team. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Listen and Learn. Talk to the people closest to the problem‚Äîyour team, your customers, your peers. Listen deeply to better understand the issue and collaborate for the best solutions. When problems together, the team owns the solution. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Define the root cause. Most people solve the symptom, not the root. Ask ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù five times. Also ask, what can we do to prevent this from happening again or how can we make it better? 5Ô∏è‚É£ Break it down. Large problems become manageable when you split them into steps. 6Ô∏è‚É£ Get curious, not critical. Replace judgment with questions. ‚ÄúWhat can we learn?‚Äù opens doors. 7Ô∏è‚É£ Use constraints to create clarity. Limited time or resources can lead to the most innovative ideas. 8Ô∏è‚É£ Communicate clearly. Great problem solvers explain the issue and the solution simply. As Einstein said "If you can't explain it simply, you don't understand it well enough." 9Ô∏è‚É£ Take fast action. Don‚Äôt wait for perfect. Move forward with a clear direction and adjust as you go. üîü Reflect and Pivot. What worked? What didn‚Äôt? Build a playbook for next time. ‚ö°Ô∏è Smart people know the answers. Problem solvers create the outcomes. ‚ö°Ô∏è ‚ÅâÔ∏è What is your tip to be a "world-class" problem solver? ‚ôª Repost to encourage your network to inspire others. ‚ûï Follow me ( Stephanie Hills, Ph.D. ) for more like this. #freedomseekers #careerfreedom #leadershipdevelopment # leadershipdevelopment #cultureofinnovation

name: tian-beng-ng-b3886a32
content: While the sun was rising this morning at 6.30am, our frontline officers were already up and ready to serve. At the Certis East Coast Deployment Centre, the early morning buzz was a familiar sight - purposeful, focused, and full of quiet determination. On the eve of Lunar New Year, it felt especially meaningful to drop by to distribute oranges, extend my festive greetings to our officers and to thank them for their service. Many of them will be on duty throughout the public holidays, steadfast and vigilant as always. Deeply grateful for the dedication of our frontliners, who continue to serve with professionalism and pride, rain or shine, day in and day out üôè. Honoured to wish them well as they head out to perform their duties, keeping Singapore safer, smarter, and better for all. Zunjie Chong Jackie Ong Raymond Poh Sing Ling Chua (IHRP-SP) Julian Chee

name: sam-coyle
content: üöÄ New Release ‚Äî Dapr Agents v0.11.0 is live on PyPI! This release continues our focus on developer experience, observability, and maintainability, while keeping quickstarts and dependencies up to date. üîç What‚Äôs new in v0.11.0: - Improved OpenTelemetry tracing with HTTP client instrumentation and MCP spans - New AGENTS.md to better document agent structure and concepts - Quickstart fixes to align component naming and configs - Refactored agent internals to use composition over inheritance - Ongoing dependency and tooling updates across Python, uv, and key libraries - DX cleanup: removed tox, deprecated code, and simplified setup v0.11.0 continues the push toward simpler agent APIs, better observability, and easier long-term maintenance. üëâ Full release notes: https://lnkd.in/dU2jVrk2 #Dapr #OpenSource #AI #MultiAgent #DeveloperExperience #Observability #Python #DaprAgents

name: davidlowjw
content: It‚Äôs been a fun but honestly pretty hectic past two weeks. I just wrapped up the AI Telco RCA challenge[1], travelled to Bali for my nephew‚Äôs wedding, and unexpectedly found myself reliving memories of my own Bali wedding 14 years ago. Somewhere in between all that, I was also honoured to be named one of the "Top AI Leaders to Watch". Thank you #Traicon and #AIRevolutionSummit for the recognition. Still feels a bit surreal. All this somehow made me reflect on my own ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù journey. It started early last year when I saw Andrej talking about vibe coding on X. Out of curiosity, I jumped in. First starting with a ChatGPT, then GitHub Copilot, and eventually Cursor AI IDE. I was actually quite an early Cursor user. To the Cursor folks who reached out for feedback‚Ä¶ sorry, I never got back to you. Work has been intense, and I‚Äôve mostly been using it for side projects. Those side projects turned out to be pretty fun though. I built crypto trading algos (intra-minute and swing trading), a web app that generates 3D models for my wife‚Äôs 3D printing business, and eventually used vibe coding to join the Zindi challenge to build a telco RCA LLM. Naturally, the conversation has shifted from if AI Agents can replace coders to when that might actually happen. Sam Altman has even suggested that we may soon see a one-person startup reaching unicorn status powered entirely by AI agents without hiring a single human. As an AI/ML practitioner, that sparked my curiosity to explore whether AI agents could perform my work autonomously. I decided to use the Zindi challenge as a litmus test. Short answer is No. Not yet. But here‚Äôs the teaser. It did help us get into the top 10 on the leaderboard in one of the track. I‚Äôll share more in a follow up post on how I vibe coded my way there, where LLMs really shine, and where the real bottlenecks still are. At this point, I don‚Äôt even think of it as ‚Äúcoding with vibes‚Äù anymore. It feels more like working with a trusted, experienced software engineer who can brainstorm with you and execute exactly what you have in mind. [1] The AI Telco Troubleshooting Challenge - https://lnkd.in/gyTA2Gce

name: theango
content: I just put my own money into this company. 254 AI-enabled apps per company. 1% consider their deployment "mature." Everyone else is spending seven figures and hoping. Fluency raised $6M to show you how work actually happens across every workflow and application so you can see which processes are ready for AI, what are broken, and prove the ROI on what you deploy. Deploy in hours. Real insights by end of day. And yes, they have opened a speakeasy office in SF because apparently that's a thing now. If you're a exec trying to figure out where to invest in AI, or a cracked engineer in SF who wants to work on workflow intelligence, come have a drink with this team DM me, I'll intro you.

name: dharmesh
content: One thing that's been on my mind a lot lately: Is a purely chat-based interface the optimal UI for humans to work with AI? As much as I love natural language interfaces provided by ChatUX, there are many use cases where there are better, more efficient ways to interact. I think the future is going to be about hybrid, fluid UI. A combination of chat and other more "classic" UI that we're used to. Here's what I'm experimenting with as a very rudimentary approach to incorporating some "classic" UI into a chat interface: Expose the ability for the LLM to request user inputs (of varying kinds) as "tools" or (functions). This ability for LLMs to use tools is a Very Big Deal -- but in most cases, we're using these tools to do back-end integrations, call APIs and access data. But we can take tool use much further. We can give LLMs tools that allow human input. For example, if the LLM needs to get a date from the user, it uses the tool to get that input, and we show an inline UI control for the user to enter a date. That control could allow natural language input (next Monday) or a popup calendar. Similarly, we could support all the UI primitives that are common (text input, dropdown selection, etc.) Not the fanciest of UIs, but even with the basic primitives, there's a lot we can do. And, I like how it keeps orchestration power in the hands of the LLM and lets it worry about when human input might be required and a way to get it. Over time, we could expand that model with more powerful UI controls (grids, visualizers, image editors, etc.) I can also conceive of a way to get human input asynchronously (for longer-running tasks). For example we could have a "send_user_approval_link_by_email". This would send the user an email with a link to approve/continue the agentic workflow. There are likely much better ways to blend the UI, but this one has the value that it could actually be implemented by mere mortals like me, and it would be a step in the right direction.

name: vanessaong1
content: 4 years at Kong ‚Äì what an incredible ride! ü¶ç It is hard to believe how quickly time flies. What started as a simple curiosity about open-source connectivity turned into a four-year journey filled with hard work, laughter, and genuine joy. Today, I‚Äôm closing this chapter with a heart full of gratitude. I have decided to take a deliberate pause to reset and reflect before the next adventure begins. To my Kong family, both past and present: THANK YOU. I am lucky to grow up a bit alongside all of you :) You have been so much more than colleagues; you have been my community. I will be cheering you all on from the sidelines as you continue to soar to even greater heights üöÄ üöÄ üöÄ David Carless Richard Koh Joe Eskenazi Gunjan A. name: dharmesh
content: This article is based on a talk I gave at HubSpot's annual INBOUND event (in 2017, we had 21,000+ people!). Full video and slides of my talk are embedded below. Full Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0yqJa48ebs (I think you'll find it entertaining) I learned this from a late night dinner while glamping with Elon Musk many years ago "Every person in your company is a vector. Your progress is determined by the sum of all vectors." - Elon Musk I didn't fully understand this at first, so I had to go digging in my brain for what I could recall of linear algebra. Once I pieced together what he meant, the impact was profound. I later shared this lesson with my team at HubSpot. HubSpot is about 14 years old now and I've spoken at countless "all-minds" gatherings (our version of an "all-hands"), written hundreds of articles and otherwise tried to share things I've learned with everyone. Of all the things I've shared, this "aligning vectors" idea is one of the lessons that has resonated the most. It "stuck". It has become part of our vocabulary and not a week goes by that I don't hear some reference to it in the halls of HubSpot. What's A Vector? In order to understand why aligning vectors is so important, we first need to understand (or remember) what a vector is. A vector is a quantity having both magnitude and direction . Every Person Is A Vector Now, let's say you have someone in your company that is a 9/10 on the competency/impact meter. They are clueful and committed. They're one of your best. Now, that impact score in and of itself does not make them a vector. Because the impact score is just a magnitude. It measures the strength/power/impact. But, there's no direction specified. We don't know which way this particular person is moving themselves or the company. It's what would be known as a scalar -- not a vector. Now, let's say we did know which direction this person was moving. Then, we'd have both magnitude and direction and they become a vector. This is commonly represented as an arrow. Now, imagine if there are four people in your company, and for simplicity, let's assume they all have an impact score (magnitude) of 9. These are what you might call your "A players" or "Star Performers". And, let's assume we know which direction each of them was moving in. What goals they're solving for. Which point they're trying to move to. Since we know their magnitude and direction, they're all vectors. This is what Elon meant when he said "everyone in your company is a vector". Sum Of All Vectors In linear algebra, it is possible to add two or more vectors together and get a resulting vector. The resulting vector is based on the magnitude of each vector being added and their direction . So, if we considered each person in the company as a vector, we could add them up, get a sum of all vectors and represent that sum with a single, new vector. That new vector is basically the direction and momentum your company is moving. Every person is a vector -- and them all up, and you know how much progress your company is going to make. Let's illustrate with a few simple examples using our four hypothetical team members. Scenario 1: The Null Vector Let's say that two of your people are pulling in one direction and the other two are pulling in the opposite direction. In this case, the sum of those four vectors is what's called a null vector . A null vector has zero magnitude and no direction. So, in our example, the company would be making zero progress. It's important to note that this is despite all four of the people being high-impact, competent people. In fact, they could all have been 10/10s (they're perfect!) and the result would still be zero. If you have perfect people and they're perfectly misaligned, the result is zero progress. Scenario #2: Sup-optimal Of course, that doesn't really happen in real-life where two or more people are moving in the opposite direction. That's just a hypothetical, right? This would never happen in our organizations, would it? Let's assume not. Let's look at a more realistic example. What's more common is that most people are pulling in the "correct-ish" direction, (except for that one person -- there always seems to be that one person). But, the sum of all vectors here is not zero, but it's also not the optimal possible vector. The resultant vector is not 36 units of impact pointed in the correct direction. This is better, but it's still not optimal. Scenario #3: Aligned Vectors (The Holy Grail of Alignment) The optimal answer is to have all the vectors aligned . That is, everyone is moving in the correct direction towards a unified goal. That's how you have maximum impact and how you make maximum progress . Add up all all the vectors and the magnitude of impact is actually 36. Nothing is being wasted, there's no inefficiency, there is no one pulling in the wrong direction, this is what we should be all striving for. This is what ‚Äú aligned vectors ‚Äù looks like. Now that we have an understanding of what "aligning vectors" means, let's dig in. Applying "Aligning Vectors" to Your Organization Although in the examples used, we're talking about aligning individual people with the organization's goals (so that everyone is pulling together in the right direction), that is just one of three broad areas. Here are the vectors that need to be aligned: Align people with the organization's goals. Aligning individual teams (product, marketing, sales, service, etc.) with the organization's goals. Aligning the organization's goals with the needs of the customer . The third one is one that a surprising number of organizations lose sight of. The people and teams are working together but they're solving for the wrong thing . They should be solving for the customer -- but instead, they're solving for internal tactical goals that lose sight of what the customer actually wants and needs. How Aligning Vectors Can Help Project Planning If you're like most organizations, you have a list of "projects" (or initiatives) somewhere. If you're good, you try to measure how well those projects are doing. What we started doing at HubSpot is looking at projects that are not going well and asking ourselves these two questions: Is the magnitude of investment in this project sufficient for what we want to accomplish? If not, we have a magnitude problem. We need more investment (more resources). Are the people and other related projects aligned with this one (and vice-versa)? If not, we have a directional, alignment problem. We need clearer direction, better communication and readjustment/realignment of vectors. Going through this exercise is often very revealing. Sometimes, it's shockingly obvious that we have a magnitude problem and other times it's obvious that we have an alignment problem. It's Vectors All The Way Down I've now become obsessed with vectors. It's vectors all the way down. Ever piece of content your marketing team produces is a vector. They should all be aligned. The partnerships you forge should be aligned vectors. It's just not just about magnitude (i.e. how big is the company you're partnering with), but how aligned is the partnership with both of your respective goals. If you're raising funding, don't just solve for deal terms (maximum valuation, minimum dilution, etc.) -- but figure out which investor is the best aligned with the kind of business you're trying to build. That will likely have a much larger impact on your outcome (and your happiness) than whoever offers the most money or highest valuation. How To Increase Progress Without Better People Or More Funding And, here's the thing that I found the most startling about this whole thing. It's profoundly simple. Assume you had to hold everything else constant -- no new people, no "upgrades" to the skills of existing people and no additional funding. Even then, you can still improve your rate of progress and level of success by better aligning your vectors . You can make more progress with the amazing people you already have simply by better aligning their vectors. We should pause and reflect on that for a moment -- because it means that all us have hope. We can be better. We can accomplish more. We can have more impact. We are not dependent on more money or smarter people. We can go further and have more impact by aligning vectors. The team that gets 80% of the decisions "right", but is 100% aligned will beat the team that gets 100% of the decisions right, but is only 80% aligned. So, what do you think? Would love to read your feedback and thoughts in the comments. I read all of them (but can't respond to all of them).

name: matthewsharp
content: The build vs buy dichotomy isn't new. AI is shifting the dichotomy toward build, but there are still plenty of reasons to buy. That said. If you are going to go with a vendor, at least use it's unique features. I've seen this a lot, a team goes through a procurement process, chooses a tool based on it's capabilities and pats themselves on the back. In the meantime, the engineers in charge of delivering the tool will avoid using some of the vendor specific features. There's lots of good reasons for it. Wanting to avoid lock in, make it easier to switch to a different vendor later, etc. This gives them the greatest flexibility to opt out easier later, but from a business perspective, why?!? I've seen this a lot when it comes to databases. A company goes all in on Redshift, BigQuery, Vertica, ClickHouse or some other tool, only to strip it of all it's features and run it like it's Postgres. Why are you paying extra and not taking advantage?!? It's like going to an all expense resort or cruise and eating sack lunches from home instead of at the provided buffet. If you want to avoid going through a door you can't back track out of, there are still ways to avoid the vendor lock in, but don't be paying for features you aren't using. Just hemorrhaging money.

name: laurennicoleryan
content: Campaigns in HubSpot vs Salesforce has been a 'hot topic' for many many years. They're not the same. They function differently. .... but A product update landed in my inbox this morning that may have changed that narrative a bit. First - no they're still not the same and no they still don't sync in the native integration (you create custom objects for Salesforce Campaigns in HubSpot & map them - so you can sync that data BUT it's still not a 1:1 campaign sync between HubSpot & Salesforce üòâ) BUT HubSpot users migrating from Salesforce have long wondered when they can add contacts to a campaign manually or via automation & see a list of campaigns they're a part of. It looks like a Public Beta is now doing just that! With this beta you can: 1. Bulk associate a contact to a campaign 2. Manually associate from a record page 3. Manually associate from the campaigns tool 4. View contact campaign interactions 5. Add contacts to campaigns via a workflow action ü§Ø üëâ My takeaway here is that HubSpot is revisiting the fundamentals to further stake their claim as a true data-first, AI-powered customer platform. And that means revisiting the functionality that made it the leading marketing platform to ensure all aspects of GTM (even offline) are fully accounted for. name: dharmesh
content: Confession time : every company on Planet Startup claims they ‚Äúlove their customers.‚Äù Cute. But love, like that gym membership you bought in January, is only impressive if you actually use it. So how do you turn that warm, fuzzy feeling into a full‚Äëblown, bonafide super‚Äëpower? Three progressively powerful levels await you. Ready? Cue the video‚Äëgame soundtrack. LEVEL 1: Good, Clean Living This is Customer Feedback 101‚Äîthe spinach of business. ‚Ä¢ NPS surveys? Yes, please. ‚Ä¢ Follow-ups to customer support issues? Fantastic. ‚Ä¢ Bug hunts and feature wish lists? Like Pok√©mon, gotta catch ‚Äôem all. If you‚Äôre not doing any of this, stop reading, go do it, then come back. I'll wait ‚Ä¶ (Jeopardy theme plays softly.) LEVEL 2: Better, Cleaner Living Now we widen the lens from ‚Äúproduct‚Äù to ‚Äúexperience.‚Äù Ask questions like: ‚Ä¢ Was pricing easy to find, or did it require a secret decoder ring? ‚Ä¢ Talking to Sales: pleasant chat or dental surgery without anesthesia? ‚Ä¢ Do your invoice emails read like a friendly note‚Äîor a ransom letter? ‚Ä¢ When customers change jobs, do they smuggle your software into the new gig like contraband coffee? If you‚Äôre gathering intel at this level, congrats‚Äîyou‚Äôve unlocked the ‚ÄúCustomer Experience Nerd‚Äù badge. LEVEL 3 (Boss Level): It‚Äôs Not About You (Plot Twist!) Here‚Äôs where most companies wimp out. Collecting feedback is still you‚Äëcentered: ‚ÄúHow can we polish our product? How can we fatten our revenue?‚Äù Important, sure, but not transcendent. Instead, zoom into the customer‚Äôs hopes, dreams, and 3 A.M. anxieties. Ask: ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúHey, how‚Äôs life treating you?‚Äù (Yes, seriously.) ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWhat monster problem keeps you caffeinated past midnight?‚Äù ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWhat would make you look like a rock star at your next all‚Äëhands meeting?‚Äù Why bother? Because customers are people too (plot twist #2). And people who feel known become fans, not just fleeting users. That‚Äôs the difference between a handshake and a high‚Äëfive. ‚ÄúBut Dharmesh,‚Äù you protest, ‚Äúdoes this scale?‚Äù Nope. And that‚Äôs fine. Talk to 100 customers; extract one blinding insight; build something nobody else saw coming. That‚Äôs venture‚Äëgrade ROI right there. A close to home example: At HubSpot we don‚Äôt just build software; we try to build careers. (Software is lines of code. Careers are lines of destiny‚Äîway cooler.) So our questions aren‚Äôt limited to ‚ÄúWhich button color converts best?‚Äù We also ask, ‚ÄúHow do we help Sarah in Sales become Sarah the CEO someday?‚Äù That mindset has served us better than unlimited office snacks (which we also have)‚Äîand that‚Äôs saying something. The Takeaways (Because Every Article Post Needs Some) Success is about turning customer love into a super-power. Do the basics. Then do the better basics. Then do the human stuff that isn‚Äôt on anyone‚Äôs KPI dashboard (yet). Do that, and your relationship with customers will stop being a polite handshake and start looking a lot more like a superhero cape‚Äîbillowing dramatically in the updraft of shared success. And if you're really looking to be supercool, start learning about AI agents and see how they can help create better customer connection. I (of course) recommend starting with agent.ai . Cape still optional, but you're going to feel like you deserve one.

name: avr27
content: In my previous post , I shared a higher level understanding of NMT(Neural Machine Translation) architecture. So, continuing from there: With the same context of language translation, let's see how different aspects of it work together. On a higher level, we have 4 major components: Embedding Layer - vector(numerical) representation of text data Encoder - that which understands the source language and condenses the patterns learned into what we call context/thought vector. Context Vector - the summarized representation of source language produced by the encoder Decoder - which is responsible for decoding the context vector into the desired translation. Let's connect the dots b/w the embedding layer, the encoder, the context vector, and the decoder: We use two-word embedding layers, one for the source language and the other for the target, to better represent the semantics b/w the words of the respective languages. The encoder is responsible for generating a thought vector or a context vector representing what the source language means. The encoder is an RNN cell. At time step t_0, the encoder is initialized with a zero vector by default. After finally getting trained on the sequence of source sentences/words, It produces a context vector, which is it's final external hidden state. The context vector's idea is to concisely represent a source language sentence. Also, in contrast to how the encoder‚Äôs state is initialized (i.e., it is initialized with zeros), the context vector becomes the initial state for the decoder. This links the encoder and the decoder, making the whole model end-to-end differentiable. The decoder is responsible for decoding the context vector into the desired translation. Our decoder is an RNN as well. The context vector is the only piece of information that is available to the decoder about the source sentence. Thus, it is a crucial link b/w encoder and decoder. After getting initialized with the context vector as its initial state, the decoder then learns the patterns in the target text. Though it is possible for the encoder and decoder to share the same set of weights, it is usually better to use two different networks for the encoder and the decoder. This increases the number of parameters in our model, allowing us to learn the translations more effectively. For the prediction, we use something like the softmax function to predict the words. The full NMT system, with the details of how the GRU cell in the encoder connects to the GRU cell in the decoder and how the softmax layer is used to output predictions, is shown: We can also add Attention Mechanism to our decoder, which I briefly discussed in my previous post . In brief, adding attention to the decoder implies that it allows the decoder access to the encoder's state in order to learn more about the source sentence. In my next post, I'll discuss in more detail about "Attention Mechanism" and why the context vector is not sufficient to produce good quality translations. BTW, if you are interested in learning more about this, here is my very in-depth notebook on this topic, explaining the concepts and code implementation in great detail. üîóGitHub Link: Seq2Seq Learning - Implementing NMT System

name: ybernstein
content: It's easy to be busy: it simply means that you're doing lots of stuff. Being productive, though, is about delivering value and is much harder: to be productive you have to make sure all the work you're doing is valuable , and minimise waste and unnecessary work. To put it another way: busy people do many units of work; productive people focus on delivering large amounts of value per unit of work. So, how can you make sure you're being productive as a software engineer? Understand the context of your work. You cannot be productive if you don't know the reason for the work you're doing. You must go further than simply plucking tickets from a queue and doing what they say. Remember, you're not building software for the sake of it; you're building a product and a business. Know your product and you'll make better decisions while you're building it. Design your software. Software development is not primarily about coding; it's about designing software systems. Coding is the bit that happens once you have come up with a high-quality design. If you don't take the time to make plans and get input from your colleagues, you will make errors that introduce bugs and technical debt. Having discussions and writing documentation to capture your plans is not a waste of time. It's a key part of your job of a software engineer. It may not feel like it, but this will save you time in the long run. Question everything. Ask "why?" a lot. It's amazing what you'll learn, and the ways in which this will help you do things right the first time. Rigorous scrutiny and debate is a hallmark of a top engineering culture. Always be respectful, but never hesitate to subject things to scrutiny. Be lazy. The best way to do a piece of work efficiently is to avoid doing it at all! Is there an existing tool or feature that you can use? Can you reframe the problem so that a much less costly solution does the job? Is this whole thing even worth doing at all? Always ask the questions. Your time is a valuable resource, it is your responsibility to make sure it's being used efficiently.

name: tian-chong-ng-76739216
content: 2024 Look Back LinkedIn Article Looking back at 2024, it‚Äôs been an incredible year filled with many global events that captured attention. We saw the rise of ChatGPT, which continues to help many people discover their hidden potential, countries coming together to triple climate finance for developing nations to better support their efforts, and on a fun note, the debut of breakdancing at the Summer Olympics that took the world by storm. For me, three themes stood out for business: digital transformation, evolving cyber threats and growing sustainably. Transforming the way we work, live and interact Singtel has come a long way since achieving nationwide 5G coverage in July 2022. We‚Äôve been unlocking many new features such as network slicing so enterprises can exploit the technology to build new apps, operate more efficiently and enhance their customer engagement experiences. It‚Äôs exciting to see how network slicing and other 5G capabilities are being used across sectors like healthcare for surgical planning using augmented and mixed reality applications, advanced manufacturing to assemble cars or check for defects in products, and so much more. 3D visualisation of organs via mixed- and augmented-reality applications That‚Äôs not all. By tapping on the huge volumes of data we process through our networks, we‚Äôre able to develop Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) that can be used to tailor solutions that meet the unique needs of businesses. For instance, we can use APIs to build security apps that detect and mitigate threats in real time, enable seamless integration of payment systems, or even test and deploy multilingual communication platforms. This makes it easier for enterprises and developers to have the tools to create truly personalised and powerful digital experiences. And for greater impact, we‚Äôve been forging global alliances to explore APIs in a range of areas like security, 5G, and customer service. We‚Äôre developing a global first multilingual telco-specific large language model (LLM) with other leading telcos Deutsche Telekom, e&, and SK Telecom, as well as SoftBank that can be applied worldwide, democratising AI in the region. These advancements are not just transforming industries but impacting everyday lives. Tackling Cyber Threats Another game-changer is AI which has brought new opportunities for business innovation and growth as well as challenges like evolving scams and cybersecurity risks. This year, we rolled out many AI-enabled measures to enhance our scam prevention capabilities. One proud achievement is the development of SingVerify that leverages telco data to perform authentication in real time. It‚Äôs all done in the background and more importantly, provides an additional layer of defence from scams and fraud. But for this to be truly effective, we need to include all the local telcos and we‚Äôre working on that. In tandem, we‚Äôve taken this initiative regional by deploying it in Malaysia and Thailand. Through our efforts, we‚Äôre protecting over 57 million customers in these markets. By federating the telco APIs more telcos can protect their customers from digital fraud and scams. Here is us signing an MoU with M1 to extend the protection to their customers. As much as we‚Äôre grappling with beating the ever-evolving cyber threat ‚Äì a new form is in the works that‚Äôll be more powerful than any other threat we‚Äôve faced before. Quantum computing will soon become mainstream and will render current encryption and security measures ineffective. There is a pressing need to protect businesses here and our way of life. To get ahead of the threats, we launched Southeast Asia‚Äôs first quantum-safe network with industry leaders and have been progressively building a robust ecosystem of solutions that will help enterprises safeguard their digital assets. It‚Äôs all about staying one step ahead because the bad guys are also preparing, and we can‚Äôt wait for them to show their hands and react ‚Äì we‚Äôll likely to be too late. Having the technology alone isn‚Äôt enough. We need to prepare our workforce to have the skills necessary to thrive in an increasingly digital and automated world. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve been investing in equipping our employees in areas like AI, cybersecurity and 5G so they can harness the tech as transformative tools and not fear that their jobs will be taken over. All companies should be actively looking into this to ensure their staff and businesses are ready for what‚Äôs to come. Making Sustainability Real As we continue to pursue new innovations, we are mindful of our impact on our planet. For years, we‚Äôve taken steps to lower our carbon emissions throughout the supply chain ‚Äì from switching to electric vehicles, tapping solar energy for business operations, and cutting down on plastic packaging, to name a few. Our upcoming data centres are also going to use highly-efficient cooling technologies to cut water consumption. We will continue to explore the latest technology and industry best practices to reduce our carbon footprint as we work towards our net-zero 2045 goal. One of the exciting projects I was involved in this year, was the opening of Sisters‚Äô Islands Marine Park, which includes a lagoon tidal pool that has underwater cameras powered by #Singtel5G. With our connectivity, we‚Äôre bringing a slice of Singapore‚Äôs incredible biodiversity into classrooms, to help students see the natural world in a whole new way and hopefully appreciate and learn to care more about our environment. The tidal pool will serve as a sanctuary for marine life and a living classroom for future generations to learn about and appreciate our thriving bio-diverse ecosystem. It's also been a year of milestones for Singtel Singapore. We scored a couple of big wins globally like with Nestl√©, one of the world‚Äôs biggest food manufacturers. We‚Äôre helping to turn their global network into a cloud-centric one. On our shores, we‚Äôre helping PSA to build a fully sustainable and autonomous port to meet rising global transshipment demand. These are proud moments for me when you can see the impact of what we do. At the Tuas Port, Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs) will be upgraded to enhance real-time shipment tracking and further streamline crane operations. As we step into 2025, we‚Äôll be looking into how we can further harness emerging technologies like AI, quantum computing, and 6G to address the most pressing challenges of our time. Sustainability will remain a core focus as we explore innovative ways to reduce our carbon footprint while driving digital transformation. Technology for me has the power to bring us closer, to solve big problems, and to unlock new opportunities. And I know as a community we can achieve so much together. So let‚Äôs keep pushing the boundaries for a better future. Here‚Äôs to an exciting 2025 for everyone!

name: shanehegde
content: Our first Super Bowl ad!!! An estimated 125 million people will watch the Super Bowl tonight... and where better to broadcast than in the most populous country in the world? That‚Äôs right, Air 's first ever Super Bowl ad, starring Suniel Shetty and internet memetic sensation Darshan Magdun (yes, that Darshan) runs tonight right before the half time show. So tune into Star Sports India at 5am and get ready! We‚Äôre making history. In all seriousness, with Bad Bunny performing entirely in Spanish, we wanted to be part of the conversation happening around language, culture, and who ‚Äúmainstream‚Äù creative work is for. This ad was designed to respond to that moment, not defensively, but confidently. Air was built to reinforce a simple truth: Great creative work travels. It doesn‚Äôt belong to a single country, language, or accent. But it does have a home.

name: mahima-mehra-37aaa086
content: Call to collaborate! At HVT Foundation, we believe that true empowerment begins with awareness. Supporting rural children, youth, and women in building better hygiene practices‚Äîespecially menstrual health awareness‚Äîis central to our mission. With the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) now making menstrual hygiene education mandatory in schools, the need for structured, sensitive, and informed workshops has never been greater. Under the HVT Education Program and our Community Awareness Initiatives, we are conducting menstrual hygiene and women‚Äôs healthcare workshops that cover: ‚Ä¢ Scientific understanding of menstruation ‚Ä¢ Breaking myths and taboos ‚Ä¢ Safe hygiene practices ‚Ä¢ Nutrition and self-care ‚Ä¢ Emotional well-being ‚Ä¢ Access to sustainable menstrual products Our goal is simple ‚Äî to create informed communities where girls grow with confidence and dignity. We invite: ‚Ä¢ School Heads to connect with Vivek Kedia to introduce this workshop in your institution. ‚Ä¢ Community groups to connect with Anshu Saxena for grassroots workshops. ‚Ä¢ Sponsors and corporate partners to collaborate by sponsoring menstrual hygiene kits, sanitary products, awareness materials, and related essentials. ‚Ä¢ Partner organisations to join hands in expanding this mission. Volunteers can support through helping to conduct such awareness programs in schools and communities - connect with Nilay N. Parikh If you would like to support or collaborate, please write to: üì© Connect@hvtfoundation.org Together, let‚Äôs build healthier, informed, and empowered rural communities. üå∏ #menstrualhealth #hvtfoundation #OnGroundImpact #listeningtocommunities #menstrual #DevelopmentWithDignity #menstrualeducation

name: joseph-fuge
content: WebMCP looks like a great step to making websites more AI agent friendly. Hopefully this reduces both GenAI agent costs and website request hammering from agents as they accomplish their task with fewer requests to the web server by nature of getting it right the first time via the WebMCP tool. The Declarative API (described in the Google documentation linked below) to enable web developers to set up WebMCP for their site seems to be really simple, especially if the functionality you want to provide to the GenAI agent can already be performed by the user through an HTML form element. A couple simple HTML attributes on the form and that functionality is ready to go. Even the Imperative API, which you would put in a JS script tag, is straightforward as well. It is currently in early access only, but I'm curious to see how it will be adopted in the future. MCP authentication, prompt injection, and other security issues remain a concern. If your personal GenAI agent with sensitive information stumbles onto a malicious website with adversarial tools exposed via WebMCP, it could be a fast track to losing your personal data. Here are some resources to understand WebMCP better: - Brief overview video from Sentry 's Syntax YouTube channel: https://lnkd.in/gaxCt5iH Wes Bos makes a great point in the video - companies who want people, not agents, to use the site to facilitate their business model will not want to configure WebMCP tools to maintain ad revenues, opportunities to upsell, and more. - Google's early preview documentation: https://lnkd.in/gb42EnaY I'll be thinking about whether it makes sense for LocoLingua to enable WebMCP. Maybe companies will move towards managing their third party tools through natural language in the future as security concerns are resolved. Take care
