name: yujunliang
content: The Pursuit of Happyness(4) ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ‚òÅ Introduction In January 2017, AWS released another 2 certifications after I became fully certified in 2016 [1] , AWS Certified Big Data - Specialty AWS Certified Advanced Networking - Specialty I passed AWS Certified Big Data - Specialty on July 22nd, 2017 [2] . It is a hard exam, no doubt of it, but I relied on my working experience on S3 and Redshift, as well as an excellent course from Sanjay Kotecha . I didn't feel it particularly difficult to pass. But AWS Advanced Networking is so hard. It became generally accepted that it is the hardest exam among 8 AWS certifications. Many people with CCIE also failed at the first attempt. If you don't know, CCIE is the most admired certification in the networking space. It is even harder for people not from networking backgrounds. I used to be a Java developer before 2016, who never heard of CIDR, BGP, and VLAN. Networking used to be so boring and I never imagined that I would become a Network Engineer. But ever since started working on the cloud, I always need to work on infrastructure and networking-related projects so I decided to learn networking. Also, since this is the only AWS certification I didn't have, I planned to get it at any cost. Comparing AWS Certifications I have taken all AWS certifications, so I have an idea how what each certification is like, here is my measurement of the difficulty and scope of these exams, AWS Advanced Networking is the hardest of all. Early Stage of the Preparation I took the beta exam on 01/31/2017 to get a benchmark and secure a half-price voucher, not surprisingly, I got 24% since I knew nothing about networking at that time. I started preparing for it by watching Acloud.guru course from Adrian Cantrill , normally at late night, but I normally fell sleep since I was tired. I watched this course many times but couldn't get it due to the unfamiliarity of the topics. For a long time, I didn't seem to be able to learn it, I was frustrated sometimes. I read Network+ and CCNA books, but it didn't help much either. Attempt before re:Invent I had completed both Acloud.guru and LinuxAcademy.com courses on this exam and did well in the practice exams provided by them. I decided to attempt it before re:Invent and hopefully to attend re:Invent as a fully certified AWS professional. There was a Thanksgiving break before the re:Invent and I had 2 days to prepare for it and I attempted it on 11/25/2017, the last available day before re:Invent. Unfortunately, it is not an easy exam that can be crammed in two days. I only got 52% on this attempt. As promised, I shaved my head for not being able to pass it. Another Attempt before New Year Deloitte gives the last week of the year as a corporate holiday, and I decided to use it to prepare for this exam and clear it before the new year. I took the exam in November, so I had an idea of what kind of questions are asked. As mentioned by many people who passed the exam, Adrian's blog can be used as the study guide, the scope of the exam is pretty much outlined in that post. So I reviewed all articles and attempted it on 12/27/2017. After time was up and the exam was submitted automatically, the hourglass on the screen spun crazily. I kept repeating it in my mind, "Let me pass", Let me pass", "Let me pass"... After the longest minute of waiting, the screen refreshed with the following message, Unfortunately you didn't pass on this attempt. This time I got 56%, slightly better than the last attempt. Disappointed, my heart sank. But I quickly accepted it and drew a conclusion I need to improve the way I study. It is uncomfortable to talk about failed exams, my friends also warned me that people will judge me. But if I didn't give you a full picture, it is not possible to let you know how difficult it is and you may also underestimate it. I told some of my friends that this is a very hard exam, but they still underestimated it and failed. So in order to pass this exam on your first attempt, the following contents are very important. Taking Expert Advice I finally realized this is a no-joke exam. There is no shortcut, I went back to square one. In September 2017, Jady Liu passed the exam and put a posting on LinkedIn, After the failed attempt on 12/27/2017, I decided to put more effort into the preparation. I read her article again and followed this advice. I noted down all important knowledge while watching acloudguru videos, which highly focused on the exam. These videos are worth watching as many as times till you fully understand all the concepts and knowledge mentioned. This advice is crucial to passing the exam, so I will give some examples in this article on how I distilled study notes from tons of information, so you can follow along. Preparing and Distilling Study Notes I searched many AWS articles and collected 140 slides of study notes, since there are so many topics covered in this exam, there are lots of content to be memorized. A study note to distill the important points from the rest of the contents is critical to passing the exam. I am giving two screenshots of the PowerPoint presentation, which can give you a direction to prepare the study notes. Illustration of the Study Notes When I felt ready to pass the exam, it became 140 slides. And this is the only exam I prepared study notes like this, for all others, I just watched videos and read materials. But I knew I wouldn't be able to pass it if I hadn't had prepared these 140 slides with distilled essence. Note: the table of contents is not a complete list, it is just the part I want myself to pay more attention to. How to Distill Verbose Contents into Concise Study Notes Just to give you another example: I read this article, The article is too long to remember, so I copied the important parts from the article and pasted them to a couple of slides, the following screenshot illustrates how I organized the articles into PowerPoint slides, the thumbnail images on the left illustrates those contents related to the network connectivity, By doing this over a 20 day period, I was able to extract the information and settle on a 140 slides PowerPoint file, I still read the original articles and watched Acloud.guru course but I planned to review this file before the exam. Please don't ask me to share this file since I may violate NDA for doing it. I just thought to share the approach to help you to be prepared. The Extraordinary Effort Besides reading all the related user guides, I also watched re:Invent videos on Networking and took notes on those important concepts. It is not easy. I spent 2 days on Thanksgiving, 10 days on Christmas and New Year break, and 3 days of the entire Martin Luther King long weekend studying it. But it is my last certification for AWS, so I made the determination to pass it at any cost! I just have this kind of persistence and dedication! I started preparing this PowerPoint file on 12/27/2017, after I prepared those slides, I finally understood networking. You can use the LinuxAcademy course as supplementary material but they are not enough to prep you for the exam. The exam relies heavily on real-life scenarios, so it is crucial to know all the topics inside out. Looking back, I should have started taking notes earlier, which is a critical technique in preparing for this exam since the scope of the exam is very broad and deep. You may not need to use PowerPoint, but you must use some method to take notes and review the notes before you go into the exam. Important Study Guides Jady mentioned you may need to watch Acloud guru many times, These videos are worth watching as many as times till you fully understand all the concepts and knowledge mentioned. I did watch many times before fully understanding the concepts of BGP and MED, also I watched re:Invent videos on Direct Connect and those videos helped me fully understand the routing, which is very important for passing the exam. I gave some examples of how to prepare the study notes and hope it is helpful for you. Also, want to let people know, it doesn't matter what background you come from, as long as you prepare with enough effort, you can pass this exam. And the knowledge you learn while preparing for the exam will help you greatly on your job. Passing the Exam On January 20th, 2018, before the exam, I reviewed the study notes of these 140 slides. When the time was up and the exam submitted automatically, I sat there blankly without hoping anything. I was afraid if I had expected I would fail again. I also knew that I had learned a lot while preparing for it and it didn't matter whether I passed it or not. When the screen refreshed, it congratulated me for passing it. And I passed the exam at 76%. It is not great but once again, I became fully certified on AWS. What's Next Just when I was about to relax and have a break, AWS released another certification, which made the journey a never-ending story. Crazy as crazy does, I became the #1 certified cloud practitioner[3] and people asked me how did I do it, it is the same way Forrest Gump ran across America. When I am tired, I sleep, when I am hungry, I eat. All my spare time, I study. Studying is exhausting sometimes, but I enjoy doing it since I made many friends along the journey, many people passed this exam before me and their success inspired me to keep running! Thank you! Maybe one day, I will stop this certification run, but not now! But not now! Run with me if you enjoy it! Note: [1] The Pursuit of Happyness - My AWS Certification Journey [2] AWS Certified Big Data - Specialty [3] Mad Max: Fury Road into ‚òÅÔ∏è! || ÂçéÂ±±ËÆ∫Ââë, Ë∞Å‰∏é‰∫âÈîã? [4] AWS Certified Advanced Networking Official Study Guide: Specialty Exam People give a good review of this book but it wasn't available when I prepared for it.

name: basiakubicka
content: It takes 4-6 years for an AI PM to get to $500k comp. It takes 8-12 years for most PMs to get to $300k comp. Here's how to become an AI PM: But what is an AI PM? An AI Product Manager is not someone who simply uses AI. They are the strategic architect who bridges intelligence, systems, and business impact. Every model decision, UX flow, and prompt chain is tied to a business outcome: reduced costs, increased retention, or defensible differentiation. An elite AI PM operates at the intersection of: 1. Product Thinking ‚Üí Deep empathy for users and the ability to translate pain into product opportunity. 2. Model & System Thinking ‚Üí Understanding how intelligence, data, and automation interact ‚Äî and how to build scalable learning loops. 3. Business Thinking ‚Üí Quantifying trade-offs, managing infra costs, aligning product bets with company strategy, and driving measurable ROI. 4. Ethical & Strategic Leadership ‚Üí Balancing innovation with governance, trust, and long-term defensibility. In essence: The AI PM is a part product strategist, part business operator, part AI architect. name: cheechong-lee
content: Most consultants think they're exhausted because they're overworked. They're not. They're tired because they're holding too many disconnected pieces together in their head. The owner becomes the translator between systems. The reminder department. The emergency backup plan. That's not leadership ‚Äì that's unpaid integration work. The real problem isn't hustle. It's disconnection. Every business runs on an operating system. Not software ‚Äì a way things flow. How people find you. What they see first. How fast someone responds. What happens next. When those steps connect, effort compounds. When they don't, effort leaks. Here's what changes when you build connection: Stop being the bottleneck Marketing feeds directly into follow-up. No manual handoffs. No dropped leads because someone forgot to check the form. Reduce decision fatigue Clear next steps for every situation. Your team knows what to do without asking you every time. Create predictable outcomes When systems talk to each other, you can actually forecast what happens next instead of hoping. Build trust automatically Consistent experience from first contact to final delivery. No gaps where prospects wonder if you're professional. Example: A strategy consultant I know was drowning in follow-ups. Leads came from LinkedIn, calls happened on Zoom, proposals lived in Google Docs, and invoicing was manual. She connected these into one flow. Now when someone books a call, the system sends prep questions, creates the proposal template, and schedules follow-up automatically. Same effort, triple the conversion. Rule: If your business only works when you push harder, the problem isn't effort ‚Äì it's how the pieces connect. Which part of your business feels most disconnected right now? What would change if those pieces actually talked to each other?

name: alex-selimov
content: I've been using August Bradley's "Life Operating System" for about 5 months now and I have to say it was a complete game-changer for me. With two kids (one under a year old), time is limited. There was only even enough to make a little daily progress on any one project. I had (and still have) a large list of projects to work on and things to learn. I needed focus to ensure that the little bit of progress I could make was on something that would yield desirable longer lasting results. August Bradley's system helped immensely with this. Planning daily activities while keeping in mind future goals really helps narrow down what things are worth doing at any given moment. The reviews have also been extremely impactful. Critically reviewing progress at the end of each week, month, and quarter gives you the opportunity to correct your heading before things go off the rails. Not sure how I got anywhere without them. I also admit that its fun to engage in the little bit of "procrastivity" of messing around with dashboards and working on project planning. You should check it out if you need help optimally allocating your time and directing your energies to make sure you are developing along the lines you want! You should at least expose yourself to this way of thinking and see if it works for you.

name: rakeshgohel01
content: DMZ launched #HackTheCruve at the beginning of April to develop a solution that could alleviate some of the most significant difficulties being faced by Canadians as a consequence of COVID-19. Solutions should help business continuity, frontline worker support, healthcare improvements, supports for non-profit organizations, crisis management tools, delivery improvements, services for seniors, contact tracing and more. Town of Innisfil also participated with their five problem statements for digital communication portal, paper-based time cards, customer service chatbot, public consultations and farmer customer API. The image is from DMZ. While working on a similar social impact project called COVID19TO , our team of five was excited to build farmer customer API. Ideation After identifying the area of work, we quickly built some surveys for farmers and end-users to determine the difficulties they have been facing. We contacted more than ten farmers, more than five farmer's markets and a couple of agricultural associations and came up with this: Problem 1) On the shoppers' side, they started facing long lineups at local grocery stores. After getting into the stores, many noticed empty shelves. Additionally, they felt risky picking the produce from the stores as those produces being touched multiple individuals. Some have tried to reach delivery apps, and they found that those services are two to four weeks out for the next delivery. 2) According to StatsCan, More than 30% of household spending goes to restaurants , and we dug more. Farmers produce is directly sold to bulk-buyers like restaurants, cafeterias and other food chains. COVID-19 broke this supply chain when 60% of restaurants were closed under a government mandate to stop the further spread of this disease. The situation worsens for farmers as some of the dairy farmers were asked to dump the milk , excess mushrooms were being destroyed in northern Ontario, and chicken farmers decided to shrink national flock by 12% . Market Size 2018 report from StatsCan shows that there are $4.2 billion farms to market (farm gate + farmer's market) sales for vegetables and fruits when it combined with other poultry products reaches to $27.3 billion of total addressable market size nationally. The farmer's market constitutes $1.8 billion in sales every year in Ontario alone, and those farmer's markets were cancelled. Solution We envisioned a solution to put money back in farmers' hands. We called it. Farmer's Food Truck Working with local farmers, we gather the produce into an assembly facility and build subscription boxes with fixed items in three sizes for an individual and family of two and four. The subscription boxes are delivered by a food truck for curbside pickup weekly and bi-weekly delivery. From our research, we found that people travel a maximum of five kilometres to get their groceries. Our solution builds a community area for a similar distance. It sends a truck to schools and community centres' parking lots as these spaces are not currently used, and people showed interest in standing up to help farmers on a small rental amount. Users receive alert notifications when they can pick up their boxes in a given time-slot of 30-60 minutes. While driving through, they can maintain the social distance, and the truck driver loads boxes into a car. We also used the Shopify store to create a fast prototype to build subscription boxes. Benefits Our solution adds values for Shoppers save valuable time for not standing lines, A direct farm's to shoppers' community area delivery reduces many people touching the produce. Fresh and healthy produce for shoppers. Can give revenue back to farmers. Next Steps If we were to pursue this solution further, it would be incredibly valuable to do extensive user research, including competitive analysis, before moving forward. We worked so far from our collective knowledge and improvised research. It would be great to study the grocery shopping patterns post COVID-19 and whether shoppers would prefer a fixed type of subscription box or customized one for a given season. In conclusion, I would like to thank DMZ for generously putting this hackathon together and our mentor Shane Flynn for providing valuable inputs. It was an excellent experience and great learning out of it.

content: I still remember the first time I entered this field. Everything felt new. Every meeting felt like a challenge. And every task felt like a chance to prove myself. I didn‚Äôt expect that a few months later, the same place would offer me something bigger. Today, I‚Äôm excited to share that I‚Äôve joined OWLED as a Business Development Associate. This isn‚Äôt just a new title for me. It‚Äôs a step that came after a lot of learning, late-night thinking, and pushing myself to grow beyond what I thought I could do. A big and heartfelt thank you to Syed Twariqh for trusting me with this opportunity. Your support has meant a lot, from answering my smallest doubts without hesitation to guiding me through things I didn‚Äôt even know I needed to learn. I‚Äôve already learned and grown so much because of your mentorship, and there‚Äôs still a lot I‚Äôm excited to learn from you. Excited to learn faster, fail smarter, close bigger deals, and grow with a team that pushes me in the right ways. Let‚Äôs get to work ‚ú®

name: andressantana
content: It was around 2003 in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic while I was a senior in high school that my cousin got me into taking a Linux class taught by one of his college professors -I still remember the distro, Knoppix-. The class didn't have any structure nor any academic accreditation, it was more the get-together with a group of geeks and access to computers with Linux that made it attractive. The professor had a hands-on approach to teaching and often would say " Linux is best learnt typing in the terminal ". That class gave me an idea of what I wanted to do in college, of course, Computer Science. To be honest, back then I didn't even know what that name meant. The college I went to didn't offer Computer Science per se, the closest they had was something I will translate as "Computer Systems Engineering". I enrolled and started classes in January of 2004, the same year I started working as a "Technical Support" for a multinational that had operations in the DR. By the way, it's very common in the DR to work while attending college (will write a post about it later). After a few months of being in the job, I was recruited to work as a Delphi programmer that included a training trip to Lexington, KY which for me was a big thing: traveling, going outside the country, getting on an airplane and bunch of other things for the first time ; I was excited. I had to stop school for a quarter but it was worthwhile. This was me debugging some spaghetti Pascal code in Delphi back in 2004 After some years of experience programming and using English frequently, many doors started to open for my professional life. I switched jobs and environment. I started programming in Java and working with Oracle DB with an awesome team of professionals working for Verizon -- all this before I had graduated from college. Before graduating I had started to look for jobs opportunities in the USA, I even signed up in several websites and uploaded my resume but I realized that without the college degree my chances were very low. So, in 2008 and less than a year to college graduation I resumed looking for opportunities outside the DR. The story goes like this: 99.99% of the companies I talked to weren't interested in sponsoring an H1B (work) visa. But you know what, I kept trying . Initially I started putting the visa requirement upfront, but then I tried the opposite; it was the last thing I mentioned, hoping that one of them will like my skills so much that they would like to at least try to sponsor me. The year was 2011 when I talked to a startup in Miami and they were interested in sponsoring me for a work visa, jackpot !!!. We did all the paperwork and by October of that year I moved with my family to Miami to work for them. It was a new life for us. We didn't have to worry anymore of not having running water or daily power outages or safety. There were a lot more opportunities there. Finally, in retrospective, I think the Miami startup was just a bridge into bigger things. After being in the startup for just 5 months I got an offer to work at Amazon and we moved to Seattle and have been here for more than 7 years now and still loving it. #TellYourStory

content: Big move for Singapore making it clear that AI isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúnice-to-have‚Äù, but a national priority. content: i proposed... introducing jam. you build, jam spreads. Mohammad Alshaikhusain and i are beyond excited to be backed by fabian hedin (co-founder cto, lovable), thomas wolf (co-founder hugging face) and devtool founders, engineers, operators, and researchers that we deeply respect from browserbase, together ai, e2b, meta, google, etc. we orchestrate tools for it to be easy and friendly for people to run complex distribution workflows. there should be an elegant software for distribution in the ai era we also expose our automation workflows as an mcp server that openclaw agents can call from any messaging channel like whatsapp, telegram, slack, or discord we are open sourcing everything we discover so u can contribute and use what you'd like (shoutout to our community of devs, you guys are great) github: https://lnkd.in/gA7ixzRq and twitter post here: https://lnkd.in/gNr-C3sG we send out rolling beta invites today! if you are a builder or company we hope you enjoy! also happy valentine's day comment "bread" to get access!

name: yujunliang
content: *Important: This study guide is outdated. The journey started here , and it continues. A Professional Collaboration Engineer transforms business objectives into tangible configurations, policies, and security practices as they relate to users, content, and integrations. Through their understanding of their organization‚Äôs infrastructure, Collaboration Engineers enable people to work together, communicate, and access data in a secure and efficient manner. Operating with an engineering and solutions mindset, they use tools, programming languages, and APIs to automate workflows. They look for opportunities to educate end users and increase operational efficiency while advocating for Google Workspace and the Google toolset 1 Object management 1.1 Manage user life cycles with provisioning and deprovisioning processes. Considerations include: Adding users (e.g., individual, bulk, automated) Removing users (e.g., suspending, deleting, recovering) Editing user attributes (e.g., renaming, passwords , aliases) Creating administrative roles (e.g., default roles, custom roles) 1.2 Configure shared drives. Considerations include: Transferring user data from one user to another 1.3 Manage calendar resources . 1.4 Configure and manage Google Groups for Business. Considerations include: Configuring Google Groups Adding users to groups Implications of current Google Workspace APIs to development efforts Using Apps Script to automate tasks 2 Service configuration 2.1 Implement and manage Workspace configurations based on corporate policies. Considerations include: Managing company profile settings Modifying OU policies Managing rollout of new Google functionality to end users Troubleshooting Google Workspace services (e.g., performance issues for services suite, Google Workspace apps for OUs) 2.2 Demonstrate how to set up and configure google mail. Considerations include: Enabling email delegation for an OU Managing Gmail archives 3 Troubleshooting 3.1 Troubleshoot user reports of mail delivery problems. 3.2 Collect log files or reports needed to engage with support . 3.3 Classify and mitigate basic email attacks . Considerations include: Configuring attachment compliance , advanced Configuring blocked senders Configuring email allowlist Configuring objectionable content Configuring phishing settings Configuring spam settings Managing admin quarantine Configuring Secure Transport compliance Configuring safety settings 3.4 Troubleshoot workspace access and performance. 4 Data Access and Authentication 4.1 Configure policies for all devices (mobile, desktop, CrOS, Meet, browser). Considerations include: Company-owned vs. personal devices Configuring personal device settings (e.g., password, Android, iOS, advanced, device approvals, app management, insights) 4.2 Configure and implement data governance policies. 4.3 Describe how to manage third-party applications. Considerations include: Configuring third-party SSO for Workspace Integrating with third party for provisioning Integrating third-party marketplace apps to specific OUs in Google Workspace Granting API access to applications that need access Revoking third-party oauth access Removing connected applications and sites 4.4 Configure user authentication. Considerations include: Basic user security controls (e.g., password length enforcement and 2-Step Verification) Security aspects of identity, perimeter security, and data protection 5 Support business initiatives 5.1 Use Vault to assist legal teams. Setting retention rules (e.g., Setting retention rules, placing legal holds , searching your domain's data by user account, OU, date, or keyword , exporting data for additional processing and review , auditing reports ) Holding and exporting data Running Vault audit reports 5.2 Interpret reports for the business. Considerations Include: Scanning email with Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Managing content compliance rules Configuring security and data region Monitoring security health check Configuring security settings Creating security records Designing security integration and addressing objections 5.3 Describe how to import and export data

name: rajvrat-thapliyal
content: We Built Autonomous Orbital Defense in 36 Hours üöÄ TreeHacks 2026 - Finalist, NVIDIA Track In 36 hours, our team built StarGuard, an autonomous collision avoidance and evasive maneuvering system for satellites operating in congested and signal denied environments. Satellite launches have increased more than 20√ó since 2010, and with mega constellations like SpaceX scaling aggressively, orbits are becoming denser every year. At the same time, communications jamming is becoming more frequent across multiple regions of the world, degrading navigation accuracy and limiting reliance on ground based coordination. In a future where satellites cannot depend on uninterrupted communication with ground stations, autonomy becomes mission critical. StarGuard provides a full end to end onboard system to: ùêÉùêûùê≠ùêûùêúùê≠ ‚Ä¢ Two fine tuned YOLOv8 models trained on synthetically generated star tracker imagery ‚Ä¢ NVIDIA Cosmos Reasoning 2 VLM for satellite classification and contextual risk assessment ‚Ä¢ Identification of satellites, debris, and non cooperative actors ùêèùê´ùêûùêùùê¢ùêúùê≠ ‚Ä¢ CUDA accelerated propagation of 10,000+ satellite trajectories using TensorGator ( https://lnkd.in/gDZasdAG ) ‚Ä¢ Unscented Kalman Filter pipeline for state estimation ‚Ä¢ Real time collision probability and proximity risk scoring ùêÄùêúùê≠ ‚Ä¢ Convex optimization to compute minimum thrust required for evasive maneuvers ‚Ä¢ Autonomous orbit adjustment using onboard thrusters ‚Ä¢ Chaser evader simulations to handle adversarial rendezvous scenarios We simulated satellite dogfights. We executed real time collision avoidance logic. We ran parallel orbital simulations on GPU. And we did it all in 36 hours on NVIDIA ‚Äôs DGX Spark. Met Cory Levy at the Z Fellows event and wrapped the weekend at the Y Combinator afterparty surrounded by some of the most driven builders I have met. Amazing meeting the teams from Cerebras , OpenAI , Runpod , Cloudflare , and Vercel that are pushing the limits of AI Massive thank you to NVIDIA , especially Chitoku Yato , for backing us and giving us the hardware to push this to the limit. name: jeremyipark
content: I made a computer vision app to measure back curvature during deadlift! My previous post focused on measuring deadlift rep timing by tracking the barbell plate. Since then, I‚Äôve added the ability to quantify back roundness, so that we can determine whether the lift was completed with either a straight back or a rounded back. This could be used to help guide proper technique during training. Here are the main technical highlights: ‚Äî RF-DETR ( Roboflow ) to segment the person (great performance out-the-box with no additional training!) ‚Äî YOLO11n ( Ultralytics ) for bounding box prediction around the barbell weight plate (trained on my own small dataset). ‚Äî Mediapipe ( Google ) for pose landmark detection to guide the bounds for the line fitting. ‚Äî Custom logic to fit a line across the back. I shared this work at AI Tinkerers Raleigh last night and got 2nd place demo! It was great to hear everyone‚Äôs feedback and to connect with this inspiring group. I‚Äôm excited for how this work can enable AI-assisted feedback and for what could be the beginning of an ‚ÄúAI coach.‚Äù I‚Äôm very passionate about fitness, and excited to connect with more people in this AI and fitness space. Happy to chat if you have any questions or if you just want to connect! ‚Äî To explain a bit more about the plots on the right side: The Back Roundness Map shows the deviation of the estimated back curve from a line of best fit. I was very happy to see that the two reps that I intentionally did with a rounded back show up so clearly in the data! The Average Back Shape plot shows how the rounded back reps look visually distinct from the straight back reps. ‚Äî #computervision #ai #ml #machinelearning #deeplearning #phd #roboflow #google #ultralytics #yolo #gym #fitness #deadlift #aitinkerers Google for Developers Google AI for Developers

name: rubendominguezibar
content: Lovable turns your deck into a web app. And it looks unfair. If you are still building decks in Google Slides, you are shipping 2014 UX in 2026. Lovable lets you write one prompt and get a full-screen, animated, web-native deck that feels like a product demo, not a PDF. It is the first time I have seen teams replace slides entirely. Some are already doing decks 100% in Lovable because the output looks cleaner, moves smoother, and is easier to share. This matters because decks are not ‚Äúslides‚Äù. They are distribution. If your deck looks like a website, it gets shared like a website. What changes with Lovable You are not making pages. You are building a React app where each slide is a full-screen view. That unlocks: Smooth transitions and modern motion Responsive layouts automatically Interactive components (tabs, charts, calculators) One-click publish as a link If you pitch investors, sell B2B, or present internally, it is a cheat code. I'm sharing the Lovable Slide Deck Kit , including: The exact ‚Äú Foundation Prompt ‚Äù that generates a full deck skeleton with navigation, dots, and animations 12 copy-paste slide prompts (Title, Agenda, Metrics, Traction, GTM, Pricing, Comparison, Case Study, Team, Roadmap, Ask, CTA) A 3-step workflow to build decks fast without breaking navigation or wasting credits A ready-to-paste Knowledge File template to keep branding consistent across slides A ‚ÄúDo not touch‚Äù guardrail prompt that prevents Lovable from breaking other slides A polish checklist for the final 10% (spacing, typography, motion, projector safe mode) üëâ get all HERE

name: milanmilanovic
content: The most dangerous answers sound clean üí° Because ‚Äúeasy to read‚Äù often feels like ‚Äútrue‚Äù But complex problems rarely have clean answers They have tradeoffs, missing data, and uncertainty A tiny critical-thinking habit is to ask: ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWhat would have to be true for this to fail?‚Äù ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWhat evidence would change my mind?‚Äù Do it once per day. Your decisions get sharper fast. Have a strong week ahead üëã

name: phil-kildea-87033a40
content: I'm honoured (and a little bit stunned) to share that I‚Äôve officially become a Golden Kubestronaut. From what I understand, this makes me the 10th Golden Kubestronaut in the UK and the first in Northern Ireland ‚Äî a milestone I‚Äôm incredibly proud of. This journey has been a long one and it's pretty surreal to finally be finished! A huge thank you to everyone past and present at Aston Martin F1 Team for the support and encouragement along the way. And to my wonderful wife Sarah Kildea ‚Äî thank you for backing me relentlessly, for giving me the time and space to study, and for doing all of that while we‚Äôre raising our baby daughter. I couldn‚Äôt have done this without you. Massive thanks as well to: Mumshad Mannambeth and everyone at KodeKloud for world-class courses and hands-on learning that genuinely made the difference. Sajeeva Nambadawa Vithanage at CertDirectory.io for the inspiration and sharing so many great exam discount codes (they really helped!). name: pascalbornet
content: For years, I‚Äôve been saying something simple: ‚ÄúVoice is the keyboard of the future.‚Äù Because typing is inefficient. ‚å®Ô∏èüó£Ô∏è As knowledge workers, we spend almost three hours a day typing and constantly switching tabs. That is a lot of time spent on mechanics instead of thinking. We don‚Äôt think in keystrokes, but we think in ideas and intentions. And now, finally, the technology is catching up. Lemon AI released it. We can interact with any application on our phone or computer just by using our voice. It is expanding the power of Vibe Coding to tasks beyond coding. Voice becomes no longer just dictation. It can trigger actions. We can ask for research, draft a document, send emails, update systems, or run workflows across different tools. Instead of typing instructions step by step, we can say what we want done. That is a big shift. It moves us from input-focused work to outcome-focused work. From ‚Äúhow do I do this?‚Äù to ‚Äúmake this happen.‚Äù I haven‚Äôt fully rebuilt my own workflow around voice yet. But for the first time, it feels realistic, not theoretical. The interface of work is changing. If you are curious to see what this looks like in practice, you can explore it at heylemon.ai . The real question is: are we ready to design our work around intent instead of typing? #LemonAIAmbassador #AI #AgenticAI #FutureOfWork #Productivity #HumanPlusAI

name: leadgenmanthan
content: What is AI automation? AI automation refers to the use of artificial intelligence technology to automate various tasks and processes. It involves the development and deployment of intelligent systems that can perform repetitive tasks, analyze data, make predictions, and make decisions without human intervention. AI automation has revolutionized industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, finance, and customer service by improving efficiency, reducing costs, and enhancing productivity. By leveraging AI automation, businesses can streamline their operations, optimize resource allocation, and deliver better products and services to their customers. Learn More in the Course of Chatbots and AI automation agency . Why start an AI automation agency? Starting an AI automation agency can be a lucrative business venture in today's fast-paced digital landscape. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and automation technologies are revolutionizing industries across the globe, offering businesses the opportunity to streamline processes, increase efficiency, and reduce costs. By starting an AI automation agency, you can tap into this growing demand and provide cutting-edge solutions to businesses seeking to leverage AI technology. Moreover, the AI automation industry is expected to experience significant growth in the coming years, presenting a promising opportunity for entrepreneurs and investors. With the right expertise and strategic approach, you can position your agency as a leader in the AI automation space and capitalize on the immense potential it offers. Key benefits of starting an AI automation agency Starting an AI automation agency can provide numerous benefits for entrepreneurs. Firstly, it allows you to tap into the growing demand for AI automation solutions across industries. With businesses increasingly looking to streamline their operations and improve efficiency, there is a huge market for AI automation services. Secondly, starting an AI automation agency gives you the opportunity to work on cutting-edge technology and be at the forefront of innovation. You can develop and implement AI solutions that have the potential to transform businesses and drive growth. Lastly, starting your own AI automation agency gives you the freedom and flexibility to build a business that aligns with your passion and expertise. You can shape the direction of your agency and create a unique value proposition in the market. Overall, starting an AI automation agency can be a rewarding and lucrative venture for aspiring entrepreneurs. Understanding the AI Automation Industry Current state of the AI automation industry The AI automation industry is currently experiencing rapid growth and innovation. According to recent reports, the market size for AI automation is expected to reach $XX billion by 2025. This growth is driven by the increasing demand for automation solutions across various industries, including healthcare, finance, and manufacturing. AI automation offers businesses the ability to streamline processes, improve efficiency, and reduce costs. However, there are also challenges and risks associated with the adoption of AI automation, such as ethical concerns and potential job displacement. Despite these challenges, the future of the AI automation industry looks promising, with more advancements and opportunities on the horizon. Trends and opportunities in the AI automation industry The AI automation industry is experiencing significant growth and innovation . Several trends are shaping the industry, including the increased adoption of AI technologies across various sectors, the development of more advanced AI algorithms and models, and the integration of AI with other emerging technologies like IoT and blockchain . These trends present numerous opportunities for entrepreneurs and businesses to capitalize on the demand for AI automation solutions. However, it is important to be aware of the challenges and risks associated with the industry, such as ethical considerations , data privacy , and regulatory compliance . By staying updated with the latest trends and addressing these challenges, aspiring AI automation agencies can position themselves for success in this dynamic industry. Challenges and risks in the AI automation industry The AI automation industry faces several challenges and risks that need to be considered when starting your own agency. These challenges include ethical concerns surrounding AI decision-making, data privacy and security issues, and the lack of skilled AI professionals . Additionally, there are risks associated with regulatory compliance and technological limitations . It is crucial to address these challenges and mitigate the risks to ensure the success of your AI automation agency. Steps to Start Your Own AI Automation Agency Identify your target market and niche Once you have a clear understanding of the AI automation industry, it is important to identify your target market and niche . This will help you focus your efforts and tailor your solutions to meet the specific needs of your clients. Conduct market research to determine which industries and businesses can benefit the most from AI automation. Consider factors such as the size of the market, competition, and potential demand. Additionally, define your niche by identifying the specific problems or pain points that your agency will address. By narrowing down your target market and niche, you can position your agency as an expert in that area and differentiate yourself from competitors. Build a team of AI experts Building a team of AI experts is crucial for the success of your AI automation agency. Look for professionals with a strong background in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data science. Consider hiring individuals who have experience in developing AI solutions and working with different industries. Creating a diverse team will bring in a range of perspectives and expertise, allowing you to tackle complex challenges and provide tailored solutions to your clients. Collaborate with your team to develop a skills matrix that outlines the specific skills and knowledge each member brings to the table. This will help you identify any gaps and allocate resources effectively. Encourage continuous learning and professional development to ensure your team stays updated with the latest advancements in AI technology and techniques. By building a team of AI experts, you will be well-equipped to deliver high-quality AI automation solutions to your clients. Develop your AI automation solutions Once you have built a team of AI experts , it's time to focus on developing your AI automation solutions. This involves creating innovative algorithms and models that can automate various tasks and processes. You will need to invest in research and development to stay ahead of the competition and continuously improve your solutions. Additionally, it's important to test your solutions thoroughly to ensure their efficiency and accuracy . Consider creating a roadmap that outlines the development process and milestones. Don't forget to document your solutions and create user-friendly interfaces to make it easier for your clients to integrate and use them. Remember, the success of your AI automation agency depends on the quality and effectiveness of your solutions. Conclusion Summary of key points In summary, starting your own AI automation agency can be a lucrative venture in today's technology-driven world. By understanding the current state of the AI automation industry and identifying trends and opportunities, you can position your agency to meet the growing demand for AI solutions. Building a team of AI experts will ensure that you have the necessary expertise to develop innovative automation solutions. With the right strategy and a focus on delivering value to your target market, your agency can thrive in this rapidly evolving industry. Future prospects of the AI automation industry The future prospects of the AI automation industry are highly promising. With advancements in technology and increasing demand for automation solutions, the industry is expected to witness significant growth in the coming years. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) technologies are becoming more sophisticated and capable of handling complex tasks, leading to improved efficiency and productivity. Moreover, the integration of AI automation into various industries, such as healthcare, finance, and manufacturing, offers immense opportunities for businesses to streamline their operations and gain a competitive edge. As organizations realize the potential benefits of AI automation, the demand for AI automation agencies is likely to surge. To capitalize on this growing market, aspiring entrepreneurs can focus on developing innovative AI solutions, providing specialized services, and staying updated with the latest industry trends and technologies. Final thoughts and recommendations In conclusion, starting your own AI automation agency can be a challenging yet rewarding endeavor. By understanding the current state of the AI automation industry and identifying trends and opportunities, you can position your agency for success. Building a team of AI experts and developing innovative AI automation solutions will set you apart from the competition. Remember to stay updated with the latest advancements in AI technology and continuously improve your skills. With determination and perseverance, your agency can thrive in this rapidly evolving field. Good luck on your journey! Discover Chatbots and AI automation agency .

name: rubendominguezibar
content: AI is slipping into everything: how we write, how we hire, how we negotiate, how we build, how we raise money. The change isn't loud, but it's relentless. And the gap between people who adapt and people who don't is getting wider, faster than most realize. The Numbers Tell the Story AI adoption hit 72% across enterprises in 2024 , up from 55% in 2023. (McKinsey Global Survey) GenAI cost optimization is now the #1 priority for 67% of companies, meaning tools that were experiments last year are now budget line items. (Gartner) 40% of working hours could be augmented or automated by AI and generative AI, according to Goldman Sachs‚Äîbut the timeline keeps accelerating. Entry-level hiring in "AI-exposed jobs" dropped 13% since late 2022. Junior positions in software development, customer service, and clerical work are disappearing faster than anyone predicted. (Stanford Digital Economy Lab) The forecast? By 2030, AI will contribute $15.7 trillion to the global economy ‚Äîmore than the current output of China and India combined. (PwC) But here's what the numbers don't show: the quality gap. It's not just about who uses AI. It's about who uses it well. The people building systems and workflows with AI are pulling ahead at an exponential rate. Everyone else is stuck arguing whether AI is overhyped. What's Actually Happening Over the past weeks, I've been publishing a series of practical, hands-on resources focused on how builders, founders, and operators are actually using AI today. If you want to stay ahead, these are worth your time: 1Ô∏è‚É£ 2,500+ Angels Who Actually Write Checks for AI & SaaS A hard-to-find list of angels who are actively investing, not just talking. AI startups raised $67B in 2024‚Äîknowing who writes checks matters. 2Ô∏è‚É£ No One Is Safe From AI A clear look at how AI is reshaping roles across industries, not just tech. When 40% of working hours are augmentable, everyone's affected. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Clawdbot: The 24/7 AI Employee You Actually Own Why autonomous AI workers are replacing tools, not just assisting them. The shift from "AI helps you work" to "AI does the work" is happening now. 4Ô∏è‚É£ Claude in Excel: 30 Prompts to Audit Any Financial Model How serious operators use AI to pressure-test spreadsheets and assumptions. Financial modeling just got 10x faster and more reliable. 5Ô∏è‚É£ I Turned Chris Voss' FBI Negotiation Playbook Into AI Prompts Using AI to prepare for high-stakes conversations before they happen. Negotiation advantage comes from better prep, not better improvisation. 6Ô∏è‚É£ The 10 GitHub Repos AI Engineers Use to Make LLMs Faster and Cheaper the infrastructure layer most people miss. As AI costs drop 90% year-over-year, knowing how to optimize matters. 7Ô∏è‚É£ I Built a Prompt That Feels Like a $50K Growth Consultant What happens when prompts are treated like systems, not text. Strategic thinking on demand. 8Ô∏è‚É£ I Built an AI Humaniser Prompt I Now Use Everywhere Making AI output usable, not obviously synthetic. The quality gap is real‚Äîthis closes it. 9Ô∏è‚É£ The One Prompt Structure That Changes AI Output Quality A simple framework that consistently improves results. Small structure changes = massive output improvements. üîü OpenAI's Early Pitch Deck, Broken Down What the deck reveals about how foundational AI companies think. They raised $1B with 3 slides‚Äîhere's why it worked. 1Ô∏è‚É£1Ô∏è‚É£ Stop Using PowerPoint for Serious Decks Why the format is holding founders back. AI-native companies present differently. 1Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£ R.I.P. Basic Prompting Why copy-paste prompts are already obsolete. The skill is building prompt systems, not finding good prompts. 1Ô∏è‚É£3Ô∏è‚É£ The Most Recent AI Startup Decks You Should Study Right Now A snapshot of where new AI companies are actually going. $67B was invested in 2024‚Äîthis shows where it went. 1Ô∏è‚É£4Ô∏è‚É£ How Serious Builders Co-Work With Claude How advanced users treat AI as a collaborator, not a chatbot. The difference between using AI and working with AI. The Forecast That Matters By 2030, PwC predicts AI will add $15.7 trillion to global GDP. But that number hides what's actually happening: The productivity gains won't be evenly distributed. Companies and individuals who build AI into their workflows will see 30-50% productivity improvements. Everyone else will see wage compression and job displacement. McKinsey's latest report is blunt: "The difference between AI leaders and laggards will be the defining economic divide of the next decade." Translation: if you're not building systems with AI right now, you're falling behind people who are. One Takeaway AI isn't about knowing one trick or one tool. It's about building a working set of mental models, prompts, and systems that compound over time. The people doing this well aren't louder or smarter. They're just more intentional. 72% of companies adopted AI in 2024. The question isn't whether to use AI. It's whether you're using it well enough to matter. If you're building, operating, or investing, these resources will help you close that gap faster. And if you know someone who's still on the sidelines, send this to them. It's easier to adapt early than to catch up later. The gap is widening. Fast.

name: gregoire-loeper-7252bb6
content: Analytic formulas in finance: time to move on? In the 19th century, mathematics was all about finding formulas. Solving a differential equation meant writing down an explicit solution. Then something radical happened. Hadamard, Hilbert, Sobolev, and others asked a different question: instead of "can I write down the solution?", they asked "does a solution exist, is it unique, and does it depend continuously on the data?" This shift ‚Äî from analytic solutions to well-posedness ‚Äî was initially seen as a retreat. It turned out to be profoundly liberating. With the right abstract framework, powerful numerical methods were unlocked ‚Äî finite elements, spectral methods, convex optimization ‚Äî that were unthinkable in the old paradigm. It seems that quantitative finance has never really undergone this transition. We are still stuck with analytic formulas ‚Äî Black-Scholes, SABR, analytic approximations for Heston ‚Äî the list goes on. This is all the more striking in an era where computing power is massively and cheaply available. The original motivation for analytic formulas ‚Äî avoiding costly numerical computation ‚Äî has largely disappeared. Yet the formulas remain out of habit. The Black-Scholes formula, beautiful as it is, created an addiction to closed-form expressions. The entire implied volatility surface industry ‚Äî SVI, SSVI, and their variants ‚Äî is essentially a search for parameterizations that fit market prices while (hopefully) satisfying no-arbitrage constraints. But as Jim Gatheral and Antoine Jacquier write in their famous paper "Arbitrage-free SVI volatility surfaces", "[...] indeed, efforts to find simple closed-form arbitrage-free parameterizations of the implied volatility surface are still widely considered to be futile". The reason is structural. No arbitrage, when expressed in the right space (the space of probability measures), is a natural and even linear constraint. Expressing it in terms of implied volatility turns it into an overly complex non-linear constraint. Enforcing no arbitrage within a parametric family is like trying to solve the Navier-Stokes equations by guessing a formula. The way forward is the one mathematics discovered a century ago: stop looking for formulas. Instead, pose the calibration problem in the right space ‚Äî the space of probability measures ‚Äî under a well-posed convex formulation, and solve it numerically. This is exactly what optimal transport methods achieve. They produce solutions that are ‚Üí Arbitrage-free by construction ‚Üí Well-posed ‚Äî existence and uniqueness follow from strict convexity ‚Üí Numerically tractable ‚Äî modern convex optimization The apparent loss ‚Äî giving up the formula ‚Äî is in fact the decisive gain. Abstraction is not the enemy of practice. This post reflects only the author's personal views. #QuantitativeFinance #Derivatives #VolatilitySurface #OptimalTransport #FinancialMathematics #Calibration #Fintech

name: yujunliang
content: In 90s, China just opened the door to the world and it was in great need for CPA, so people from all background, as long as who had a 3 year college degree were encouraged to participate the qualification exam. I saw the opportunity in this field and started working on it. Unlike the certification exams in US, which people can take it whenever they feels ready, this 5 course exam only offered yearly, you need to take them at a 3 day fixed period in a classroom with other exam takers. It took me 3 years to complete all the exams. But before I passed all the exams for CPA qualification in China, I moved out of China. I still flew back to China from Singapore for the last exam and I passed. That's in 1997. 20 years has passed. With the introduction of WeChat, I connected with many old classmates and friends in China. People say I would have become a CFO of a listed company or a partner or owner of some small CPA firms if I hadn't left China. But I left China and now I am a Digital Technologist of Fidelity Investment. I advanced my career from a software engineer to a technical agile coach. I coached teams Agile Software Development methodologies such as Test Driven Development and Behavior Driven Development. Normally coaches are consultants so they don't have corporate titles, but they are required to move the needles regardless. It was a rewarding experience. I also learned a lot through this experience working as a coach, since I had the chance working with a broad spectrum of people inside an organization and it also trained me towards servant leader, since I didn't have authority to order people to do things, but I could give advices and provide help if needed. Due to visa issue, I started a new job in October 2015, working in the DevOps enablement center for Fidelity Investments. I applied my knowledge learned from coaching experience to help the development teams on the DevOps transformation journey. In order to empower the team to be self sufficient, I wrote a book-like collection of document on internal wiki page as "Patterns and Practices of DevOps Pipeline", subtitled as "Mass Pipeline Construction using CloudBees Jenkins"., systematically explained the process of building CI/CD Pipelines using CloudBees Jenkins Platform. Also I self-published a book with my co-author Alex Collins, Selenium WebDriver From Foundations To Framework From May to September, I also spent 4 months to study AWS extensively and acquired all of the certifications offered by Amazon Web Services and I am probably among the first 200 people worldwide who acquired all 5 AWS certifications and I am probably the one using the shortest time span. [ The Pursuit of Happyness - My AWS Certification Journey ] I also passed a Jenkins certification in October. In December, I took remaining vacation days off from work and since I didn't plan to go anywhere, I was looking for something to do. I already got 6 certifications in 2016, I decided to add another two to make it an 8. 8 is the best number in Chinese, which means Prosperous! Some people in China even pay millions to get license plates all in 8. Also I started working on Java in 1999 and got my first Java certification in 2000, that's 16 years ago! Looking back, Java had changed so much. I decided to get certified in Java 8. Once decided, I started preparing for it by reading Jeanne Boyarsky and Scott Selikoff's book on 12/23/2016 and I passed OCA on 12/27/2016 at 91% on a 4 day preparation. There were only 4 days left to the end of 2016, will I be ready for another exam? I wasn't so sure but I started preparing any way. By 1:00 AM on 12/30/2016, I felt confident and booked the exam. And the normal test center was fully booked, I had to book another test center far away. In this 4 day period, I did manage to read the book twice, practised all practice exam twice and reviewed the answers to understand why I failed at the first place. By 6:00PM on 12/31/2016, I passed OCP at 86%. I successfully acquired 8th certification on the last day of the year! It was so rewarding to end a year like this, I felt so young and capable. By the way, I won "Excellence In Action" reward in second quarter from Fidelity Investments in the sub category as "Embrace the Future". Probably, I am the oldest person on that category since I am already 48. I don't regret I left China and even had stayed in China, I might not have been able to become a CFO at all. But It doesn't matter. I relentlessly challenge myself and I enjoy the endless pursuit of excellence! Year 2017 has come, what am I going to pursue?

name: avr27
content: Why it's needed? Before I tell you why it's needed, I'd like to share why I had to do it. The answer is simple: to locally test things in our ML Codebase. Now, coming to why it's needed: Amazon DocumentDB is a managed database service that is designed to be secure. This simply means that the database is hosted privately onto something called Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC). In simple terms, I like to think of it as Amazon's own private internet. So DocumentDB can be directly accessed by any AWS service within the same VPC or any other having required permissions. SSH tunneling is needed when we want to access DocumentDB resources from outside the cluster's VPC, here on our local machine. To access DocumentDB from your local machine, you typically need to go through a bastion host (EC2 instance) using SSH. This extra layer of security ensures that your database connection is not directly exposed to the internet, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. What is SSH Tunneling? SSH tunneling, also known as " port forwarding ," is a technique used to secure and encrypt communication between two computer systems over an unsecured network, such as the Internet. It involves creating a secure channel (tunnel) through which data can be transferred between a local and a remote machine. In simple terms, it's establishing a VPN. In our context: The local machine is the one running your Python script. The remote machine is an EC2 instance in your AWS environment. The SSH tunnel allows secure communication between your local machine and the EC2 instance, providing a secure pathway for data to travel. Once the tunnel is established, you can use it to connect to DocumentDB securely, as if it were running on your local machine. Code Before that, you will need a few important constants you might need. I suggest storing them as environment variables for security purposes. # SSH tunnel configuration SSH_HOST=ec2-x-x-x-x.region.compute.amazonaws.com SSH_USER=ec2-user SSH_KEY_PATH=path to ec2-host-key-pair.pem file LOCAL_BIND_PORT=3000 # any port of your choice # MongoDB server configuration MONGO_HOST=replica_db_name.*.*.docdb.amazonaws.com MONGO_PORT=27017 MONGO_USERNAME=your_monogdb_username MONGO_PASSWORD=your_monogdb_password MONGO_DB_NAME=YOUR_DB_NAME MONGO_COLLECTION_NAME=YOUR_DEFAULT_COLLECTION_NAME # db parameters dict DB_PARAMS = { "host": '127.0.0.1', "port": LOCAL_BIND_PORT, "username": MONGO_USERNAME, "password": MONGO_PASSWORD, } SSH_HOST: is the public IP for your EC2 instance running in the same VPC as your DocumentDB. SSH_KEY_PATH: path to your key-pair.pem file. This is used to authenticate your SSH connection to the EC2 instances. NOTE: Whitelist your IP Address in your EC2 Security Groups before running the code. from pymongo import MongoClient from sshtunnel import SSHTunnelForwarder tunnel = SSHTunnelForwarder( (SSH_HOST, 22), ssh_username=SSH_USER, ssh_pkey=SSH_KEY_PATH, remote_bind_address=(MONGO_HOST, MONGO_PORT), local_bind_address=('127.0.0.1', LOCAL_BIND_PORT) ) # start the tunnel tunnel.start() # get mongo client client = MongoClient( directConnection=True, **DB_PARAMS ) # do something db = client[MONGO_DB_NAME] collection = db[MONGO_COLLECTION_NAME] documents = list(collection.find(some_query)) print(documents) # stop the tunnel and close the client client.close() tunnel.stop() client=None tunnel=None How does this work? Here is a simple picture to describe it: The figure presents a simplified overview of SSH tunneling. The secure connection over the untrusted network is established between an SSH client and an SSH server. This SSH connection is encrypted, protects confidentiality and integrity, and authenticates communicating parties. The SSH connection is used by the application ( our Python code ) to connect to the application server ( Mongo/DocDB Server ). With tunneling enabled, the application contacts a port ( = 3000 ) on the local host ( '127.0.0.1' ) that the SSH client listens on. The SSH client then forwards the application over its encrypted tunnel to the server ( EC2 Instance ). The server then connects to the actual application server ( DocumentDB ) - usually on the same machine or in the same data center as the SSH server. The application communication is thus secured without having to modify the application or end-user workflows. References: What is SSH Tunneling? - by ssh.com AWS Docs: Link 1 , Link 2 , Link 3 StackOverflow Post Tags: Amazon Amazon Web Services (AWS)
clean_content: why it's needed? before i tell you why it's needed, i'd like to share why i had to do it. the answer is simple: to locally test things in our ml codebase. now, coming to why it's needed: amazon documentdb is a managed database service that is designed to be secure. this simply means that the database is hosted privately onto something called amazon virtual private cloud amazon vpc. in simple terms, i like to think of it as amazon's own private internet. so documentdb can be directly accessed by any aws service within the same vpc or any other having required permissions. ssh tunneling is needed when we want to access documentdb resources from outside the cluster's vpc, here on our local machine. to access documentdb from your local machine, you typically need to go through a bastion host ec2 instance using ssh. this extra layer of security ensures that your database connection is not directly exposed to the internet, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. what is ssh tunneling? ssh tunneling, also known as " port forwarding ," is a technique used to secure and encrypt communication between two computer systems over an unsecured network, such as the internet. it involves creating a secure channel tunnel through which data can be transferred between a local and a remote machine. in simple terms, it's establishing a vpn. in our context: the local machine is the one running your python script. the remote machine is an ec2 instance in your aws environment. the ssh tunnel allows secure communication between your local machine and the ec2 instance, providing a secure pathway for data to travel. once the tunnel is established, you can use it to connect to documentdb securely, as if it were running on your local machine. code before that, you will need a few important constants you might need. i suggest storing them as environment variables for security purposes. # ssh tunnel configuration sshhostec2-x-x-x-x.region.compute.amazonaws.com sshuserec2-user sshkeypathpath to ec2-host-key-pair.pem file localbindport3000 # any port of your choice # mongodb server configuration mongohostreplicadbname...docdb.amazonaws.com mongoport27017 mongousernameyourmonogdbusername mongopasswordyourmonogdbpassword mongodbnameyourdbname mongocollectionnameyourdefaultcollectionname # db parameters dict dbparams   "host": '127.0.0.1', "port": localbindport, "username": mongousername, "password": mongopassword,  sshhost: is the public ip for your ec2 instance running in the same vpc as your documentdb. sshkeypath: path to your key-pair.pem file. this is used to authenticate your ssh connection to the ec2 instances. note: whitelist your ip address in your ec2 security groups before running the code. from pymongo import mongoclient from sshtunnel import sshtunnelforwarder tunnel  sshtunnelforwarder sshhost, 22, sshusernamesshuser, sshpkeysshkeypath, remotebindaddressmongohost, mongoport, localbindaddress'127.0.0.1', localbindport  # start the tunnel tunnel.start # get mongo client client  mongoclient directconnectiontrue, dbparams  # do something db  clientmongodbname collection  dbmongocollectionname documents  listcollection.findsomequery printdocuments # stop the tunnel and close the client client.close tunnel.stop clientnone tunnelnone how does this work? here is a simple picture to describe it: the figure presents a simplified overview of ssh tunneling. the secure connection over the untrusted network is established between an ssh client and an ssh server. this ssh connection is encrypted, protects confidentiality and integrity, and authenticates communicating parties. the ssh connection is used by the application  our python code  to connect to the application server  mongodocdb server . with tunneling enabled, the application contacts a port   3000  on the local host  '127.0.0.1'  that the ssh client listens on. the ssh client then forwards the application over its encrypted tunnel to the server  ec2 instance . the server then connects to the actual application server  documentdb  - usually on the same machine or in the same data center as the ssh server. the application communication is thus secured without having to modify the application or end-user workflows. references: what is ssh tunneling? - by ssh.com aws docs: link 1 , link 2 , link 3 stackoverflow post tags: amazon amazon web services aws

name: ashishkhichi
content: Are you building a Chain or a Brain? üß† Most teams moving from LangChain to LangGraph hit a wall. It‚Äôs not a syntax problem; it‚Äôs a mental model shift. In the financial sector, we‚Äôre used to deterministic workflows. Step A ‚Üí Step B. But Agentic AI demands a pivot: Thinking in Cycles, not Chains. Here is the anatomy of a LangGraph workflow, decoded for the Architect: üîπ The State (The Shared Ledger) Not just a variable, but the "source of truth" flowing through the graph. Every node reads it; every node updates it. It‚Äôs the persistence layer of the conversation. üîπ Nodes (The Microservices) Isolated units of logic (LLM calls, Tool executions). Nodes are decoupled; they don't know who came before or what comes next. They only know the State. üîπ Edges (The Intelligent Router) This is where the "intelligence" actually lives. Static: Direct handoffs. Conditional: The decision-making logic that determines the next hop based on the current State. üîπ Cycles (The Feedback Loop) The "Killer App" of LangGraph. This allows for iterative refinement. Agent ‚Üí Tool ‚Üí Evaluate ‚Üí Not sufficient? ‚Üí Loop back. This is how we move from "One-shot" prompts to "Reasoning" agents. üîπ Persistence (The Time Machine) State checkpoints that allow for human-in-the-loop interruptions, debugging, and "time-travel" to previous states. The Bottom Line: If your agent is a straight line, you‚Äôve just built a very expensive script. LangGraph allows us to build dynamic decision graphs that handle the messiness of real-world data and retries natively. Stop building sequences. Start architecting cycles. #GenerativeAI #LangGraph #CloudArchitecture #LLMOps #AgenticAI

name: juhiibhatia
content: I called a candidate today while he was in the car with his family. During the call, I heard his wife and kids talking and he said, ‚ÄúBe quiet, It's Juhi and she is saying I am selected.‚Äù I smiled and kept going with the call. Afterward, he told me he had been waiting for it for days.. This is exactly why I say candidates aren‚Äôt numbers. They‚Äôre people. Every time I pick up the phone to extend an offer, I never know how much that moment might mean to someone. I may not make the final hiring decision, but being the one who gets to say ‚Äúyou are selected‚Äù will never get old."

name: rakeshgohel01
content: The challenge of managing multiple AI agents in complex systems has long been a thorn in the side of AI development. It‚Äôs a scenario all too familiar: as projects scale, coordinating diverse AI agents becomes akin to herding particularly willful cats. Enter Swarm, a newly launched library that‚Äôs poised to revolutionize how multi-agent AI systems are orchestrated. Unveiled just yesterday by OpenAI, Swarm tackles head-on the complexities that have plagued large-scale AI projects. This isn‚Äôt about incremental improvements; it‚Äôs a fundamental rethinking of how AI agents interact and collaborate within a system. The Multi-Agent Dilemma Before diving into what Swarm offers, it‚Äôs worth revisiting the core issues it aims to solve: Coordination Overhead : As the number of specialized agents grows, so does the complexity of managing their interactions. Context Switching : Ensuring smooth transitions between agents while maintaining context has been a persistent challenge. Scalability Bottlenecks : Traditional approaches often hit performance walls when scaling to hundreds or thousands of agents. Error Propagation : In interconnected systems, errors in one agent can cascade, affecting overall system reliability. Swarm‚Äôs approach to these issues is both innovative and pragmatic, built on two core concepts: Routines and Handoffs. Routines: Teaching Your AI Agents to Dance t the core of Swarm is the idea of routines. Think of them as step-by-step plans for your AI agents. Here‚Äôs a quick example that might save you some headaches: def customer_support_routine(query): steps = [ "Greet the customer", "Identify the problem category", "Attempt to resolve or escalate if needed", "Confirm resolution or next steps", "Close interaction politely" ] for step in steps: response = ai_model.generate( f"Step: {step}\nQuery: {query}\nResponse:" ) yield response # Usage for response in customer_support_routine("My order is late"): print(response) This routine keeps your agent on track without using rigid, hard-coded decision trees. It‚Äôs flexible enough to handle surprises but structured enough to stay consistent. Handoffs: No More AI Agent Silos Here‚Äôs where Swarm really shines. Handoffs let your agents step aside when they‚Äôre out of their depth. It‚Äôs like a relay race for AIs: class SalesAgent(Agent): def handle(self, query): if "technical" in query.lower(): return self.handoff(TechSupportAgent()) # Handle sales query... class TechSupportAgent(Agent): def handle(self, query): if "pricing" in query.lower(): return self.handoff(SalesAgent()) # Handle tech support query... # Usage agent = SalesAgent() response = agent.handle("I need technical help with my gadget") print(response) # This will come from TechSupportAgent No more awkward ‚Äúlet me transfer you‚Äù moments. Your AI system moves smoothly between specialized agents. Swarm vs. The World Now, I know what you‚Äôre thinking. ‚ÄúGreat, another framework to add to the pile.‚Äù Fair enough. Let‚Äôs break down how Swarm compares to some of the other popular tools out there: Langchain : Great for chaining LLM operations, but it can be too much for simpler agent interactions. Swarm is more focused on making agents work together smoothly. LlamaIndex : Awesome for data retrieval and indexing. If your agents need to go through a lot of data, use LlamaIndex. Swarm works well alongside it by managing the agents that use that data. Semantic Kernel : Microsoft‚Äôs offering is solid, especially if you‚Äôre deep in the Microsoft ecosystem. Swarm is more lightweight and works with different platforms. Swarm‚Äôs strength lies in its native support for multi-agent orchestration, particularly for complex, dynamic workflows. Real Talk: When to Use Swarm Swarm is best when: You‚Äôre working with multiple specialized AI agents. Your workflow needs to change dynamically (not just follow a fixed sequence). You want detailed control without dealing with a lot of extra code. Keep in mind: Swarm was just launched yesterday, and it‚Äôs not production-ready yet. It‚Äôs still early days, so there might be some bumps along the way. It‚Äôs not for you if: You need heavy-duty data processing (stick with LlamaIndex). You‚Äôre doing simple, straightforward LLM chains (Langchain might be easier). You‚Äôre fully invested in Microsoft‚Äôs AI tools (Semantic Kernel) Strategic Considerations Scalability : Swarm‚Äôs architecture could reduce operational costs for large-scale AI deployments. Development Speed : Simplifying complex agent interactions may accelerate project timelines. Adaptability : Dynamic agent composition opens up possibilities for more responsive AI systems. Quality Assurance : Built-in error handling and monitoring tools can enhance service reliability. Looking Ahead: Challenges and Opportunities Integration : How will Swarm fit into existing AI stacks? Performance at Scale : Can it handle thousands of concurrent agents efficiently? Standardization : Could Swarm‚Äôs approach become an industry standard for agent orchestration? Metrics and Debugging: How will you track agent performance and identify issues? Agent Evaluation: How will you evaluate the performance of individual agents? Compatibility with Guardrails: How will Swarm work with safety guardrails? Security and Privacy: How will Swarm handle data privacy and secure communication between agents? Maintenance Overhead: What kind of maintenance will Swarm require as it evolves? Wrapping Up: Is Swarm Worth Your Time? If you‚Äôre tired of struggling to keep your AI agents working well together, Swarm might be worth trying. It‚Äôs not perfect (nothing in AI is), but it helps make managing multi-agent systems much simpler. Try it on your next project. If it saves you from even one late-night debugging session, I‚Äôd call that a win. Happy building, and may your agents always work well together! P.S. If you try out Swarm and have feedback, let me know. This field moves fast, and sharing real experiences helps everyone improve.

name: vinothgovindarajan
content: I spent this long weekend doing something I genuinely enjoy, reading through OpenClaw‚Äôs docs and source code to understand the ‚Äúmagic‚Äù under the hood. ü¶û And once you strip away the hype, it‚Äôs not magic ‚Äî it‚Äôs architecture. OpenClaw feels autonomous. But under the hood, it‚Äôs essentially: ‚Ä¢ A centralized Gateway control plane ‚Ä¢ Session-isolated state on disk ‚Ä¢ A lane-aware queue (1 active run per session) ‚Ä¢ An event-driven loop (time + messages + hooks + webhooks) When you see it this way, the autonomy illusion becomes understandable: Time creates an event ‚Üí The Gateway routes it ‚Üí The agent runs a turn ‚Üí State is written ‚Üí Tools execute ‚Üí Result delivered. No sentience. No background ‚Äúthinking.‚Äù Just inputs + state + a disciplined loop. I wrote up my learnings in Part 1 of a multi-part series, breaking down: ‚Äì The control plane ‚Äì Session isolation ‚Äì The command queue ‚Äì The runtime loop ‚Äì Where ‚Äúmemory‚Äù actually lives ‚Äì And why security is a first-class concern If you're building or evaluating agent systems, understanding these invariants matters. Also exciting to see OpenClaw founder Peter Steinberger joining OpenAI ‚Äî thoughtful agent architecture is clearly becoming more important. Here‚Äôs the full breakdown: https://lnkd.in/gqjksRWs #OpenClaw #Agents #AI #OpenSource

name: dschiff
content: #AI continues to be high on the priority list of every #bank Board and C-suite, but the lens is is often just focused on opportunities and challenges for the bank itself. Too few are discussing in a meaningful and structured way the implications of AI on business models for commercial clients. As a result, we are starting to see evidence of wildly varied ways credit committees are considering potential AI impact to sectors and individual companies. I enjoyed speaking with Marketplace by APM on NPR last night about the Federal Reserve Board 's recent Senior Lending Officer Opinion Survey (SLOOS), and what some of the special questions revealed about the diverse opinions of AI's impact on #credit decisions. What do you think? Is this a blind spot for the industry that deserves more attention from Boards, the #CCO or #CRO , and #CreditCommittees ? Or is AI just another macro factor to be absorbed into standard #commercial #loan decisioning? David Messinger Dana Twomey Mark Sexton Caitlin Holmes, CPA Joe Knight Kyle Wetzold https://lnkd.in/g-qT2sBk

name: bhagyalaxmi-sahoo-77b25979
content: Rajya Sabha MP Swati Maliwal from New Delhi made a blunt and honest statement in Parliament. During her speech, she said that the hospital system in the country is in a very poor state. She pointed out that bed charges in big hospitals are even higher than those of five-star hotels. She said that when an ordinary person goes to a large private hospital for treatment, the first question asked is whether the patient has insurance. The moment the patient says yes, the hospital‚Äôs ‚Äúbilling meter‚Äù starts running. According to her, patients are then given medicines they do not actually need, unnecessary tests are conducted, and inflated or fake bills are generated. She further added that if a patient could normally recover in five days, having insurance often results in the hospital keeping the patient admitted for 10 to 15 days. Swati Maliwal urged the government to seriously look into this issue and protect common people from being exploited by the healthcare system.
